PETITION.TITLE: Family Law
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the child support scheme.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate support the following changes.

PETITION.PARA: (1)That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

(2)That the Family Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel; the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.
(3)That legal professionals be barred from appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast savings to the disputing parties.
(4)That a modified fault clause be re-introduced to Family Law primarily designed to discourage adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the expense of deserted and innocent parties.
(5)That the Child Support Agency be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate administrative procedure within the Tribunal.
(6)That apart from cases of exceptional circumstances parental-child access become the inalienable right of all parents.

(7)That alternative counselling, (Government funded) be made available through the Churches and that much more emphasis be placed on mediation in resolving disputes prior to the commencement of legal proceedings.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Kemp (from 800 citizens) and Senator Spindler (from 1,200 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Building Materials
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of certain residents of Australia respectfully showeth that the tax on selected building products, proposed in the May, 1995 Budget, will place an unwelcome burden on all Australians planning to build a new home, or carry out alterations and additions, or repairs/maintenance to existing homes. Moreover, it is considered that the tax is iniquitous in that, when introduced, it will apply retrospectively to people currently building homes, who had entered in good faith into "fixed price" building contracts.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should reject the extension of proposed wholesale sales tax to building products.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Building Materials
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned citizens strongly urge the Government to accept the Democrats' proposal to drop the intended tax on essential building materials.

We believe the proposed tax—adding between $600 and $1,200 on the cost of a medium-sized home and up to $3,000 over the life of a mortgage—will make it more difficult for Australians to buy their own home, increase maintenance costs and rents on existing houses, and hinder growth in the building industry.
We call on the Government to drop the tax on essential building materials.

PETITION.TITLE: Chemical Registration
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned respectfully call upon the Federal Government to introduce legislation that will require the National Registration Authority to provide all available information on registered chemicals.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Guide
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.We are opposed to the sex guide endorsed by Ms Lawrence, Minister for Health in the Keating Government, and published in the December issue of Cleo.
2.We believe that the sex guide encourages dangerous sexual practices which could have serious medical and moral effects.

PARA.TAB: We request the Senate to call on Ms Lawrence to withdraw her endorsement of this sex guide and for the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, to indicate his disapproval.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.PARA: 30 March 1995CAO Part 105; AD/BEECH 33/32 Amdt 2; AD/BEECH 35/59 Amdt 2; AD/BEECH 36/31 Amdt 2; AD/BEECH 55/69 Amdt 2; AD/BEECH 56/27 Amdt 2; AD/BEECH 60/40 Amdt 2; AD/BEECH 65/62 Amdt 2; and AD/BEECH 90/78 Amdt 2; and AD/DHC-8/34 Amdt 1.
11 May 1995CAO Part 105 AD/BELL 214/13 Amdt 1; CAO Part 105 AD/BELL 214/17; CAO Part 105 AD/EMB 110/27 Amdt 3, and CAO Part 105 AD/HU 369/41 Amdt 8.

I trust that you will understand the delay in replying. The Minister has received a large volume of correspondence in recent months on a range of transport matters and it is taking us more than the usual time to work through replies to everyone.

You have asked whether these amendments may have retrospective effect so as to be in breach of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 in relation to the retrospective operation of subordinate legislation. Since the reasons for perceived retrospectivity are similar in each case, I am responding to the three letters at the one time.

I have been advised by the Civil Aviation Authority that in none of the above cases was it intended that the amendments were to have retrospective effect. The apparent problem that you have drawn to my Minister's attention appears to be a direct result of the style used by the Authority to notify amendments of Airworthiness Directives. Although legislation in Australia is normally amended by textual amendment, a different system has be followed in relation to the amendment of Airworthiness Directives. Any change to a Directive is incorporated into the existing text of the Directive and the complete Directive is then promulgated. Therefore, when a Directive includes a date of effect (which may go back to the date on which the Directive was originally made) and the Directive is later amended, the later Directive may appear to have some form of retrospective operation when in fact no retrospectivity was involved nor intended.

I have been further advised that the amendment of Airworthiness Directives in this form has been used for many years and the aviation industry is well aware of the system used. An operator or other person who has airworthiness responsibilities for an aircraft has the full text of a Directive to hand at all times. Thus it would appear that the present system has distinct benefits for the aviation industry. If amendments were distributed to the industry in the form of a textual amendment, the text presently in use would have to be amended by a hand-written notation or otherwise.

In light of your comments, however, and to overcome the problem of perceived retrospectivity, the Authority has examined its procedures. It now proposes that in future all amendments of Airworthiness Directives be made as simple textual amendments with the date of effect clearly shown. Each amendment will be tabled in the Parliament however, it is proposed that industry be advised of amendments with the distribution of the full text of each Directive with the amendment included. The Authority also proposes to attach a copy of this full text to the Explanatory Statement relating to each amendment.

Since amendments prepared and made in this format will only state the precise changes being made to an Airworthiness Directive, it should overcome the Committee's concerns about the possibility of amendments being seen to have retrospective effect.
I understand that officers of the Authority plan to discuss the above proposals with the Committee's staff in the near future.
I thank you for bringing this matter to my Minister's attention.
Kindest regards

Thank you for your letter dated 28 March 1995 to my Minister, concerning the identifying notation given to amendments to the CAOs. Advice on this matter has now been received from the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA).

I trust that you will understand the delay in replying. The Minister has received a large volume of correspondence in recent months on a range of transport matters and it is taking us more than the usual time to work through replies to everyone.

The CAA has advised me that the amendments are raised frequently to AD/PROP/1 in order to accommodate new safety information. To facilitate economical amendment of this Airworthiness Directive (AD), the CAA does not re-issue the entire AD on each occasion that a change is required. Instead, the particular section of the AD (ie. manufacturer group) that requires amendment is re-issued as a partial amendment to AD/PROP/l. Its individual Amendment List number is printed opposite the manufacturer group sub-heading. As the entire AD is not replaced under these arrangements, the CAA does not consider it to be appropriate to add an amendment number to the AD.
The approach adopted by the CAA makes it clear when a change to the overhaul period for an affected propellor was made (eg 1/95, 8/71 etc).
The basis upon which amendments are made, as outlined above, is explained in more detail in the "NOTE" on Page I of the Airworthiness Directive.

However, the CAA acknowledges that the format utilised printing the AD title "PROPELLORS—GENERAL" and headings for sections within the AD, such as the "PROPELLORS OVERHAUL" section, has not been consistent on all past amendments. To clarify the situation, the CAA will ensure that future amendments issued to CAO Part 107 will have both the AD title and AD section headings printed at the top of each page.

Dear Senator Mal

I refer to your letter of 27 March 1995 requesting my advice in relation to matters contained in amendments to the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations (the Regulations) effected by Statutory Rule No. 15 of 1995.

The amendments to the Regulations contained in this Statutory Rule primarily deal with import controls with respect to firearms and parts for firearms. Under regulation 3 and item 24 of Schedule 1 of the Regulations, the importation into Australia of firearms other than exempt firearms is prohibited absolutely. Under regulation 3 and item 25 of Schedule 1, the importation of parts specifically for firearms other than exempt firearms is also prohibited absolutely.

"Exempt firearm" is defined in subregulation 2(l) of the Regulations and includes firearms imported for official purposes and handguns in respect of which the importer holds a state or territory licence or authorisation to possess the handgun. The importation of exempt firearms is governed by subregulation 4(2) and Part 1 of Schedule 3 of the Regulations. In short, the importation of such firearms is prohibited unless the conditions, restrictions or requirements specified in that Schedule are complied with. At present, the only condition that applies to exempt firearms is that such firearms must satisfy the safety requirements specified in Part 2 of Schedule 3. Certain classes of exempt firearms have also been excluded from this condition.

Apart from the new import controls in respect of parts for certain exempt firearms inserted by Statutory Rule No. 15 1995, there are no other import controls on parts for exempt firearms. These new import controls in new regulation 4DB of the Regulations make the importation of parts for firearms imported for use in films or in the development of mountings for a laser target designator subject to the requirement that the Minister for Justice must give permission for their importation. The importation of such parts is subject to the further conditions that the parts must only be used for such firearms and that the parts, if not used, must be exported within 6 months of their importation.

The amendments to the Regulations by Statutory Rule No. 15 introduced a new category of "exempt firearm" into subregulation 2(1), being firearms in respect of which the importer produces to the Collector a written permission under subregulation 4DA(l). New regulation 4DA allows the Minister for Justice to give permission for the importation of a firearm for use in the development of mountings for a laser target designator. As stated in the Explanatory Memorandum a laser target designator is a simulated firearm training system which is mounted onto a firearm. This category of exempt firearm was inserted into the Regulations to enable the importation of such firearms. These firearms are unavailable in Australia and, in order for effective and practical mountings to be developed, it was necessary to exempt them from the general import prohibition applying to firearms.

The method by which this new category of exempt firearm is effected is identical to an existing category of exempt firearms, being firearms for use in films in respect of which the importer produces a permission under subregulation 4D(1) for its importation. Under regulation 4D, the Minister for Justice may give permission for the importation of firearms if satisfied that the firearm is to be used in connection with the production of a film.
Before the Minister for Justice may grant a permission under either subregulation 4D(1) or 4DA(1), he or she must be satisfied of three matters:
1.that the firearm is not available in Australia;
2.that the firearm is to be used in connection with the production of a film (regulation 4D) or in the development of mountings for a laser target designator (regulation 4DA); and
3.that the use will occur in a State or Territory in which the importer holds a licence or authorisation in accordance with the law of the State or Territory to possess a firearm of that kind.
If the Minister for Justice is not satisfied of all of these matters, he or she cannot grant the permission under either subregulation 4D(l) or 4DA(l).

If a permission is granted, under both regulation 4D and 4DA, the importation of a firearm in accordance with the permission is subject to the condition that firearm be re-exported within 6 months of its importation. Longer periods for re-exportation can be specified in the permission. A permission can also specify other conditions or requirements that must be complied with, such as requirements as to the secure storage of the firearm and accounting and reporting requirements.

A decision by the Minister for Justice to refuse to grant a permission to import a firearm under either subregulation 4D(1) or 4DA(1) is not subject to merits review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The matters of which the Minister must be satisfied before he or she can grant a permission are based on high government policy considerations of public safety. First, the Minister must be satisfied of the limited use to which the firearms will be put. The fact that permission can only be granted in respect of limited use will ensure that the firearms the subject of the permission will not enter the general circulation of the national stock of firearms. The fact that the Minister must be satisfied of the limited use to which the firearms will be put is necessary because such firearms would otherwise be, without his or her permission, prohibited imports.

Secondly, the Minister must be satisfied that the importer holds a licence or authorisation to possess the firearm in the relevant State or Territory in which the firearm is to be used. Again, in the interests of public safety, the Minister for Justice cannot grant a permission to import a firearm that an importer is not licensed or authorised to possess.

Therefore, if the Minister is not satisfied of these matters, permission to import would not be granted and this refusal would be based on the high government policy ground of public safety. It is not considered desirable to have merits review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of refusals of permission when based on high government policy grounds such as this one, or national security and defence reasons of international treaty obligations. This has been acknowledged previously by the Committee and indeed is reflected in the position taken in respect of the controls on the importation of goods under regulation 4 (the importation of goods in Schedule 2), regulation 4AB (the importation of polychlorinated biphenyls), regulation 4C (the importation of coffee), regulations 4QA, 4QB and 4QC (the importation of goods from specified countries presently under United Nations sanctions) and regulation 4R (the importation of radioactive substances).

Under these regulations, the refusal to grant permission to import is not subject to independent review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunals. As with regulations 4D and 4DA, however, the decision maker who might refuse an import permission is restricted to a Minister on the ground that the necessary corollary to the high government policy exception to the reviewability of decisions is that the decision is ultimately made by the Government's relevant policy Minister. This has equally been acknowledged in the past by the Committee as an appropriate control on the high government policy exception to the reviewability of decisions.

Under the Regulations, the only decisions to refuse an import permission that are subject to independent review are decisions under the Health portfolio under regulations 5 (drugs), 5A (antibiotics) and 5H (goods in Schedule 8). While the refusal by the Attorney-General not to grant permission for the importation of objectionable goods under regulation 4A may be subject to independent review, this right may be restricted where the Attorney certifies that it would be in the public interest that he or she bears the responsibility for the refusal.

The amendments to the Regulations contained in new regulation 4DB complement regulations 4D and 4DA and introduce the requirement for a permission to import parts for firearms imported in accordance with a permission granted under these regulations. This import control was introduced to address concerns relating to what would otherwise be the unrestricted importation of parts for such firearms. As referred to above, there are no import controls on parts for exempt firearms. There were concerns that an importer could import parts for firearms imported under regulation 4D or 4DA and then assemble in Australia what would otherwise be a prohibited firearm.

Therefore, the refusal to grant permission to import parts for such firearms would be based on the same high government policy grounds of public safety as the refusal to grant a permission under regulation 4D or 4DA. The absolute prohibition on the importation of firearms for public safety reasons is only to be relaxed in certain limited circumstances where the Executive is satisfied the proposed use of the firearms comes within its interpretation of the nominated exceptions. It is considered that merits review by the non-elected Administrative Appeals Tribunal of refusals of permission when based on such high government policy grounds is inconsistent with the doctrine of Government responsibility in the Westminster system.

I do concede, however, as the Commonwealth has noted, that other regulations under the Regulations do provide for independent merits review. This might indeed make an attempted distinction between the non-reviewability of decisions on the importation of firearms and parts for certain firearms (regulations 4D, 4DA and 4DB) and the reviewability of decisions refusing to grant permissions or licences to import drugs or antibiotics (regulations 5, 5A and 5HA) difficult. I note this will be considered in the Government's response to the Australian Law Reform Commission's report on the Customs and Excise legislation which is currently being settled, so that a consistent position on the reviewability of these types of decisions is forthcoming.
I trust that the above comments are of assistance to the Committee.
Yours sincerely
CHRIS SCHACHT

Dear Mal

I refer to your letter of 28 March 1995 regarding two minor discrepancies in Quarantine Determination No. 1 of 1995, made under section 86E of the Quarantine Act 1908. Your letter followed consideration of this Determination by the Senate Standing Committee at its meeting on 23 March 1995.

You highlighted the fact that Paragraph 8(A) of the Schedule sets out fees for the use of a quarantine station for the management of animals "at Cocos Island", and that there are several Cocos Islands throughout the world. As you presume, the quarantine station is located on Cocos (Keeling) Islands. An amendment is therefore required to specify that the quarantine station is located on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands.

The Committee also points out an inconsistency with the reference in subparagraph 8(B)(j) to paragraphs (a-j) (inclusive). As suggested by the Committee, this reference should be to paragraphs (a-i) (inclusive).

The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) is currently in the process of consulting with industry groups on fee levels for the 1995-96 financial year. A number of fee reductions are expected to result which will require a new Quarantine Determination to be issued by I July 1995.
I thank the Committee for pointing out these errors in the Determination, and I undertake to amend the discrepancies in the new Determination to be issued by 1 July 1995.
Yours sincerely
(Bob Collins)

Senator Panizza—It is not rubbish. I have never heard of anyone being stopped in the middle of a notice of motion. I believe that the procedure in the past has been for notices of motion to be ruled upon later by Mr President or whoever looks at them to see whether they are in order. I think Senator Baume should be allowed to proceed.

Senator Sherry—Mr President, on the point of order: I submit that there was enough of that so-called notice of motion read out for you to conclude that it was not in conformity with the standing orders. Mr President, you do not have to listen to someone's abuse or incorrect views in full to conclude that they are wrong.

Senator Ian Macdonald—Mr President, on the point of order: I would appreciate seeing in writing how you came to your ruling and under what standing order. It is also quite inappropriate to rule without having heard the notice of motion in full. If your ruling on this is that Senator Baume is making a mockery of the giving of notices of motion, why do you not have a rule about your colleagues in the Labor Party making an absolute mockery of question time every day by refusing—
Senator Sherry—That is not relevant.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Keep to the point of order.

PARA.TAB: Senator Ian Macdonald—Yes. If you are talking about making mockeries of the process, how do you distinguish between this and evidence every day that the Labor Party makes an absolute mockery of question time by refusing to answer questions, by talking about things that are not asked, by continually referring to the opposition and by asking us questions when question time is for us to ask government ministers questions and to get answers on their portfolios, not tirades about the opposition? If are you going to rule on the basis of mockery, you must be consistent all the way through and start stopping the Labor Party ministers in the way that they make an absolute mockery of parliament and question time every day of the parliamentary sittings.

Senator Michael Baume—Mr President, on the point of order: the question of making a mockery of procedure is, with respect, irrelevant in this matter in that there are other opportunities that I or any other senator could take for getting this matter on the record. You are basically saying that this matter, which can be put on the record at any other time during the day, is somehow not capable of being put on the record at this time because it is `satirical'. I put to you that it is a matter of your judgment whether something that is satirical is making a mockery of the parliament or whether it is quite properly pointing out to the parliament a matter that merits satire. If your judgment is that satire is an insult to the parliament, Mr President, I fear that you have lost your sense of humour. But I thank you very much. What you have done has made certain that this little verse will receive a lot of publicity. Thank you.

Senator West—Mr President, I rise on the point of order in relation to whether that notice of motion was in order. The question I wanted to ask you was: was it in order? I would suggest that the references to the Prime Minister and the members of the other house without the use of correct titles are, in fact, out of order and unparliamentary.

Senator Abetz—Mr President, I rise on the point of order. With due respect, I do not think it is appropriate for you to make a ruling on the basis that you perceive a certain notice of motion to be mocking. There is a great degree of mocking that takes place here. The Liberal Party mocks the Labor Party and vice versa. Your ruling ought to be based on the standing orders, whether or not it is competent—
Senator Sherry—It is.

Senator Abetz—There is no precedent, with due respect, to argue that a notice of motion is out of order because it is in some way mocking certain activities within the Australian Labor Party. The ruling ought to be on technical grounds and not on perceived political embarrassment.

Mr President, on the basis of your numerous rulings that frustrate us on this side of the house each and every question time, when you say you are unable to determine whether or not an answer is relevant or appropriate because you believe the minister is still developing his or her answer, I would have thought it appropriate for you to have listened and allowed Senator Baume to develop his notice of motion to its conclusion and then made the appropriate ruling.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you have made your point of order, haven't you?

PARA.TAB: Senator Abetz—All right, if you rule so, Mr President.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to what Senator Panizza raised, both courses of action—either raising it straightaway in the Senate chamber or afterwards—are in order and commonly done in both cases, so I have a right to intervene here. As for my not having a sense of humour and not accepting that satire has its place in this chamber, that is not the case. There are appropriate places for that to be raised and the giving of notices of motion is not an appropriate place. The standing order that applies here is quite clear. Standing order 76(7) states in full:

PARA.TAB: A notice shall consist of a clear and succinct proposed resolution or order of the Senate relating to matters within the competence of the Senate, and shall not contain statements, quotations or other matter not strictly necessary to make the proposed resolution or order intelligible.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think the other matters raised were relevant, but I rule this out of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that notice of motion No. 1644 standing in the name of the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Kernot, relating to underground nuclear testing and the mining and export of uranium, be taken as formal.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion standing in the name of the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Kernot, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Kernot moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 1644 standing in the name of Senator Kernot, relating to nuclear weapons testing and uranium.

SPEECH.PARA: This is, after all, the substantive issue. The issue is not whether our Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) went to France; it is not whether he went with other Pacific island nations; it is not what was discussed; it is not how hard he hit the French minister over the back of the wrist with a wet noodle. The substantive issue is whether Australia is aiding and abetting the testing of nuclear weapons by France by supplying France with nuclear material.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats argue most strongly that we are and that we should consequently be doing everything within our power to ensure that that testing—presumably it is the intention of the French to use those nuclear weapons, if need be—be inhibited. This is a matter of extreme importance, and that is why we are moving for the suspension of standing orders this morning.

There is no place at all in a modern world for nuclear weapons. We have seen exactly what nuclear weapons can do. We know that nuclear weapons can never be used in time of war. The development of nuclear weapons and the testing of nuclear weapons depend ultimately on the supply of uranium which comes from mines in the ground, and much of that uranium comes from Australia. This is the link between the Australian exports and the French tests, and this is why this is precisely the action that Australia should be taking. We should be stopping those exports to France here and now. There is no need for us to export uranium to France. It was claimed in the early days, when the Ranger mine began in the Northern Territory—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I thought that we were debating why we should suspend standing orders rather than the substantive motion, yet that is what Senator Coulter seems to be doing, so I would like you to rule that he be brought back to the subject of the debate at this moment. If he succeeds in suspending standing orders, by all means we will debate it, but let him stick to the point at this stage.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, on the question before you: Senator Panizza is being vexatious. There is an agreement among all the parties that, in this five minutes, we can range over these issues to establish the importance of the need to suspend standing orders this morning.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—Technically, Senator Panizza is correct. I am quite happy to allow some latitude, but I would like you to relate your remarks, to some extent, to why there is urgency and why standing orders should be suspended.

TALK.START.PARA: —The urgency, Madam Acting Deputy President, is that we are facing French nuclear tests. The French, clearly, would use those nuclear weapons, otherwise there is no point in testing them, and Australia is providing uranium to France—providing the raw material for those weapons to be manufactured. That is why it is urgent. No other issue is more urgent than this issue—and that is the sense of the notice of motion which has been put down by the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Kernot. That is why it is important that it should take precedence over all other matters this morning. That is why it is so urgent.

PARA.TAB: I was going on to explain that there is no need for us to export the uranium to France. There is not the enormous profits in the export of uranium to France, or to any other countries, that was anticipated in the 1970s. We have had to abolish the floor price. The expansion of the uranium mine at Ranger has not occurred. We could do many other things instead of exporting uranium to France or, indeed, to other countries.

Most Australians, in fact all I have spoken to, are intensely annoyed, absolutely angry, at the inaction of the Australian government on this important issue and are calling for Australia to take much stronger action. What more significant action could we take than to stop the export of that raw material on which both the civil nuclear program and the military nuclear program are based.

We know that the French are one of the few nations in the world that are reprocessing the uranium, the spent fuel from nuclear weapons. We know that in that reprocessing they are making the raw material for bombs. We know that under the NPT they can then proceed to actually test and use those bombs. This is indeed the substantive issue that we should be debating. It is the most important issue before this parliament at the present time and it is urgent that we debate it this morning. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is urgent that we actually deal with this issue. Anybody watching Lateline last night would have seen the changes that are occurring right now within the international community and would have realised how serious and very urgent this situation is.

PARA.TAB: We heard last night that the United States, with the concurrence of our Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans, is suggesting that even after a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty they would like to continue with what they call `benchtop tests'. They are talking about several kilograms of nuclear material. Quite frankly, I do not think the bench would survive that. That is not what I would consider a benchtop test. France is saying that they will stop testing, but what they mean is that they want to continue testing up to several hundred kilograms of nuclear materials.

The urgency now is that, clearly, even last night the message has not got through to our Minister for Foreign Affairs. He is still right there on national television supporting the nuclear states by suggesting that limited nuclear tests are part of a so-called comprehensive test ban treaty. The urgency of this motion is highlighted by the ability of countries continuing to upgrade nuclear weaponry while being part of a so-called comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty.

This government, despite some statements, is not taking this at all seriously. I am ashamed to say that Australia's Minister for Foreign Affairs is making statements which are clearly sending the wrong signals to France, the United States and the international community.

The problem and the urgency are that those signals are not just to the nuclear nations. Those signals are to the non-aligned or non-nuclear bodies which Australia quite proudly brought on board. We may never find out what the deals with nations like Indonesia were. What was the quid pro quo that Australia delivered to Indonesia to bring the non-aligned nations into line with the nuclear states and how is that going to backfire? That is the urgency. If Australia does not take urgent action, we are going to see repercussions from now until heaven knows when.

It is not just a matter of whether these tests take place. It is not even a matter, it seems, of assuming that if these 8 tests take place France will do the right thing. France is suggesting several hundred kilograms of material does not constitute a nuclear test. That is what they are saying. The whole thing is a farce. Australia's compliance or acceptance of the level of France's nuclear testing is a farce and that is why it is urgent the message must go through.

Australia is blind to the consequences. We have continued to sell uranium to countries which either reprocess nuclear material or, in this case, produce nuclear weapons and, in France's case, test or are likely to test within our region. The urgency is that we should no longer be doing that. The urgency is that we should be debating this and not pretending that trade in this material is not somehow adding to the situation. We are either ethical or not ethical in our world trade in nuclear material. If we clearly know that we cannot control the use to which our nuclear material is put in the countries to which we sell it, it is no longer ethical that we export this material. That possibility does not make it more ethical that countries like Namibia would quickly fill the gap. That does not make it ethical. That is the same kind of argument as saying that if we do not sell heroin someone else will.

There is a point in our history where we say that this is urgent and we have to take action. There are some things that are more important than dollars and this is one of them. I definitely support the urgency motion. I support the argument that we need to deal urgently with this matter. I have had no indications whatsoever that either side of the chamber—the major parties—have any idea of the implications of Australia's compliance and Australia's role in acceding to the demands and the requirements of the nuclear nations, but it is time they did. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to speak briefly and hopefully I will not use my full allocation of time. The government opposes the motion seeking suspension of standing orders. It is traditional to canvass some of the issues in speaking to the suspension of standing orders and I wish to make a couple of quick comments.

PARA.TAB: Australia permits the mining and export of uranium only under the most stringent safeguard conditions. The government has taken a view that Australia can contribute to international non-proliferation objectives by ensuring that a significant portion of the world's uranium trade is covered by stringent Australian conditions. Australia's commitment and involvement in international non-proliferation efforts are second to none. In the nuclear field, Australia has been able to project influence in non-proliferation forums because it has been prepared to establish itself as a reliable supplier of uranium, albeit one which attaches the strictest non-proliferation conditions.

Australia decided to permit the mining and export of uranium only after an exhaustive series of public inquiries and national political debate. This was an issue that even Senator Coulter acknowledged in the Senate earlier this week. It is through such influence that Australia has been able to encourage wider acceptance of strict non-proliferation conditions. For example, at the recent Non-Proliferation Treaty Review and Extension Conference we were able, with a group of like-minded countries, to have a requirement accepted which puts in place full scope International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards as an essential condition for new nuclear supply. This was the culmination of a campaign which Australia has successfully prosecuted internationally over a number of years.

In the case of France, Australia's uranium exports are governed by the provisions of the bilateral agreement concerning nuclear transfers between Australia and France. This agreement, like Australia's other nuclear safeguard agreements, contains binding international undertakings which give effect to Australia's stringent safeguard requirements on export of uranium including coverage by International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards.

These arrangements provide assurance that Australian obligated uranium cannot end up in the nuclear weapons program of France, which in any event has its own sources of nuclear material not subject to the stringent conditions required by Australia. Current policy prohibits new contracts for sale of uranium to France until France becomes a party to the comprehensive test ban treaty. This issue has been debated exhaustively within the Australian community for the past 20 years and longer. We have dealt with this issue at times during the past week when at least some aspects of our approach to this issue were discussed. I have indicated that the government is opposed to the suspension of standing orders. We touched on some of the issues why we do not believe the matter needs to be dealt with today as an urgent matter. Before I conclude, I point out the urgency of the requirement to get some government legislation debated and passed. We have been doing precious little of that over the last few weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the absence of the shadow minister, the opposition will not be supporting the motion to suspend standing orders. As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) has pointed out, bilateral safeguards are in place for countries purchasing uranium from Australia. They prohibit the purchasing nation from using Australian uranium to manufacture nuclear weapons. Other conditions such as the agreement that spent reactor fuel originally made from Australian uranium will not be reprocessed as plutonium are in place. We have these bilateral agreements. As the parliamentary secretary has said, we do not believe this is the time nor the place to debate this particular matter today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration I present the report of the committee entitled Protecting the Vulnerable? The Migration Agents Registration Scheme, together with submissions, transcript of evidence and minutes of proceedings.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: When introducing the migration agents registration scheme, the then Minister, the Hon. Gerry Hand, MP, promised that the scheme would be reviewed two years after its commencement. In fulfilment of that commitment, the Joint Standing Committee on Migration has just completed a year-long inquiry into the scheme. Our findings and recommendations are contained in the report which I am now tabling, entitled Protecting the Vulnerable? The Migration Agents Registration Scheme.

PARA.TAB: The report is a comprehensive analysis of the way in which the migration agents registration scheme has impacted on the providers and receivers of immigration advice in this country during the period of its short and uncertain existence. Shortly after the scheme was enacted, its validity was challenged in the High Court. The High Court's decision upholding the validity of the scheme, which was delivered during the course of the inquiry, settled the question of whether the scheme could continue to operate both legally and constitutionally.

The committee's principal task was to determine whether the scheme should continue to operate and, if so, whether any improvements were necessary. The committee, in arriving at the conclusions contained in the report, took account of the evidence it received from all the major stakeholders in the scheme, including migration agents, legal bodies, immigration advice centres, community organisations, government departments, review tribunals, legal aid commissions and members of the public. I take this opportunity to thank all those who contributed to the inquiry by providing useful submissions and evidence at public hearings.

While the scheme has not lived up to all of its expectations, evidence to the inquiry indicated that there is a continuing need for some form of regulation of the migration advice industry to ensure consumer protection. The committee rejected the notion of self-regulation at this stage because of the varied nature of the industry and the lack of a self-regulatory body with broad coverage of the industry.

The committee considered that abolition of the scheme, or its substantial diminution, would send an inappropriate signal to the community about the government's commitment to the establishment of a competent and reputable migration advice industry in which the interests of those most in need of assistance are safeguarded. Indeed, the committee has proposed the continuation of the scheme for a further three years with suggestions to improve its effectiveness. At the same time, it has addressed concerns about the operation of the scheme raised in submissions.

The committee heard many arguments about who should be included and who should be exempted from the requirement to register as a migration agent. Lawyers were among the most vocal opponents of the requirement for lawyers to register. They argued that the legal profession is already subject to its own disciplinary mechanisms and that these are adequate in controlling the conduct of lawyers who provide immigration assistance.

Evidence received from the Immigration Review Tribunal and the Refugee Review Tribunal suggested that, in proceedings before the tribunals, poor standards have been evident among lawyers and non-lawyers alike. In addition, it was evident to the committee that many consumers of immigration advice would have little knowledge of the intricacies of the legal profession's disciplinary mechanisms. As the government's original objective of raising professional standards within the migration advice industry has yet to be achieved, the committee concluded that lawyers should not be exempted from registration at this time.

Another difficult issue was whether persons who provide immigration advice on a non-fee charging basis should be required to register as migration agents. Again, the committee concluded that, in general, the need to protect consumers warranted the inclusion of non-fee charging advisers in the scheme. To assist organisations in the non-fee charging sector which satisfy relevant standards, the committee has recommended a system of organisation based registrations. In addition, the committee has moved to plug the loopholes which have enabled some in the community to avoid the registration requirements. In particular, the committee has recommended that the scheme be expanded to include advice given to sponsors and nominators of migration applicants, as well as advice given to citizenship applicants.

As a principal objective of the scheme is to raise the standard of immigration advice, the committee also has proposed an ongoing education requirement for migration agents when renewing registrations. While some argued for tighter entry standards, the committee felt that it was inappropriate to establish more significant barriers to entry within the industry. The committee preferred to emphasise maintenance of standards through a continuing education points model.The committee has also proposed amendments to the Code of Conduct in order to strengthen consumer protection, including publication of an indicative guide on fees.

The committee has also recommended an expansion of the functions and powers of the Migration Agents Registration Board, which constitutes the operational base of the scheme. We suggest: a more pro-active role for the board in monitoring the activities of migration agents and in publicising its disciplinary actions; jurisdiction over unregistered practice; increased powers to refer the conduct of lawyers who are migration agents to the relevant legal bodies; increased powers to seek information from applicants for registration as migration agents; penalties for obstructing board investigations and adjudications; and an increased range of sanctions which can be applied by the board in disciplining migration agents, including the power to impose fines and order payment of compensation.

Concerns about the administration of the scheme have also been addressed. One such concern related to the role of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs within the scheme. Currently, the secretary to the department, or the secretary's delegate, serves as chairperson of the board, approves straightforward registration applications, and also refers controversial applications to the board for its consideration. This has given rise to the perception that the scheme and the board which administers the scheme are linked too closely to one of the major stakeholders in the scheme.

In addressing this perception, and as a means of increasing public confidence in the scheme, the committee has recommended the appointment of an independent chairperson to the board who would have the additional power to initiate investigations of migration agents. This, we believe, will contribute to the standing of the board as an independent decision making body. It should also assist in improving the timeliness of board decision making processes.

When the scheme was established, a primary objective was that the scheme would be self-funding through the registration and renewal levies which migration agents are required to pay. That objective has not been achieved and, according to advice from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, is not likely to be achieved in the future if the registration levies are kept at existing levels. One of the major reasons is that a significantly higher proportion of agents currently pay a concessional levy than was intended when the parliament agreed to the existing levy structure.

To overcome this problem, the committee has recommended limiting the availability of the concessional levy so that it is only available to those for whom the concession was originally established. This will bring additional revenue for the scheme. At the same time, the committee has proposed a 50 per cent reduction in the general registration and renewal fees to address concerns that the existing levies were perceived as a barrier to entry into the industry.

In total, the committee has made 49 recommendations aimed at improving the operation and effectiveness of the migration agents registration scheme. The committee admits to having some lingering doubts about whether the scheme is capable of achieving its admirable objectives. The short time for which the scheme has been in existence, and the fact that for the majority of this time the very existence of the scheme was being challenged in the High Court, add to and reinforce these doubts. Notwithstanding this, the committee endorses a modified scheme and suggests that it be reviewed again in three years time.

Before concluding, I take this opportunity to thank the deputy chairman, Senator Short, and my fellow committee members for their efforts throughout the inquiry. Their cooperation has resulted in a unanimous and what we believe to be a valuable report. The committee is grateful for the high quality and professional work undertaken by its secretariat, which was headed by the secretary, Mr Andres Lomp, and which at various points of the inquiry included Mr Stephen Boyd, Ms Sophia Konti, Mr Scott McClelland, Mrs Tu Pham and Mr Peter Tighe. Special thanks are also due to the committee's legal adviser, Dr Kathryn Cronin, and to Mr Ian Branston, who was seconded from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to work on the inquiry. Their advice and assistance throughout the inquiry was extremely valuable. The department's cooperation in arranging this secondment is also appreciated greatly.

In commending this report to the parliament, I note that its ultimate objective is to ensure that a professional and competent migration advice industry operates in Australia for the benefit of those who need immigration advice and assistance. By improving the migration agents registration scheme, we can help to protect the vulnerable.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment briefly on this report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration and to support most of the remarks made by the chairman, Senator McKiernan. I thank him for his chairmanship of the committee during this important inquiry. I also join him in thanking all those who assisted the committee in its activities—not least, of course, those who made submissions to the committee. Without those submissions we would not have been able to conduct an inquiry at all.

PARA.TAB: Apart from them, I also join Senator McKiernan in thanking the committee secretary, Andres Lomp, and his secretariat for the high quality and professional work that we have now come to see from them, including, of course, the work of the committee's research officer, Mr Stephen Boyd, and Mrs Tu Pham, who worked on the secretariat as part of the Public Service executive development scheme. It is a very valuable scheme. I hope she gained benefit from it. We certainly benefited from her participation. I also thank the administrative officers who assisted at various times in the inquiry, Ms Sophia Konti and Mr Peter Tighe. As Senator McKiernan said, our thanks once again go to the committee's legal adviser, Dr Kathryn Cronin, and on this occasion also to Mr Ian Branston, seconded from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

I do not want to go over all the points of detail contained in the report or those already mentioned by Senator McKiernan in introducing the report. There are just two or three things that I want to say. I pick up the chairman's comments of a few moments ago that there are lingering doubts as to whether the scheme can ever achieve the admirable objectives that have been set for it. For that reason, the committee recommended that there be a three-year extension of the existing scheme, which is due to expire in September this year.

There is a bill before the parliament to extend the life of the scheme for an additional year. We have recommended an additional three years, because we do not think there has been sufficient time to judge whether the scheme, as a long-term proposition, is what is the most desirable to meet what we all agree is the necessary objective of achieving a competent and efficient migration agents system within which the professionalism and integrity of the participants is of the highest priority. We are all agreed on that objective. The question is how best to get there.

Whether this type of arrangement that is now in legislation in the form of the migration agents registration scheme is the best way of doing it is still an open question. Therefore, the jury is still out on it. To some extent, that is reflected in the committee's title of the report, which is Protecting the vulnerable?. It has a question mark in the official title. The question mark is an important one. What we as a committee are really questioning is whether this scheme protects the vulnerable and achieves the objectives that we all want for it.

In that context, the committee agreed that self-regulation is not a viable option at this time, given the varied nature of the industry. Speaking personally, I hope that, in the course of time, self-regulation may prove to be a viable option. Industries and participants in industries, be they of this type or any other type, have a responsibility to keep their own house in order and to preserve and build the integrity of their industry or profession. In that context, self-regulation is idealistically the best way to go. Whether it can be achieved is another matter. That is something for another day in the light of what happens with our experience of the scheme over the next three years, if the government accepts the recommendation to extend the existing scheme for a further three years.

The scheme has laboured under some difficulty to date. As the committee report points out, and as Senator McKiernan mentioned, for most of its history it has laboured under the shadow of a High Court challenge to its very existence. Only relatively recently has that challenge been decided by a very close margin. A four-three majority in the High Court upheld the validity of the scheme. The fact that it has had that shadow hanging over it during most of its existence to date has had an impact on the scheme. Now that that shadow has been removed, it will give us a better opportunity to see how the scheme can perform.

For those reasons, I strongly urge the government to support the basic recommendation of the committee; namely, to extend the scheme for a period. Let us see whether it protects the vulnerable and provides all those other admirable objectives that have been set for the scheme. Allowing some breathing time to see how it works seems to us to be a commonsense and practical way to go. The fact that the government has foreshadowed in the legislation at least a one-year extension beyond the existing September 1995 deadline is an indication that it is probably thinking in a similar vein to us on that issue. Certainly if the coalition wins the next election we would be wanting to look at the future of the scheme in light of the very important findings and information that has come out in the course of the committee's inquiry. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Public Works, I present the following reports: No. 11 of 1995, Redevelopment works for CSIRO Division of Wildlife and Ecology, Gungahlin, ACT; and No. 12 of 1995, RAAF base Richmond replacement medical centre. I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the reports.

SPEECH.PARA: The subject of the committee's 11th report for 1995 concerns the redevelopment works for the CSIRO Division of Wildlife and Ecology, Gungahlin, ACT. The proposed works will include the replacement of existing temporary and substandard accommodation and the provision of additional facilities to meet expanded functions of the division. The new building complex will incorporate research laboratories and data collection areas, offices, stores, seminar rooms and staff amenities, and a central resource facility for graphics, information technology and library. The estimated cost of the proposal is $7 million at January 1995 prices.

PARA.TAB: The Division of Wildlife and Ecology has occupied the Gungahlin site—a semi-rural site located on the Barton Highway, approximately seven kilometres north of Canberra's central business area—for over 40 years. The 36 buildings, which mainly occupy the eastern part of the site, are of diverse age, merit and condition. Three of the buildings and their surrounds have a heritage listing, including the Gungahlin Homestead, which was constructed in the 1860s.

The need for redevelopment at the Gungahlin site results from a requirement to replace temporary and substandard accommodation and to provide increased facilities to meet expanded functional needs on the site. Overcrowding exists in some laboratories, leading to potentially unsafe working conditions and limitations for research usage. Many of the temporary buildings need to be replaced with permanent facilities more appropriate to the needs of the division, providing long-term flexibility, adaptability and ease of maintenance consistent with master plan principles.

In submissions to the committee, the Australian Heritage Commission and the ACT division of the National Trust of Australia expressed considerable concern regarding the mass and scale of the proposed building A and its form and architectural detail, which were not seen as being sympathetic to the adjoining heritage listed Gungahlin Homestead. The placement of building A within the heritage precinct was also of concern. Given the ad hoc developments that have taken place on the site in the past, the Australian Heritage Commission believes that this proposal provides an excellent opportunity to establish a precedent for a more sympathetic design on the site.

At the public hearing, CSIRO indicated that discussions had been held with both organisations, and also the National Capital Planning Authority, in an attempt to alleviate these concerns. The committee was assured by CSIRO that it will continue to work, during detailed design development, with these organisations to ensure that the design is sympathetic to and respects the prominence that should be afforded to the homestead and the historic nature of the site.

The committee has recommended that the Barton Highway entrance should continue to be the main entry point to the Gungahlin site and that CSIRO should continue discussions with the ACT Department of the Environment, Land and Planning to resolve issues relating to site entry and the impact on CSIRO activities of proposed road works in the vicinity of the Gungahlin site.

Finally, the committee is aware that a possible reorganisation of CSIRO's administrative structure is currently under consideration. However, the committee was assured by CSIRO at the public hearing that any reorganisation of administrative structures will not impact at the divisional level and will not affect the proposal being considered by the committee.

The subject of the committee's 12th report for 1995 is the provision of a replacement medical centre and associated medical facilities at RAAF base Richmond, New South Wales. The proposed works consist of a medical centre complex, an operational health support and training facility, and associated engineering services. The estimated cost of the project, when referred to the committee, was $11.4 million at July 1993 prices.

Major features of the medical centre are that it provides the Australian Defence Force with a unique aviation medicine service, has air transportable medical equipment, and its staff are trained and exercised in deploying and operating anywhere in Australia or overseas as a complete air transportable hospital. The staff, and allocated reservists, receive specialised medical training as well as the normal range of military training to allow them to provide health services in the field under normal operational conditions.

The medical centre currently occupies a conglomerate of interlinked buildings in the centre of the base. The main building is of brick construction dating from the mid-1930s, and houses an operating theatre, administrative areas and several wards. Ancillary buildings are of a timber-framed, asbestos-clad construction with galvanised iron roofs dating from the early 1940s, and are used for wards and ancillary medical functions.

The condition of the buildings can generally be described as being decrepit and incompatible with the performance of contemporary medical procedures. They present a high maintenance commitment, a fire safety problem and, despite the best endeavours of the base medical staff, compliance with statutory requirements for occupational health and safety is questionable. I might add that they are in a condition similar to the recently demolished and replaced services of HMAS Cerberus's naval depot at Frankston.

The committee raised with Defence the question of the long-term future of RAAF Richmond and the impact of the development of the Badgerys Creek airport on flying operations at RAAF Richmond. Defence assured the committee that the RAAF will occupy the base until at least the year 2015. The development of Badgerys Creek will require careful liaison between the RAAF and the Civil Aviation Authority in relation to airspace management. Defence believes that the impact on flying operations from RAAF Richmond will be manageable.

At the public hearing the committee sought advice from Defence regarding what appeared to be a very high usage rate of medical facilities at RAAF Richmond. There is something like 10,000 pharmacy uses per year. It works out roughly that defence force personnel use either the pharmacy or outpatient facility at least once a week, which we thought was a quite high usage rate.

Defence advised that the usage rate resulted from a combination of factors which stemmed from the fact that military activities are essentially significantly different from those of civilian life. Service personnel are required to present early with their conditions so that their fitness for operational service can be maintained. Because of the fundamental requirement that service personnel become physically fit, a great deal of the outpatient usage results from sporting injuries. In fact, the physiotherapy unit was probably the most used. Also, as a significant number of single people live on base in barrack accommodation there is a very high incidence of common colds and upper respiratory tract infections.

The outpatients statistics include immunisations for which there is a high demand at RAAF Richmond as it is the third busiest airport in Australia for international movements. Service in Cambodia, for example, required some 12 immunisations, not all of which could be given together. In addition, air crew require hypnotic medication to allow them to sleep in adverse circumstances.

The issue of the high incidence of sporting injuries at RAAF Richmond is of concern to the committee and it is a trend which the committee has noted at other defence establishments. The committee has decided that it is an issue on which it will be focusing during its forthcoming inquiry into the 1st Field Hospital at Holsworthy, New South Wales. While the committee obviously recognises the need for service personnel to become and remain physically fit, the methods by which they reach that condition may be open to question.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill seeks to amend the Child Care Act 1972, the Childcare Rebate Act 1993 and the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 to facilitate the Government's Budget 1995 commitment to improve the focus of the Children's Services Program. This will be achieved through two initiatives. Firstly, the Government will improve the targeting of financial assistance for families who require child care to enable them to participate in the work force. And secondly, the Government will create a more equitable availability of occasional care for families with one or both parents at home.

These amendments change the eligibility for Childcare Assistance for occasional care in long day child care services to 12 hours per week for all families excepting those using childcare for work-related purposes and other exceptional circumstances.

This Government recognises the important contribution to society and the economy of the unpaid work undertaken by women caring for their children at home. The Government also acknowledges that the skills of women with workforce experience are extremely valuable in an economy dependent on the training and flexibility of the workforce.

These days, many parents will spend some time at home when their children are young and some time in the paid workforce. To meet the needs of parents at home caring for children, the Government has introduced a comprehensive package of Government payments which include Family Payments, Home Child Care Allowance, the new Maternity Allowance and Parenting Allowance.

And under this Government's policies, work-related child care is an economic issue and is an integral part of the Government's approach to building a highly skilled and adaptable work force. The expansion of child care over the past decade has been a major achievement of the Government and has made the return to the work force a real option for many parents, particularly women.

Work-related child care is required by parents who are working, studying, training or looking for work. The Government has a commitment to meet the anticipated demand for work-related care by the year 2001 and is well on the way to meeting the target of 354,000 work-related places by 2001, with an interim target of 300,000 places by 1996-97.
Federal expenditure on child care has grown from $65 million in 1982-83 to an estimated $1.1 billion in 1995-96.2

But child care must be affordable for families. The Childcare Cash Rebate was introduced to assist families meet child care expenses while working, looking for work, studying or training. Over 200,000 families have claimed the Childcare Cash Rebate.

The Government also assists families with the cost of child care through Commonwealth Childcare Assistance. Childcare Assistance is available to families using approved long day care services. About 76 per cent of families using these services receive some assistance with their child care fees, with over 40 per cent receiving full Childcare Assistance.
As at December 1994, an estimated 222,000 low and middle income families using long day care services received Childcare Assistance.
However, at present, 25 per cent of Childcare Assistance is paid to families with one or both parents not in the work force.

This proportion is increasing by about 2 per cent each year due to the increasing use of substantial periods of occasional care in the long day care sector by families with a parent outside the work force. Occasional care makes up about 20 per cent of all hours of care in the long day care sector.

Recent surveys indicate that many working families cannot gain access to the care they need. The surveys also show that some families use substantial amounts of occasional care, while many others have no access to child care at all.

The Government's clearer targeting of Childcare Assistance will ensure that families who need child care to enable work force participation get priority to places. The amendments contained in this bill will assist by revising Childcare Assistance arrangements consistent with the work-related focus of the Program.
These measures will provide access to care for an estimated additional 31,000 families.

In the 1995 Budget, the Government also announced that the assessment of a family's eligibility for Childcare Assistance and Family Payments will be streamlined. This will be achieved by having the Department of Social Security assess eligibility for both payments at the same time each year using a common definition of income from October 1995. This initiative is designed to make the assessment process easier for families by enabling families to provide information applicable to both schemes on the same application form at the same time.
As part of the Government's aim to increase the availability of care for parents who need child care to participate in the work force, the Department of Social Security and the Health 3

Insurance Commission will verify the work-related status of any family wishing to receive priority of access to a child care place for work-related reasons. Amendments are required to enable the Health Insurance Commission to assist families, at their request, with evidence of their work-related status, for the purposes of gaining priority of access to Commonwealth funded long day child care services.
Amendments to the Child Care Act 1972, the Childcare Rebate Act 1993 and the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 are included in this bill which will enable:
the Department of Social Security to collect information and assess a family's entitlement for Childcare Assistance on the basis of work status; and

the Health Insurance Commission to verify the work-related status of those parents who are not currently claiming or are not eligible for the Childcare Cash Rebate to assist them in gaining priority of access to a Commonwealth funded long day child care service.
Moving to the detail of the amendments required to the individual acts:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments to the Child Care Act 1972

SPEECH.PARA: Current Priority of Access Guidelines require long day child care services to give priority of access for vacant places to parents who need child care for work-related reasons. However the implementation

of this arrangement is highly variable and there is a significant number of child care places being used by families who do not require the care to enable them to participate in the work force. As a result, in some areas, families who need care for work-related reasons are unable to access child care. In addition, many services and industry organisations have agreed that Government Departments should introduce a way of verifying the work-related status of parents.

In order to address these concerns, these amendments include provisions to assess a family's entitlement to Childcare Assistance, not only on the basis of economic need, but also on the basis of the work-related status of the family or other special circumstances such as children at risk of abuse or neglect or emergency situations.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments to the Childcare Rebate Act 1993

SPEECH.PARA: This bill also includes amendments to the Childcare Rebate Act 1993. These amendments will enable the Minister to make guidelines for the purpose of administering sections 29-31 of the act which define work-related commitments. These guidelines will 4

clearly set out the requirements of families who are verifying work, study or training commitments and will make the process of verification of work-related status more transparent. Decisions made under these guidelines will be reviewable.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments to the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973

SPEECH.PARA: This bill also contains amendments to the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 which will give the Health Insurance Commission the power to verify the work-related status of families at their request.

As part of the Government's initiative to better target child care places to families who require child care to enable them to participate in the work force, the Health Insurance Commission will verify the work-related status of any families who request it.

Many families will be able to verify their work-related status by producing a recent Childcare Cash Rebate receipt as evidence that they receive the Childcare Cash Rebate and therefore have already verified their work-related status.
The Health Insurance Commission already has the power to verify a family's work-related status as part of the Childcare Cash Rebate scheme under the Childcare Rebate Act 1993.

However, there are a small number of families who are not eligible for, or currently claiming, the Childcare Cash Rebate and who may choose to verify their work-related status with the Health Insurance Commission, independent of the Childcare Cash Rebate Program scheme. These amendments will allow these families to gain priority of access to Commonwealth funded long day child care services.
In order to confer on the Commission the function of verifying the work-related status of this group of families, it is necessary to amend the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Changes to Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 and the Childcare Rebate Act 1993.

SPEECH.PARA: From time to time there may be a need for the Health Insurance Commission to clarify or confirm information about a family's composition or their work-related status with a Department of the Commonwealth or a Commonwealth funded long day child care service.

This may occur if the information contained in a family's work-verification document from the Health Insurance Commission is not sufficient to allow the service director, who is assessing priority of access to a child care place, or the Department of Social Security, which assesses eligibility for Childcare 5

Assistance, to properly identify the family concerned. Examples of circumstances where this may be necessary include where a family changes their address, or there is a change of partner or surname for a member of the family or where a family misplaces their work-verification document.

In these circumstances, in order to obviate the need for families to seek further documentary confirmation from the Health Insurance Commission, amendments in this bill to both the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 and the Childcare Rebate Act 1993 will allow the Health Insurance Commission to verify information about a family's composition and work-related status directly with either the Department of Social Security or a Commonwealth funded long day child care service.
The Health Insurance Commission will only be able to provide this information with the consent of the parent concerned.

The Health Insurance Commission will set out administrative procedures which must be followed before any information about a family will be verified directly with the Department of Social Security or a child care service. These administrative procedures will conform with the requirements of the Privacy Commissioner and will be authorised by the Minister for Family Services, to ensure that the privacy of personal family information is protected in accordance with the principles set down in the Privacy Act.
This Government's support for choice in child care is clear and unambiguous.
The Government supports the choices parents make, either caring for their own children or in placing their children in the care of others.
The Government has introduced a comprehensive range of payments which provide an independent income for parents who choose to care for their children at home.
The Government has provided, and will continue to provide, funding for new child care places, innovative child care programs and services for children and families with special needs.
Child care funding will continue to grow from an estimated $894 million in 1994-95 to $1.1 billion in 1995-96, and is expected to reach $1.5 billion in 1998-99.

Child care provides parents with options to balance their work and family responsibilities. The amendments sought in this bill will help to ensure that the Children's Services Program is better targeted to families with parents in the work force and that available places used by families with a parent outside the work force are spread more equitably. Through this initiative, 31,000 more families will have access to child care in the long day care sector.
These amendments will ensure that the significant growth planned for the Children's Services Program is properly directed and sustainable.
I commend this bill to the Senate.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.
