SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum and move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill serves to make various portfolio amendments to social security and associated legislation. Taken together, the amendments amount to a significant further step in moulding a responsive and accountable social security system for the Australian community.

The bill introduces a series of initiatives that recognise the importance of further education and training in equipping people currently in the social security system for their future roles in the workforce.

Recipients of job search or newstart allowance may currently continue to be paid that allowance for up to three weeks if they start a course that lasts for longer than six months. This payment is made while their entitlement to AUSTUDY or ABSTUDY is being assessed. The scheme is to be made simpler for all concerned by continuing the payment for a standard three weeks, rather than up to three weeks. The scheme is also to be extended to certain people who start courses that last for less than six months and who, as a result, lose qualification for their allowance. Currently, a person in this situation would lose the allowance if the course is one that is not approved for the purposes of the activity test or an activity agreement. Furthermore, special beneficiaries will now also be able to take advantage of these improved rules.

The bill also makes an education entry payment available to recipients of job search, newstart or youth training allowance who start a full-time course that lasts for less than six months. This will apply as long as the course is one that they were required to start under the activity test or an activity agreement. Therefore, these people will join the longer term unemployed customers who already have access to this important payment that can make all the difference with the unavoidable up-front costs involved in starting an educational course.

An inconsistency is also being eliminated in the treatment of AUSTUDY and ABSTUDY for the purposes of whether social security allowance or benefit recipients qualify for bereavement payments on the death of their partners. In the past, bereavement payments have been paid only if the person was a long-term social security recipient, that is, they have been receiving a relevant social security payment for at least 52 weeks. Periods on AUSTUDY and ABSTUDY will now count towards that period. This will reduce any disadvantage to people who undertake study during an extended period on social security payments compared to those who do not.

This bill will exclude as income under the act loans made to AUSTUDY and ABSTUDY recipients under the Student Financial Supplement Scheme. The amendment ensures that a person in this situation will not be excluded from qualification for a Health Care Card on the basis of Student Financial Supplement Scheme loan payments being included in their income.

Two amendments are also being made to the waiting and deferment period provisions for job search, newstart and sickness allowance. There is a current rule that reduces the education leavers waiting period for a person who does some full-time study during the waiting period and reclaims allowance within four weeks of starting the course. To improve the incentives for people to attempt a return to education, this concession will now apply if the person reclaims allowance within 12 months of starting the course.

It is also being clarified that the part of the waiting or deferment period that may be waived if a person undertakes approved vocational training during the period is only that part of the waiting or deferment period that overlaps with the vocational training. In other words, it is not the whole waiting or deferment period.
The bill also contains a number of useful enhancements to the social security disability programs.

Mobility allowance is generally available to people with disabilities who are engaged in gainful employment, vocational training, voluntary work or job search activities, to help them with their special transport costs. Period of grace payments of six weeks' worth of mobility allowance are paid to people who cease some of these qualifying activities. This bill provides that all mobility allowance recipients will generally receive these period of grace payments when they stop any kind of qualifying activity.

A further amendment relates to telephone allowance. Telephone allowance will continue to be paid to people who lose their entitlement to disability wage supplement when they return to work, as long as they continue to qualify for fringe benefits. Also, it is being clarified that, to be entitled to an employment entry payment, disability wage supplement recipients must claim the payment within a reasonable time of returning to work in the supported wage system. The time limit will be 28 days. These amendments bring disability wage supplement recipients into line with disability support pensioners whose payments are similar in nature.

The bill also modifies the meaning of the term "continuing inability to work" which is one of the qualification criteria for disability support pension and disability wage supplement. In response to the unanticipated outcome in the AAT case of Loknar, the amendment puts beyond doubt that the necessary assessment must be whether the person is fit for any work, whether skilled or unskilled, that he or she could do without needing preparatory training. Alternatively, if such training were necessary, it would have to be likely to equip the person to do the job within two years.

In a further amendment affecting disability support pension and disability wage supplement, the qualification provisions will address a trend emanating from several recent SSAT and AAT decisions. The amendment will make sure that the person's continuing inability to work is directly caused by an impairment of 20 per cent or more under the act's Impairment Tables. Factors that are consequences of the impairment, such as attitude and lack of motivation to work, may not be taken into account.

The Government has assessed the legal impact of the assets test in the Social Security Act on successful native title claims. In general, a person's native title right or interest would be regarded as akin to a life interest because of the restrictions on saleability of native title land. All life interests, unless created by the person or their partner, are exempt under the assets test. Government policy on this issue is clear; the assets test should not apply. The Government wishes to make this policy explicit and this bill does that by exempting as assets under the act any native title rights or interests of a person, or of any community or group of which the person is a member.

The compensation recovery provisions of the act protect the social security system from "double dippers", that is, those who might receive social security payments, as well as compensation, for the same period. Several measures contained in this bill build on this comprehensive package of provisions. First, the provisions will clearly apply to superseded payment types. In other words, they will apply (as was always intended) to the forerunners of the payment types that are already specified in the current provisions.

Secondly, a trend in compensation settlements highlighted by the AAT case of Kilinc needs to be overcome. This trend has meant that the compensation recovery provisions have been avoided by splitting compensation settlements into two or more payments, only one of which (usually relatively small) is expressed to represent lost earnings or earning capacity and is therefore caught by the provisions.

Thirdly, the provisions will apply to claimants as well as recipients of certain social security payments. This will free claimants as well as the Department of the need to go through a time consuming and often costly qualification assessment exercise when the compensation recovery provisions might well already preclude payment.
Lastly, compensation payments will be clearly included in income for the purposes of the Disadvantaged Persons Health Scheme.

The relaxed residence requirements for refugees were introduced last year. These basically allowed the payment of certain pensions to refugees without their needing to satisfy the usual qualifying residence requirements. This bill refines certain aspects of that legislation. The amendments make sure that a person continues to be regarded as a refugee for social security purposes, and therefore retains the residence concession, even if they cease to be the current holder of a refugee-type visa because of certain incidental effects of the immigration visa system.

The loan fringe benefit provisions apply under the family payment income test and the parental means test for young allowance recipients. How this operates is that, if an employee receives a loan from an employer, the employee has a loan fringe benefit. The value of the loan fringe benefit is calculated having regard to a notional interest rate that should reflect market rates. However, it is in fact well below those rates at present. This amendment both raises the rate to a reasonable market rate and sets in place an automatic mechanism for its adjustment each year. The rate will be the lowest available rate from any one of four major banks specified by the Minister.

Provisions also being amended are those that govern the date of effect of determinations to cancel, suspend, increase or decrease a person's job search, newstart or partner allowance. The amendments provide that where the information that results in the determination to vary, cancel or suspend the allowance is provided on a recipient statement notice, the determination will take effect on the day of the event or change. A recipient statement notice is the form that persons receiving these payments are required to submit to the Department regularly declaring their circumstances.

Lastly, the bill makes minor technical and consequential amendments, including to provisions in the areas of the qualifying age for the seniors health card, the income test and related matters, superannuation pensions, debt recovery, data-matching.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT MARKET DEVELOPMENT GRANTS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1994 [1995]

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 20 June, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Export Market Development Grant Amendment Bill No. 2 is to broadly extend this very successful scheme for another five years. We have had a number of speakers in support of the bill. Broadly, there is consensus in this chamber that such an extension is warranted—nay, necessary. It has been suggested that there be amendments to the bill in its present form.

PARA.TAB: Can I say, before turning to the amendments, that what we are building in Australia is an export culture. That is to say that Australian business thinks internationally, thinks about market opportunity overseas and works to claim Australian presence in those overseas markets and to extend them. What we have seen over the last several years, and indeed borne out in the OECD report figures that came out last night, is a growth of exporting from Australia. We are now part of a global economy. We are a successful exporting nation. As I have said in this chamber many times, the export of manufactured goods in particular—a poor performer when measured in the past against the exports of mineral commodities and agricultural products—has boomed over recent years and now, in total value, manufactured exports outweigh the total value of agricultural exports from Australia. In short, we are becoming a more sophisticated economy and a more sophisticated exporting nation.

The export market development grants are aimed at helping businesses establish themselves in the export market. The grants are provided across-the-board. They are in grant form, which is to say that, if a business qualifies under the criteria, it gets the grant. That means that the configuration of the grants are not capped, that they are open ended and that as many businesses which apply and meet the criteria succeed. We are in the active business of encouraging many more Australian companies to export. Therefore, taxpayers' money diverted to export market development grants in order to build an export economy has been working dramatically well for us. This bill is appropriate in extending that provision for another five years and in putting around it certain conditions which safeguard the best use of taxpayers' money when we have a scheme based on grants which is open ended like this.

The amendments that have been proposed are related in the main to changes to the conditions of export market development grants. When we come to the committee stage, I will rely on the fact essentially that the conditions that we have imposed are conditions that have been, if you like, refereed externally. Professor Helen Hughes has done a study which recommends that the conditions be applied in the manner in which we have applied them.

But, importantly, given that this is an open-ended grant scheme, conditions of this type are necessary to safeguard proper use of taxpayers' funds. As a consequence, we will be rejecting the amendments proposed by the opposition and by the Australian Democrats, and rejecting them with respect. We do appreciate what moves their spirit in bringing these amendments forward to make this a more widely accessible scheme, but our broad view—given the reports we have in front of us—is that that enthusiasm to broaden the scheme transgresses against prudent management of the scheme and proper safeguarding of taxpayers' interests. So, for those reasons, we will be essentially rejecting these amendments.

However, these amendments may be carried because of the joint support for them by the Australian Democrats and the coalition. I do not propose that we will make a spectacle of this. In other words, we will not divide on each of these amendments; I will take the vote on the voices. Doing it this way ought to speed the proceedings, but it should not be interpreted in any way as a less forceful advocacy of the government's position than if we took the issue to a division. But, in the prudent expedition of this bill, it is an appropriate measure for us to take. Nonetheless, I want to record that we feel strongly about our position. That may well mean that the vote is carried against the government's wishes. The bill will then return to the House of Representatives. It is for the house to decide what it does, but I imagine it will support the bill and the bill will come back here for further consideration in the Senate.

In addition to that there is a government amendment, which of course we support. We ask the house to join us in supporting it. The Minister for Trade, Senator McMullan, made a statement to the parliament on Monday of this week pointing to an administrative oversight in the tabling of a disallowance instrument relating to export market development grants. This change is to accommodate that oversight. It is in the best interests of all of us who are committed to this scheme to rectify that administrative flaw that has arisen. I seek support for that.

I commend all the speakers in this debate. It is true that there is a wide consensus that we should build our export strength and that this scheme plays a fundamental role in that—and everyone has bent their minds to indeed encouraging that in a constructive way. So I thank all senators for their contribution. However, as I said, the amendments are not acceptable. I commend this bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is suggested that we go through the bill clause by clause and I think the program for doing that has been circulated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendments to be moved to this bill.

PARA.TAB: Clause 1 agreed to.
Clause 2.
Amendments (by Senator Cook)—by leave—proposed:

(2)Clause 2, page 2, at end of clause, add the following subclause:

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding of these amendments is that they relate to the administrative oversight referred to by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) in his second reading speech. I would like to direct a number of questions to the minister in respect to those amendments. Firstly, was the government aware that the guidelines were invalid?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government became aware of this administrative oversight as recently as last week. What triggered a re-examination by the officers of Austrade was the publicity that had been given to the administrative oversight in my own department, the Department of Industry, Science and Technology, on research and development grants and, as a consequence and with proper diligence, Austrade revisited these guidelines because at one time the host department for Austrade was DITAC as it then was, not DIST as it now is, but, nonetheless, in linear descent the same department, my own department. I understand from the statement by the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) that this occurred in 1991. As a consequence, triggered by the unearthing of this oversight on R&D, Austrade identified this oversight and is now moving speedily to rectify it.
—Minister, how many applicants for export market development grants were rejected under the invalid guidelines?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that Austrade advice to the minister has been that, during the time in which there were no valid guidelines, only 10 applicants were denied approved joint venture consortium status and nine applicants were denied approved trading house status. So that is in two categories.

PARA.TAB: Austrade also advises me that these applicants were not disadvantaged, as their applications would not have been successful under the properly constituted guidelines. However, in order to put the issue beyond question, we are seeking appropriate amendments to the act. Austrade has advised the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan), and through him me, that, since it took over operation or carriage of the EMDG legislative process in late 1991, measures have been put in place to ensure that such an oversight does not recur. All guidelines in the form of disallowable instruments since then have been tabled, and Austrade has met its obligations to the parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have any of those applicants who were denied grants appealed? Does this amendment to the bill mean that any avenues that those people may have to appeal will be destroyed if this legislation were not in place?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will get a better definition on the question, if I may. I am advised that the advice given to the minister by the Attorney-General is that the invalidity of the guidelines for the relevant time does not entitle those claimants to any claim because of the invalidity. That is an important point. Is that the issue that you are concerned about? Paraphrasing it in my terms, are you asking me whether, despite all that, there are any claims on foot, or would people be disadvantaged?
—I am asking whether this legislation denies the possibility of an appeal by those people who were denied grants under guidelines that were invalid.

—The advice I have is that the answer to your question is no. This legislation validates the guidelines and the decisions that were made at the time. Bear in mind that, had these guidelines been properly tabled, they would have operated. Decisions were made according to those guidelines. We are simply reinstating those guidelines properly. So the answer to your question is no.

—The minister just said in response that the guidelines validate decisions made at the time whether to approve or disapprove export development market grants. The point is that this legislation would seem to mean that those people who were denied grants would now be denied the opportunity to appeal against those denials.

—I would like to drive the point home. The question is whether applicants who were denied in their applications have retained the right to appeal on the substance of their application quite irrespective of any validation of the guidelines. If they had a right to appeal against the decision not to grant them the application that they made, is that right still in existence or has it been in any way affected by the amendments the government is proposing?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —To put it as simply as I possibly can, what I am advised is this: everyone believed the guidelines were valid and properly constituted, and they acted accordingly. The fact they had not been tabled was not taken or understood to have invalidated them. They were gazetted, they were thought to be law and people behaved according to them. Where applicants were rejected under the guidelines—the numbers for which I have given—they had an opportunity at that relevant time to take an appeal, presumably if they disagreed with a ruling against them.

PARA.TAB: My advice is that some exercised that right, in which case one imagines those cases were heard and resolved. All of them are now out of time legally to appeal. In other words, if they exercised their right at the time, they had an appeal which then proceeded. But all of them as a block are now out of legal time were they disagreeing with the decision against them. From that perspective, one assumes that no-one's rights have been impeded.

However, Austrade has further advised me that, because an administrative error is occurring here, it will be open to any of these businesses approaching it for reconsideration from this time on in order to properly be responsible to what might be the considered rights of individuals. In answer to your question, even now they are out of legal time.

TALK.START.PARA: Two questions arise out of the minister's answer. First, I was not aware that there was a limitation on the capacity to make an appeal against a substantive decision not to grant an application. Perhaps the minister could direct me to the provisions which impose the time limitation. Secondly, I welcome the minister's undertaking. I make quite certain that it is a binding undertaking on the part of the government that, if any of the 10 applicants which have been refused now wish to make an application on substantive grounds of this agreement with a decision, their appeals will be accepted and dealt with.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I need to correct the advice I have just given Senator Spindler. My most recent advice of a few seconds ago is that two of the applicants who were ruled out previously are within time. Whether those two will be making an appeal is not known. This is the most recent advice that I have just received. Perhaps I should just answer that part of the question and allow other honourable senators to raise their questions in further explanation.

—Minister, in your earlier response you indicated that you had advice from the Attorney-General's Department on this matter. Would the minister table the legal advice he received to confirm that the government was not exposed to action by companies that incur damages or losses through adverse decisions made under the invalid guidelines?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is advice to the Minister for Trade from the Attorney-General. I would need to approach the minister on that subject as I understand it is privileged advice. While I tabled my legal advice, as Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, in dealing with the research and development glitch, that is not necessarily a precedent for all other ministers in these circumstances to table theirs. I say that to protect the interests of the Minister for Trade. I will refer your question to him and see what his answer is.

—I ask the minister to clarify the position he has made today. Am I correct in understanding that the government is saying that people are time-barred from pursuing certain claims under the provisions of an invalidly made delegated instrument?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you have done us a service, Senator O'Chee, in tying down this matter. I will present to you the advice that I have and I will ask the advisers to indicate whether that advice is properly articulated by me.

PARA.TAB: In simple terms, everyone thought this was the binding law and acted accordingly. People who got adverse decisions and wanted to exercise their appeal rights did so. Two of those are still broadly within time. Your question is similar in character to that of Senator Spindler—whether there is a time limitation on such appeals. I refer to section 40A of the Export Market Development Grants Act, entitled `Review of decisions of the Commission'. Subsection 40A(2) reads:

SPEECH.PARA: A person affected by a decision of the Commission and dissatisfied with the decision may, by notice in writing given to the Commission within a period of 30 days after the date on which the decision first comes to the notice of the person, or within such further period as the Commission allows, request the Commission to reconsider the decision.

When I was referring to being out of time, I was referring to subsection 40A(2) and that provision of a 30-day limitation. In this case, `the Commission' means the Australian Trade Commission, which is Austrade for short.

PARA.TAB: The legal matter on foot over research and development is a matter for an Administrative Appeals Tribunal appeal. My answers are related to decisions of Austrade. On the secondary question of Senator Spindler as to what happens now, can they come back on substantive matters? The answer, in view of all this, is that, yes, they can. What might be the rights, vis a vis appealing a commission decision to the AAT, is another matter. I have a nod from the advisers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a further question on section 40A(2) as quoted by the minister. It refers to a 30-day period, which is the statutory period, or such further period as could be specified by way of delegated instrument. Has that further period been a relevant period in relation to any of these claims? That is also quite crucial to the question.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is, no.

—The minister said that these applicants who have been refused will be able to appeal in the current circumstances. But that seems to be contrary to section 40A(2). What action is the government prepared to take to ensure that the minister's undertaking can be implemented? In other words, will the government issue a delegated instrument, in the words of the provisions, to enable it to bring that substantive appeal, even though the people are out of time under 40A(2)?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The advice I have, as I understand it—and to put this question in context—is that this is how the law was thought to be and this is how this amendment, if carried, would make the law to be. People acting as they thought the law was—and, hopefully, will now be confirmed to be—acted consistently all the way through on that belief. One imagines that if you were knocked out under the previous situation, if there is consistency of treatment, you ought to be knocked out in the future. No-one is here wanting to change the intention of what was done, only to validate the legal requirement.

PARA.TAB: However, the concern is—I take it as being embedded in your question to me—that people were knocked out but were they validly knocked out; and have they now got a right to come back? As I recall the reading of 40A(2), in the first instance the commission has a 30-day limit on appeals but, in the second instance, the commission has the right to extend the appeal time. What Austrade is saying is, `If you feel badly done by under those guidelines, if you thought we had inappropriately interpreted the guidelines or you have some substantial matters to put, come back and see us and we will sort it out.' That, effectively, is the signal being flagged by Austrade. I do not see how, reasonably, it could do anything else.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that an undertaking by the minister on behalf of the government?
—Yes, it is.

—I take the opportunity to outline to the minister another concern I have which I think has been met by his undertaking, but let me explain it first so that he can see the crux of the matter. It is this. Under the provisions of the Acts Interpretation Act, where a delegated instrument is invalidly made or, as in this case, has not been tabled, what happens is that the instrument is valid from the day of making until it becomes invalid by virtue of an omission. The problem then is that thereafter it is invalid.

PARA.TAB: The difficulty that arises is this. The government cannot rely on a provision of an invalid regulation after that date to the detriment of somebody who seeks to make a claim. I think what the legislative amendment does—and there has been some broad agreement on the thrust of it—is effectively take away certain rights because after the date on which the delegated instrument became invalid the government really had no right to turn people down, other than existing statutory rights. So the legislation reinstates what people thought the law was. In reality, what they thought the law was, after the invalidity of that delegated instrument, was not correct. The law was, in fact, a nullity. So it reinstates it.

I feel assured now by your undertaking, minister, that the normal processes will apply as per the regulation, but without that undertaking you will recognise my concern that the legislative act on which we are embarking at the moment has the effect of denying people rights which existed because of the invalidity of the delegated instrument.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I took that rather learned intervention from Senator O'Chee to be an explanation of his view. I should indicate for the record that the legal advice that the department has is different. I think this then comes up against the `so what' test. There are different views, but none of us need to go to the contest of which is the right view at the moment if the principle is that the legislative procedure being enacted here is the prudent and appropriate procedure.

PARA.TAB: I accept your explanation as an entirely valid one, Senator O'Chee. I do not contest it. All I do is indicate for the record that I am uninformed as to the legal rights here and the department has a different legal view, as informed to it by the Attorney.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I then raise a further concern? We agree on the broad thrust of the legislative amendment. My concern is this. The undertaking which has been given appears to address the time factor which may arise. The problem then is that there may be certain other administrative procedures outside Austrade to seek review of matters. My concern is that that undertaking may not be sufficient to ensure that people get full access to their rights of administrative review of any decision which goes against them by Austrade.

PARA.TAB: You understand what I mean, minister? An undertaking that the government gives on behalf of Austrade will obviously be binding on Austrade, but if Austrade rejects an appeal and a person seeks some other means of reviewing that decision, the mere undertaking that the government has given would appear not to bind a review body. I ask the minister to turn his mind to that concern and be kind enough to provide the government's view of how we can address those people's rights.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding is that the appeal from an initial decision goes to the commission, which is Austrade itself, and the undertakings I have given would be understood to be undertakings that the commission itself, on appeal, if there were one, would be obliged to take as well; that is, not to rule out an appeal on the basis that you are out of time because you should have made it several years ago, but that there is a newly invigorated process by virtue of this and they should take it within that time span, within the 30 days from this new application, if there is one, and deal with that appeal as if it were a new application.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is fairly obvious from the comments made by Senator Spindler, Senator O'Chee and me that we have some concerns about the effect that this would have. I have just circulated an amendment that may cover the concerns. I will not go over old ground again, in the interests of time. The amendment which I have circulated reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Government amendment No. 3, after proposed section 5 insert the following section:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Saving of rights of action for adverse decisions or acts etc

PARA.TAB: "5A.(1) In spite of anything in section 5, the validations provided for by section 5 do not affect any rights of action of a person in relation to:
(a)a decision of the Australian Trade Commission; or
(b)an act or thing done by any person or body;

SPEECH.PARA: that was adverse to the person in relation to whom the decision was made or the act or thing was done and such rights of action may be pursued as if this Act had never been enacted.

PARA.TAB: "(2) In this section:
(a)a reference to a decision of the Australian Trade Commission includes a reference to a purported decision of the Commission;
(b)a reference to an act or thing done by any person or body includes a reference to an act or thing purportedly done by such person or body.".

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to me that Senator Parer's amendment confirms what the minister has been telling the committee. I am therefore disposed to support it. I would suggest that the minister gives it serious consideration, because it simply confirms the undertaking he has made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —On the face of it, so it does seem. I have just received this copy. If Senator Parer does not mind, I will submit it to the scrutiny of my advisers and give him a more educated answer in a moment.

PARA.TAB: "(2) In this section:
(a)a reference to a decision of the Australian Trade Commission includes a reference to a purported decision of the Commission;
(b)a reference to an act or thing done by any person or body includes a reference to an act or thing purportedly done by such person or body.".

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —An on-the-spot reading of this amendment appears to us to confirm what we have been saying. In that case, we will not resist it; we will accept it. My only qualification—in enunciating this qualification I do not in any way suggest bad faith or duplicity here; the proceeding is quite open, honest and direct—is that we have not had more than a few minutes perusal of this. If it does not reflect the position I put down in some way, our position would be different. Perhaps we would then need to talk about it. On the face of it, it appears to meet that. In that spirit, we accept the amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment (Senator Parer's) agreed to.
Amendment (Senator Cook's), as amended, agreed to.
Schedule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Schedule, page 3, after item 9, insert the following item:
"9A. Section 11D:

PARA.TAB: Add at the end:

SPEECH.PARA: `(4) In this section "samples" includes the provision of eligible tourism services or designated tourism services to a person whose primary or principal purpose in accepting the services is to examine, evaluate and report on them in the course of a business, trade or profession in a way that is likely to influence, create or increase demand for them.'.".

This initial amendment deals with samples. Samples are eligible from the point of view of calculating costs of exports in respect of every other export industry. This means that, where people wish to export products made in Australia, they are taken overseas and given as samples to prospective buyers. That is fair and legitimate.

PARA.TAB: With regard to tourism, that is impossible. It is required that tourism operators have no option but to bring people such as Japanese wholesalers, tourism journalists and any other industry representatives to Australia to see what the tourism services are and what can be offered to potential tourists to Australia from throughout the world. For example, one of the popular things in my state of Far North Queensland—it is a popular and niche market—is the market of ecotourism. One group of people that has a great interest in it comes from Europe. I believe that the vast majority of people who visit Far North Queensland for ecotourism purposes come from Germany. This means that the wholesalers—the people marketing the product—must come and look.

That is not permissible under the existing act in the calculation of the costs, in getting to the $30,000 expenditure for export market development grants. So it really is bringing into line the great tourism industry—an industry that both Senator Cook and Senator McMullan have praised a number of times because of its growth. There is no option. You cannot take the product to the overseas buyer; you must bring the overseas buyer to the product—hence the reason for moving this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated in my reply in the second reading debate, the government does not accept this amendment. There are several grounds for our non-acceptance. The first and most overarching one is that the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 [1995] itself does, for the first time, encompass tourism within the EMDG scheme.
—No, no, not right—single tourism operator.

—Single amenities, right. Nonetheless, it is a significant change for the tourist industry. If we turn to the particular amendment on samples, we will see that there is a cost problem here. This would blow out the expected expenditure on what is an open-ended scheme, bear in mind, by some $5 million to $10 million per annum, in our estimate.

PARA.TAB: It is also true that this scheme provides a situation where no industry sector, irrespective of what it is, is allowed to claim free samples given away in Australia. This would, in fact, distort the scheme, were we to make an exception to this particular industry. To allow this amendment would be to give preferential treatment to the tourism industry over other industry sectors. That may sound to be a rather direct judgment but, nonetheless, it is an appropriate one when you consider it against some other balancing facts too. For example, the Australian Tourist Commission already funds these types of promotional visits—which are felt to be in the interest of the national tourism industries—and that is an appropriate way.

We are not saying that no other circumstances apply; we are saying that this scheme is designed to establish new markets. It needs to be seen alongside the array of other schemes that apply in particular industry sectors. The role of the Australian Tourist Commission—its success in building a popular tourist destination image for Australia in foreign markets—has been outstanding. Under its funding, it does provide promotional visits of the sort that would be, if you like, defined as free samples in Australia under the opposition's amendment.

Finally, the government has serious concerns about the accountability of free samples for this industry sector. How do you define it? What is one? What is just a junket? We are talking about expending public moneys under a particular scheme for people to visit and have a so-called free sample of the Australian tourist industry. Defining and operating that, if we were to agree to it, would be a terribly difficult task in itself. So, for that reason as well, we oppose the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting the amendment moved by Senator Parer. The minister's point that an avenue of funding is already available through the Tourist Commission means that, if that happens, the tourist operators would not be able to claim the cost of such trips as expenditure. This provides a second avenue for tourist operators to provide the opportunity for overseas agents to assess the tourism destination, namely, Australia, and what it has to offer to overseas tourists. As such, it is an essential promotional strategy.

—As I mentioned in the seconding reading debate, tourism is probably one of the most competitive industries in the world—and I do not think the minister would disagree with that. Every country in the world would like to maximise the number of tourists which come to visit, and also to maximise their stay when they are there. It is also an industry which has an awful lot of potential benefits to Australia, in that those people who come leave foreign exchange in this country. They also do it in a way that supports the regions in which they spend the money. It is a very effective way of keeping money within regions. It is probably a more effective way of redistributing income than is already done in some of the government's schemes.

PARA.TAB: The minister raised a point about the ATC, and quite rightly. There is a program, called the ATE, under which, for the past two years, people have come to Darling Harbour in Sydney to promote their products. The ATC certainly encourages people, mainly journalists, as well as overseas buyers, to come along. Journalists are important to the industry because it is through them that its products are promoted. However, irrespective of the ATC, the people who spend the most on promoting tourism in this country are those in the private sector. In fact, of the total budget of the ATC, about 30 per cent is provided by the private sector. You could argue that it is paying for that aspect of the ATC's operation.

In my experience, by far the biggest promoter is the industry itself. It is all very well to have a particular facility—be it ecotourism, the vineyards of the Yarra Valley in Victoria, or the Sydney Opera House—but it is up to those people to go overseas and do their own promotion, whether as individuals or as representatives of a region. With a new market, in particular, you cannot send the product overseas to be sampled; you must bring the prospective buyers or promoters to the product. I would just like to reinforce that as the reason we have moved this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe the amendment should be passed for the simple reason that familiarisations—or `famils', as they are known in the tourism industry—are an essential part of marketing a product. One reason for some tourist enterprises failing and other tourist enterprises succeeding is the simple fact that it is not good enough to just build a facility and hope that the people will come. It is not like that baseball movie, where the guy kept being told, `Build it and they will come.' The Australian tourism industry is littered with operations that were set up but never properly marketed. Everybody would know of one or two examples of that.

PARA.TAB: If we are going to wholesale holidays in this country to the international market, it is absolutely crucial that there be some proper recognition of and assistance with that process. That is what this amendment seeks to do. It is not fair to say that there will be a certain cost involved. An immense amount is recuperated in revenue, not just for the industry but also for the government, by virtue of the success of familiarisations. But if you do not do them, you do not get people, particularly from overseas.

Increasingly, people are being booked on package tours. It is therefore important that the wholesaler, or the retailer at the other end, knows what options are available to prospective visitors when they go to the tourism retailer's establishment to book a holiday. People go in and effectively buy from a catalogue, so it helps if the people helping them make a decision have been there and can say that they have been to a certain hotel, or on a certain cruise, or have done a certain safari, and can give a personal view of the experience. We have to remember that when we are selling tourism we are not selling a destination—we are not selling the sights of Sydney Harbour—we are selling a tourism experience. People buy that tourism experience on the basis of what they are told when they walk into the office of the booking clerk.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Schedule, page 4, after item 14, insert the following item:

PARA.TAB: "14A. Section 11ZC

SPEECH.PARA: Add at the end:
`(11) Expenditure is qualifying export development expenditure for an approved joint venture or approved consortium if:

PARA.TAB: (a)in the Commission's opinion, the expenditure is incurred primarily and principally for the purpose of:

TAB.TAB: (i)creating or seeking opportunities for; or
(ii)creating or increasing demand for:

SPEECH.PARA: the supply by a member of the joint venture or consortium of designated tourism services; and

TAB.TAB: (b)the supply by a member of the joint venture or consortium is for reward and in the course of carrying on business in Australia.'.".

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition's second amendment allows joint ventures and consortia to apply for export market development grants. In some respect this concerns what Senator Spindler was considering in his own amendment. However, for other reasons I will not be supporting his amendment. This amendment allows people in more remote areas—regions where farm tourism is carried on, for example—to be able to get together as a consortium.

PARA.TAB: Overseas marketing of any product—tourism in particular—is a very expensive exercise. One would have very little change out of $20,000 in the production of a decent brochure. This amendment will allow a group of single operators to get together and market their region. That is more effective than the government giving money to consultants in order to determine whether an area has tourism potential. Some people may be competing against each other, but it is necessary for them to get together and market their product overseas.

By supporting joint ventures we would attract more tourists to different areas of Australia. Single operators could not afford the money to market their product overseas. This measure gives an opportunity for one, two, three, four or five operators to join together as a group and market their product to the overseas wholesalers and retailers. That is the purpose behind the amendment. We believe that this measure will promote those areas of Australia which otherwise may not receive the benefits of tourism.

TALK.START.PARA: —What Senator Parer is seeking to do is consistent with so much government policy about regional tourism. Towns in Queensland, and elsewhere in regional Australia, are being told that if they want assistance in marketing tourism they must get together and create a regional tourism board or some sort of confederation of different towns in the area and seek grants on a regional basis. What Senator Parer is doing is entirely consistent with that approach. This amendment seeks to extend the EMDG mechanism to those regional bodies.

PARA.TAB: It is much more practical. I will give a first-hand example. The Gulf Country in Queensland is very interesting country and is different from the rest of Australia. There is no point in Burketown trying to market itself to the world; nor is there any point in Karumba trying to market itself to the world. But if, for example, the Gulf local authority development association or some other regional body put together a comprehensive package to take in all the experiences that the Gulf has to offer—from the Undara lava tubes to Escott Lodge at Burketown—it could be successful.

We are not going to get someone coming from the other side of the world to visit Burketown—with the greatest respect to my friends in Burketown—because it is not enough. People are spending a lot of money. These days tourists do not like to spend two weeks in the one place: they like to spend a bit of time here, a bit of time there, and a bit of time somewhere else. What Senator Parer is doing is entirely commendable, it is perfectly logical, and in fact it is a necessity if we are going to have proper tourism development outside the already established areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —The advantages to be gained from individual tourist operators being able to combine in a consortium are self-evident. The Australian Democrats will be supporting this amendment. I do not accept what Senator Parer said that this has anything to do with my amendment, which I will be moving in a minute and which seeks to reduce the threshold figure from $30,000 to $15,000. In many other industries it is very difficult for single operators at times and in particular locations to create a syndicate or a consortium. If one is serious about assisting small businesses, then one should not put additional barriers in front of them.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes this amendment and there are a number of reasons that I certainly want to make clear to the chamber. Firstly, the cost is estimated to be initially $2 million to $3 million, but may rapidly escalate. Secondly, large tourism operators currently excluded because of the $25 million export earnings upper limit would be able to gain access to this scheme through this facility. The scheme should promote things that otherwise would not occur. Fundamentally, tourism operates through this joint promotion anyway and the existing provisions of the act encourage this.

PARA.TAB: The aggregation of three or more tourism amenities would qualify the group for a 50 per cent grant rate, thereby providing a means of circumventing the application of the 25 per cent rate to single service providers. Because inbound tour operators operate larger on a joint basis with providers, there is potential under the current rules for them to receive multiple grants for joint ventures for different components of the same promotion. These are the main reasons why the government is opposing this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know this is not Senator Crowley's area, although she is handling the bill and she has her written instructions, but it would be interesting for her to consider her own state, as she could compare places like the Hunter Valley or the Yarra Valley in Victoria. There is a host of operations in those places which, on their own, are not capable of marketing themselves. The great vineyard areas of South Australia, the Hunter Valley and others have the opportunity to join with accommodation places to market their particular product. This is a reason for aggregation.

PARA.TAB: I note the estimated cost given by the minister, but the tourism industry is a classic economic industry. It is one into which very few other industries in the world fit. It is an industry in which, if the money is spent, there is a return made. An estimate has been made that for every dollar spent on the promotion of tourism—and this is not my estimate; I think it is the estimate of a learned man from Monash University or somewhere—there is a $32 return to this country, which is an incredible amount. So we cannot really weigh it up in the way the minister has.

Another point I want to make is that, if they are successful in attracting tourists, for every 17 tourists that come into this country another Australian is employed. Another interesting fact is that every tourist who comes to Australia spends something like $400 on indirect taxes to government. So the potential benefits to this country are great. It is a massive marketing exercise. Under this amendment—as I mentioned earlier, and as supported by Senator O'Chee and Senator Spindler—this is just another way in which operators who would not normally have the ability to participate in encouraging people from around the world to come and visit our country and see what it has to offer will now be able to do so.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Schedule, page 4, after item 16, insert the following items:
"16A. Paragraph 14(1)(b):
Omit `$30,000', substitute `$15,000'.
"16B. Subsection 14(1)(c):
Omit from the formula `$30,000', substitute `$15,000'.
"16C. Subsection 16(4):
Omit from the formula `$30,000', substitute `$15,000'.
"16D. Subsection 16A(3):
Omit `$30,000' (wherever occurring), substitute `$15,000'.
"16E. Subsection 16A(4):
Omit `$30,000' (wherever occurring), substitute `$15,000'.
"16F. Subsection 16A(6):
Omit `$30,000' (wherever occurring), substitute `$15,000'.".

This amendment, as I indicated before in my speech during the second reading debate, seeks to reduce the threshold amount from the current $30,000 to $15,000. The threshold has been increased progressively over the years and clearly it establishes a very significant barrier for small business operators who wish to break into export markets. We have seen items in the newspapers just in the last few days saying that only a small percentage of small business operators are entering export markets and that the potential is very much greater.

PARA.TAB: The government, aided and abetted by the opposition, actually puts barriers in front of small business to access this particular scheme which, if not the only one, is one of the really interventionist schemes that the government is pursuing—one that is successful and one that the Democrats support. All we are asking is that small business operators be given access to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —While the opposition has some sympathy for the proposal put by Senator Spindler, we will not support it. The proposal is to reduce the threshold for export market development grants from $30,000 to $15,000, bearing in mind that, currently, when the $30,000 is reached the grants start from $15,000.

PARA.TAB: As a person who has spent many years working in export promotion around the world, I would have to say that the suggestion is difficult to justify. One of the concerns that we had is that of cost and—this is no reflection on the small business sector with which I have a close affinity—the possibility for those who are not terribly interested in the promotion of exports being able to use the system for their own particular needs to travel overseas.

As I have indicated on many occasions, if one is serious in the export market it is not cheap—it is expensive. I think I mentioned earlier that the production of a brochure could cost as much as $20,000. Over a number of years we have seen the value of our dollar collapse to half the value of the US dollar and, going back far enough in time when there were 440 or 400 yen to the dollar, it is now 60 yen to the dollar. In fact, two or three trips to Japan will come to $20,000 very rapidly.

There must be a cap put on it. In this day and age with the Australian dollar at such a low value—others often call it the peso because of the actions of this government in doing what it has done to the economy—the amount of money spent must have a cap. My belief is that $30,000 is a reasonable cap, whereas the $15,000 would open it up. I would not like to hazard a guess at the cost and the amount of bureaucratic work involved in determining whether grants were eligible or not with a figure as low as $15,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret the position enunciated by Senator Parer on behalf of the coalition parties—a lot of words but, essentially, a smokescreen for the refusal to give small business a chance. I think they will stand condemned on that point.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will not be supporting this amendment. The estimated cost is around $3 million per annum. These thresholds were set as a result of a review by Professor Helen Hughes in 1989 and applied from 1990. Professor Hughes's analysis showed a direct correlation between the amount spent on promotion and the likelihood of developing sustainable export markets.

PARA.TAB: A higher threshold results in greater success, but may have less influence over the company's behaviour. Whereas a lower threshold raises the likelihood of failure but probably has a greater influence over behaviour. Subsequent evaluation supports this linkage. The thresholds have not changed in line with inflation since that time and the thresholds were considered to be appropriate by an independent evaluation of the scheme which concluded in April 1994. So, for those reasons, the government is not persuaded to support this amendment.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Schedule, pages 5 and 6, item 20, omit the item.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this amendment is to allow tourism operators exactly the same facilities as are available to every other exporter in this country. It is worth pointing out that in 1993 the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology unanimously concluded that not only was it inequitable to have one sector of industry eligible for assistance through the export market development scheme and others not but it was inequitable that exporters of manufactured goods and other services were eligible for assistance while certain exporters were not. It went on to recommend that tourism be given full access to the scheme.

PARA.TAB: There seems to be a slow realisation by the Labor Party in this country that tourism is now one of our major industries. It is in the same league as mining, primary industry and manufacturing. If one looks at what the tourism industry in a very sustainable way brings into Australia, one will see that it is different from other industries because, under the normal export procedures widgets and so on, goods have to be produced. In my own industry, from years gone by, products had to be mined, processed, sent overseas and, in return, dollars came into Australia.

Tourism is a different animal altogether in that it promotes Australia internationally as a destination. It means that people come here, they are accommodated, they eat and they look at things without anything having to go out of Australia—the foreign exchange stays here. I would have thought that, since we are looking at a $27 billion current account deficit in the current budget and are realising the effect this will have on our foreign borrowings, every incentive would have been given to promote an industry that brings in close to $12 billion worth of foreign exchange, employs over 500,000 people and has the potential to make a big dent in the unemployment levels in Australia, particularly among young people—that is where the opportunity arises.

The availability of export market development grants of 50 per cent to any other industry but not to tourism is inequitable. It flies in the face of what this government says it is trying to do. It flies in the face of really tackling our foreign debt. It flies in the face of tackling our current account deficit. As I have indicated at other times in this debate, this is an industry which is tied up with promotion: if you do not promote the industry, it will not survive.

I am pleased to see the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) in the chamber. Only a little time ago, on 2 March 1995, he put out a media release in which he lauded—quite correctly—the exports of Australian services to the world and said that they had increased by more than 11 per cent. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Growth was driven primarily by the strong performance of travel service exports which have become Australia's highest performing service export. . .

It is not only the highest performing. If one looks at the foreign exchange earnings of the tourism industry—around $11 billion—one can see that tourism earnings are higher than the combined earnings from exports of iron ore, wheat, alumina, aluminium, sugar and petroleum.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) in his closing remarks in the second reading debate talked about the growth of the manufacturing industry. The manufacturing industry has grown, but nothing has grown like the tourism industry. Tourism is the most competitive industry in the world. I have often made the remark in years gone by that, if it were not for tourism, places like London, Rome and Paris may not exist. Promotion is done mainly by the individual operators, certainly with the support of the Australian Tourist Commission—which does a first-class job. And the people who promote their industry most are those who have got most to lose—for example, the individual operators, the resorts and the regions.

There is no justification whatsoever in singling out the tourism industry for a lower export market development grant than other industries. In fact, it shows that the government is just paying lip-service to this particular industry. The government does not recognise it as being the major industry that it is and an industry that is competing fiercely with every other country in the world. I know the government will argue that this is going to cost $7 million—that is the estimate I have—but that takes no account of a number of factors. First, under the export market development grants scheme, supposing one is profitable and following the last budget, 36 per cent will go back to the government in tax because it is added to the taxable income.

Second—and I have said this prior to Senator McMullan coming in here—this is the classic industry where, if you want to earn money, you have to spend it. If you do not spend money on promotion, you will not earn it. Senator McMullan knows that as well as I. There are certain similarities between this industry and other industries. You have to have a good product and give a good service but you must promote it. Promotion is a major item. Without the first two factors, it is no good promoting to your heart's content. We have a good product, we give a very good service, we have excellent accommodation and other facilities, but it must be promoted. Once that promotion falls away, the industry itself will not grow. On all the information we have, for every $1 spent on promotion, $32 will come back into this country by way of revenue to Australia. There is no justification and it is highly inequitable that this particular industry should be treated adversely compared to any other industries doing their best to promote and market Australia or Australian products overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be voting for this amendment. As has been correctly emphasised, it is identical to the amendment the Australian Democrats have put on record. We believe that the Australian tourism industry is an important industry for Australia and that it should not be singled out for disadvantageous treatment, which is the effect of the government's legislation. It is difficult to understand, because tourism is one of the growth industries and an industry in which we perform well. As has been said by others, it needs to be promoted. It has a chance to grow, it has a chance to provide us with employment and with many other benefits that derive from interchanges with people from other countries. I believe that it would be totally inequitable to allow the government's bill to pass without amending it in this particular way.

PARA.TAB: In assessing this amendment we have of course considered the ecological concerns that are justifiably expressed on the issue of greenhouse emissions. On balance, taking everything into account, the Australian Democrats have decided that the tourism industry must be promoted—at the very least, it must be treated equally with other export industries that Australia is promoting through this scheme, which the Australian Democrats promote. It is one of the most successful interventionist schemes—and one of the few—which the government still has in existence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very strange debate. Anybody listening to this debate would think the government was about to slash assistance to the tourist industry. The fact is that the government's proposal is for a very major increase in assistance to the tourist industry. The argument is whether the assistance should be what the government proposes or twice that amount. That is the debate.
—No, it is the same as everyone else.

—Let me get the first point clear. This great booming industry was very accurately described by Senator Parer; it must have been accurate because he quoted me. The comments of Senator Parer and Senator Spindler about the importance of that industry are without challenge from me. We accept that. That is why I cannot go into the nature of the cabinet process that led to the ERC approving this 25 per cent, but it was the result of some very significant compromise and concession in other areas of priority by the trade portfolio because I recognise that tourism is important.

PARA.TAB: Why did we make the distinction? It is not true and it has never been true that to treat everybody the same is to always treat everybody fairly. That is not a principle that the Democrats support. They distinguish between people on the basis of need, and properly so. The opposition also does, but not so much. We have never fallen for that logical fallacy that treating everybody the same equals treating everybody fairly. We need to treat everybody in accordance with the circumstances in which they find themselves.

The evidence shows that a large part of the overseas promotion for Australian tourism, which is what is covered by EMDG matters, and what determines whether people choose Australia, Hawaii or Europe, is money already provided by the Australian government. That is not true when people are choosing to buy steel, coal or other products, but in this circumstance it is. There is a large amount of Australian government money that says, `They make the choice for Australia.' The subsequent advertising is `competition within Australia'. Much of the promotion that is done is about whether they go to Cairns or Townsville and then within Cairns, Townsville, Melbourne or whenever, which place they go. There is nothing wrong with people doing that—it is a perfectly proper commercial activity—but that is not adding to our exports.

The competition between Australians is that once the Australian decision has been made, it is qualitatively different. There is no other industry that has that first and critical decision so significantly influenced by government outlays. That is not just some assertion. The evaluation has found that a portion of the tourism industry's promotion did not create additional tourism; it directed tourists who were already coming to Australia to particular facilities, what is known as the captive market factor.

The committee that reviewed the EMDG also found that there was a strong interrelationship between individual promotion and generic promotion. The government already provides significant support for generic promotion to the Australian Tourist Commission. It is not that we are saying that we do not regard tourism as important as other industries. There is massive budget support for tourism. There should be and there is.

I am not saying anything about the Democrats because it is a while since they put out a comprehensive alternative budget strategy and they may well in those days have advocated more funding on tourist promotion. That is possible but I have not seen it for a year or so. The opposition has not proposed that we should increase outlays on tourist promotion. I am not saying that it is proposing to cut it. We could go back to Fightback and have a bit of fun about that, but that is not the point I am trying to make. The point I am making is that the opposition is not proposing that we increase it at this stage, nor cut it. It is saying that promotion is okay. I am saying that it has to take that into account when it says that this industry should be treated the same as every other. It is not in the same circumstance as every other. Therefore, treating them the same will not give the equivalent budget support—taxpayer support—to the various industries. Treating people in different circumstances in the same way is not treating them necessarily equally or fairly. That is the principal argument.

Of course, the secondary argument—Senator Parer flagged it and it is correct—is that this amendment adds to the cost of the budget $5 million in 1995-96, $7 1/2 million in 1996-97 and $9 million in 1997-98. They are the figures I have.
The government will not accept this amendment. We will vote against it here and we will not accept it in the House of Representatives. When it comes back, we will have some hard choices to make.
Amendment agreed to.

Motion (by Senator Alston, on behalf of Senator Hill) agreed to:

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)the report of the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) on the cross media rules was handed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) on or before 7 June 1995,
(ii)the Government has made it clear that this report will form the basis of upcoming legislative changes to the cross media rules,
(iii)the Minister has not given any firm commitment to make this report publicly available, and
(iv)there is no valid reason for not publicly releasing this report; and

PARA.TAB: (b)orders that there be laid on the table, before the adjournment of the Senate on 21 June 1995 by the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator McMullan), the report of the ABA referred to in the Minister's media release of 3 May 1995.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to speak on this matter at length, other than to say that I understand Senator McMullan has an objection. I would be more than happy to hear from him and it may well be that Senator Bourne and I would want to respond very briefly.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a more difficult issue than most returns to order we come to deal with. When I explain why it is more difficult, it should be easier. In fact, the difference between us is narrow but it is one of certain underlying assumptions. This is not a question of whether this is a document which should be public or not. That is an agreed view by, I think, everybody in the chamber. It is a question of when it should be public, and we are not even disagreeing about a very long period. If this motion referred to next Wednesday, 28 June, then probably the government could agree to it, although I might find myself in an embarrassing position next Wednesday, but probably not. Let me explain why.

PARA.TAB: The report of the Australian Broadcasting Authority is a report the nature of which we would normally expect to be made public, and the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) has indicated his intention to do so. But it is a matter bound up with and part of a submission which the minister is making to the cabinet and the cabinet is scheduled to deal with next Tuesday. Once the cabinet has made its decision, we will release the document. The minister has indicated, I think publicly, but he has certainly authorised me to say to the Senate and to Senator Alston that we will then release it. If it has not been said publicly, I say on his behalf that it will be made public soon in conjunction with the announcement of the cabinet decision, and I expect that to be Tuesday or Wednesday of next week.

I cannot give a cast iron guarantee about that, because, of course, it is the prerogative of the cabinet to say, `We want more documentation, we want another round of consideration of this. Therefore we will defer consideration for a day or two.' That is always possible. It does not happen very often, but I would be giving a guarantee on which I cannot deliver if I guaranteed that the cabinet would do so on Tuesday. But that is my expectation.

This is what distinguishes this return to order from those which we normally have, which is a contention about whether it is appropriate that a certain document should be public; is it cabinet-in-confidence; is it commercial-in-confidence—all those arcane arguments which we have from time to time. This is only about timing. It is about the role of this document as a part of the executive government's decision making process, as against its role as part of the public debate about the issue. I accept, and I think Senator Alston accepts, that there are arguments on both sides. It is not an easy judgment to make, but I and any one who has been in executive government or who aspires to it will accept that I am bound to the point that this is a document currently categorised cabinet-in-confidence.

The document is part of a submission to cabinet for its consideration next week. We will not use that category to protect it from public debate and from people who want to analyse our decision as to whether we should have made some alternative judgment. We will release it when we make the decision. I expect the Senate to carry the motion. I ask it not to, but if it is going to, that it amend the date to next Wednesday, 28 June. I think there is a 90 per cent chance we can comply with that date, but I cannot give a guarantee. I will seek to do so and the minister has indicated that he will seek to do so.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—It is clear that the government acknowledges this ought to be a public document. Therefore, the only argument in relation to timing is to suit the political convenience of the government. To cloak it with cabinet-in-confidence is no more than saying that cabinet wants to take it into account at some stage.

PARA.TAB: As we know, the Senate will not sit for about seven weeks after next week. Of course, it may not sit at all before the next federal election. I am sure Senator McMullan acknowledges, if not publicly, then in his heart of hearts, that a 90 per cent guarantee that it will be finally resolved next week and therefore able to be tabled or at least made public is not worth the paper it is written on.

I understand perfectly that the government may well decide it simply does not want a debate on this matter until the election campaign. Well, good luck to it. But the point remains that this has been a matter of immense public controversy. The Minister for Communications and the Arts, Mr Lee, has stated in the media that his preferred option was 20 per cent. Now we have had this report, he is saying he wants 15 per cent. The public ought to be able to have their say. It simply ought not be debated in private by the government at a time to suit its political convenience. The matter ought to be on the table publicly so that not just political parties but all those interested in the community can have an input. Therefore, I think it is in everyone's interests—perhaps not the government's political interests but everyone else's interests—to ensure there is the maximum possible input into a very contentious issue as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree, and I think everybody here agrees, that the changes to cross-media rules are a very vital part of the communications debate in this country. Of course, the sooner we see it, the better. I have spoken to Senator McMullan about this matter. As usual, I have found him to be very reasonable and sensible in his approach. I know that he, too, would like to see this as a public document. Obviously, it has to be a public document; it has always had to be a public document. We have been calling for that forever. I do not see any reason why the ABA should be able to do things in secret when the ABT did not.

PARA.TAB: I have spoken to a few people today. It is their opinion—and I must say it has influenced my thinking—that it would be a very sensible and reasonable move for everybody in the Australian community, including the ALP backbench, to be able to see the ABA report before cabinet makes a decision. They should at least have the opportunity to have some input into cabinet's decision. They should have the opportunity to see that report before cabinet makes its decision on how it will respond.

I must apologise to Senator McMullan because I know this is not what I said to him on the phone. I must say that I found that argument really quite persuasive. I think it is a sensible one. I certainly want to see it as soon as possible. It is the case that yesterday I was prepared to wait until next week. Having heard that argument in particular, I find that it is a very good argument.
