The government backbench, as well as I, ought to be able to see this before cabinet makes a decision. I would like to see it as soon as possible and I will be voting for the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens have expressed concern on a number of occasions about the types of categories of documents that the government says are not available. It is getting to the ridiculous kind of statement that the only things the Senate can ask for are those things which normally would be available under freedom of information. Because of this concern that there is this closing-in on the kind of information that the democratic parliamentary process can have access to in order to make proper decisions, we would certainly support this reasonable request from the opposition to have this document made available and not at some politically convenient time for the government.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Alston's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1995FRINGE BENEFITS TAX AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 9 June, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That these bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to concentrate my remarks in this debate in respect of the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1995 and the Fringe Benefits Tax Amendment Bill 1995 on the manner of financing our health system arrangements in this country. At the outset, I note that there is much to be proud of in the current health system arrangements. The coalition, as has already been announced, endorses these aspects and will ensure that they continue under the next government.

PARA.TAB: Bulk-billing and community rating will be features of the coalition's health care system. No member of the community need be in any way concerned that bulk-billing might be lost if a coalition government is elected. As I have said, there is much in the current health arrangements about which Australians can be proud. However, there are also features of the current arrangements which the government must acknowledge are indefensible and must act to remedy.

I do not, however, wish to examine those issues today. I highlight the degree to which Australians are being forced into a collective system of health care, where those who are financially able to contribute to their own health care arrangements are able to ride on the back of average Australians and compete with them for places in the public hospital system.

This is not an equitable health system. This is not egalitarian: it is socialist; it is ideological; and, most certainly, it is inefficient. Until Australians with the financial capacity to take responsibility for their own health care are encouraged to do so by utilising the private health care system, we will continue to waste resources and we will continue to see waiting queues grow. As I said earlier, I would particularly like to take the opportunity to consider the method of financing the Medicare health system.

When Chris Hurford, a former Minister for Housing and Construction and Minister Assisting the Treasurer, introduced the Income Tax Laws Amendment (Medicare Levy) Bill into the House of Representatives on 6 September 1983, he said that he did so with pride and with pleasure. The bill introduced a surcharge, an add-on, a levy, a tax—a tax of one per cent on taxable income for people residing in Australia—to finance the implementation of the government's universal Medicare system. That was back in September 1983—almost 12 years ago.

Of course, the government claimed that this was no tax: it was a levy—a contribution by Australian taxpayers. Even though the levy was to be collected by the Australian Taxation Office, and employers had to deduct the levy from the workers' salaries, the government continued to claim that this was no tax.
Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Order it being 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, because of the culture I have grown up in, my religion, the philosophy I find to be true, my instincts, my emotions and my logic, I am against making euthanasia legal. This is a free, democratic and multicultural society; it should be kept that way. Many people in Australia take a view of things widely different from mine. While the community must accommodate this diversity, clearly there are some things society treats as going beyond the bounds of what it can accept.

PARA.TAB: In spite of ours being a free, democratic and multicultural society, we impose criminal penalties on people who rape, assault, steal, take part in unlawful assemblies, act offensively in public places, illegally use uniforms and, in some circumstances, go on strike. Murder is an activity that is punished in all societies of which I know. It seems to be universal policy amongst law makers to punish murderers. There are differences from jurisdiction to jurisdiction as to whether a particular act constitutes murder but, whatever makes up the deed is declared a crime.

The Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory has declared certain acts by medical practitioners which were previously declared murderous acts no longer so. Some have said that the Northern Territory act is a compassionate one; that it is an expression of values of freedom and democracy. I cannot see that.

If euthanasia is a good thing, why are there so many people denied it who, on the basis of the thinking behind it, seem entitled to its benefits? Why is a person who is suffering from a treatable clinical depression not able to enjoy the good that euthanasia brings? Why is the same true of someone who is 17 years of age, or who has not considered the implications of his or her decision for his or her family, or who is of unsound mind, or who is living in an area where only one doctor is available, or where no interpreter can be got to the bedside? Why are they not able to make use of this good? In other words, why is this act so capricious?

If euthanasia is as good as it is contended to be in the Northern Territory, why is it made available to so few people? Is it that at the back of the minds of the people who passed this law there is a fear that, in the end, a killing in the circumstances which they have approved is so near what is still considered murder in the Northern Territory? Is it that they fear going to the point which the logic of the situation compels?

On what principle are people denied a merciful death? Why should it be murder if a doctor kills them but not if a doctor disposes of people from a very narrow group? In other words, why is the group identified in this act—those who are entitled to be killed in such a way that the doctor does not become liable—so narrow if this procedure of euthanasia is so good? The logical result of all this is for future legislation to widen the coverage of the act, and legislation creep—or legislation gallop—is likely to take place.

The number of authorities that can now make legal use of telephone interceptions has increased apace since ASIO was first allowed to employ them. The tax file number was to have had a most confined use when parliament first approved its establishment, but that use has widened amazingly in the meantime. The powers that this legislature has given to investigative agents have expanded mightily over the last decade. Precedent creates a logic for its own development. Making some kinds of killing lawful makes it almost inevitable that more and more types will be brought within the law.

If killing is allowed in the circumstances provided for in the Northern Territory act it is almost impossible not to see that there must be an extension to people who are under 17 years of age; to people who are of unsound mind; and to people who have not taken into account the effect that this might have on their families. We have a situation where what is now murder becomes an act of kindness and compassion within a few years. Acts which were of a murderous kind last year have now become acts of compassion within the meaning of the act. Some dreadful things can be done to people, some dreadful crimes can be committed, but murder is still the most heinous.

Many provisions in the act constitute a code that doctors must follow before they commit themselves to killing someone so that the killing is lawful within the meaning of the act. The opportunity for mistake along the way is mind-boggling. The ability of the Northern Territory police to investigate whether a killing is murder is going to be made incredibly difficult. The way out for the police is not to investigate killings if two doctors have been involved in sending the person to his or her grave or to the crematorium.
There is provision in the act to punish people who give a reward to doctors above and beyond what is proper. Section 6 of the act reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: A person shall not give or promise any reward or advantage (other than a reasonable payment for medical services), or by any means cause or threaten to cause any disadvantage, to a medical practitioner or other person for refusing to assist, or for the purpose of compelling or persuading the medical practitioner or other person to assist or refuse to assist, in the termination of a patient's life under this act.

That very provision contemplates that there will be people who will try to use this act for murder and not as a means of alleviating someone's pain. That underlines the difficulties that this legislation presents. The penalty provided is $10,000. If you want to get rid of someone and you give an inducement to a doctor, the most that can happen is that you will be fined up to $10,000.

PARA.TAB: The other thing I want to turn my mind to is that the people who will be doing the killing under this act will be doctors. Doctors take a Hippocratic oath to protect life. If we are going to have the sort of thing that is contemplated under this act, wouldn't it be better to leave doctors out and to train up, as it were, licensed killers so that the culture of medicine was not perverted by the culture of death? That is what we ought to be looking for. Perhaps we can have a TAFE course that educates people in the putting down of terminally ill patients so that we have, as it were, a sort of 007 number. That would save the culture of the doctors in this country from being tainted. Speaking for myself, it is a very bad business to expect doctors to put people down.

I have an emotional reaction to this. I have probably got a bit weak in this respect. I have an emotional reaction to seeing anything put down. I remember Dulcify, a great thoroughbred, being put down in the straight at Flemington. A canvas covering was put around the horse and it was put down. I would hate to see a doctor required to do that to people. If we are going to put a canvas covering around people and put them down when they feel under the pressure of extreme pain that they want to depart this life, why shouldn't we have, as it were, a band of people specially trained for the purpose? That way, the profession, which I have a daughter studying for now, will be kept clean of this necessity—and it will become a necessity for her in years to come if this develops the way some people hope. She will be expected to join in on this sort of thing.

Let us be clear about it: if this is going to be a democratic provision, then it should be available to everybody, no matter where they are. If there are only two doctors in a town, why shouldn't a person who wants to be put down under this act be put down with the compliance of those two people? If we do not expect them to do it, what sort of democracy is behind this? Is this an act of parliament that is providing for people in big towns only, only if they are suffering certain conditions, only if they can find two doctors to do it and, in certain circumstances, only if there is an interpreter present?

This is talked about as being a free and democratic act. Even if we take the principles of people who approve of this act, have honourable senators ever seen anything so confined, so undemocratic and so perverted almost that it applies only to certain people and to certain people who are able to get two doctors to go through a list of things that are provided for? It is an act that is difficult to justify under any principle that we, as a democratic society, would see as appropriate.

In the end it comes down to this: certainly legislation can change from time to time in relation to acts that constitute murder. But surely to goodness if the whole world, except the Northern Territory, considers that the acts it now takes out of the category of murderous acts should still be in a category of murderous acts, then we have something to worry about. Even given that the Northern Territory is no doubt one of the most outstanding, astute and intellectually attuned legislatures in the world, it is just so strange that no other legislature throughout this universe has gone down the same path. Perhaps I would be forgiven for concluding that we, as policy makers, ought to preserve the situation as it now is—in my view, always—but, even as legislators, we should at least preserve the situation until a lot more evidence and learning is brought forward into public debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to make a contribution to this debate and I congratulate Senator Cooney for his contribution. Euthanasia is currently a popular topic for discussion and, as a result, there is a need to inject a degree of maturity, sensitivity and intellect into this matter which concentrates on the ethics rather than simple slogans. We need definition and we need full extrapolation of the potential consequences of any change. We also need to define the value of human life and, indeed, its very meaning. In short, the topic is very deep.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, what does euthanasia mean? The Macquarie Dictionary tells me that it means a painless death. I am sure that only a sadist would disagree with such a sentiment. But the debate is not only about a painless death. The dictionary also tells me that active euthanasia means `the deliberate bringing about of the death of the person suffering from an incurable disease or condition, as by administering a lethal drug or withdrawing of existing life-supporting treatments.' I believe that those definitions are wrong in their current usage because it has always been the right of a person to reject medical treatment and, in a discussion of euthanasia, I do not think it is proper to introduce that aspect. Everybody has that right and there is no difficulty in exercising that right.

However, as the community is now discussing euthanasia, I believe that it is commonly defined as the intentional taking of life of a person who requests it for compassionate motives. Some would seek to define euthanasia on a broader basis, others on a narrower basis. Until there is a specific definition, we will vary as to what we are actually talking about. Some naively define euthanasia as providing medical help to a peaceful death. Whilst possibly technically correct, from the Greek basis of the word euthanasia, I do not believe it defines the topic of the debate. I have no opposition to a practice of providing medical help to assist somebody to a peaceful death. But I do not view medical help as meaning intentionally killing the person. There is a substantial difference between medical help and intentionally killing a person, and I echo the sentiments of Senator Cooney in that regard.

When we talk about the meaning of life, and things of that nature, one's personal faith and views on life clearly come into play. I make no apology or retreat in any way from the fact that my faith convicts me that human life is intrinsically valuable. It is a gift from God. It is His creation and I believe in the sanctity of human life. It is my view that in His wisdom He determines when life commences and ends for each one of us. To involve ourselves in that process is to embrace a most onerous responsibility. Sometimes we must make those difficult judgments; for example, in times of war or in self-defence, where a judgment has to be made. But just because those judgments have to be made, and sometimes acted upon, that of itself does not devalue human life or somehow make it expendable. The concept of human life being worthless or expendable is anathema to every instinct within me, hence my opposition to the death penalty, abortion on demand and euthanasia as killing the dying, as it is commonly called.

Whilst I accept that not all my fellow Australians would necessarily share my particular faith or beliefs, I believe that my values in this area would be generally embraced. As I understand it, every major religion in the world places value on human life. Indeed, our own indigenous people give human life a great degree of sanctity. I refer people who may be interested to the excellent contribution of my colleague Senator Boswell in this debate last week where he quoted certain Aboriginal elders and communities in relation to this matter.

For the purposes of today's debate, I will consider euthanasia as meaning the intentional taking of the life of a person who requests it and who is terminally ill. I acknowledge that that definition may not necessarily be accepted by everybody but I believe that in general terms it defines what the discussion is all about. I think it is a pretty narrow definition when we listen to some of the contributions that have been made. But even with this narrow definition, there are very real problems. The definition has three elements. The first two are the preconditions for the third, or the act of killing. Firstly, one needs the person's request or agreement; secondly, one needs the confirmation that someone is terminally ill. If those two preconditions are in existence, one can then move to terminate that person's life.

Those two preconditions require definition in themselves. How do we define a request? What if the person changes their mind but is unable to communicate the change? What if the request is the product of a mentally ill or depressed mind? Terminally ill people are often also clinically depressed. What if people are only clinically depressed and want to be relieved of life? If somebody stands on top of the Tasman Bridge, for example, in my home state of Tasmania and says, `Please help me to commit suicide,' only on the basis of a mental illness or a desire to be relieved from the tragedy of life, do I then assist and say that I was assisting this person to exercise their democratic right? Do I help someone commit suicide? I would like to think that in a civilised society I would not do so.

We then move to the other precondition. How do we define `terminally ill'? As I understand it, in the Northern Territory legislation one needs two doctors to make that finding. But what is terminally ill? Does a person have only six months to live, three months to live or 24 hours to live? What is a terminal illness? Often we do not know. The only thing we can be sure of is that from the day of our birth we are afflicted with the certainty of death, but when it will come upon us none of us know. I know that as a lawyer I exercise my best judgment from time to time and try to advise my clients. I have been in situations where I have advised a client of a certain course of action. In one case, we then moved to the registrar of the court who in fact had the same view that I had privately advised my client of. So we had two legal opinions saying to somebody, `This is going to be the outcome if you proceed to court.' Because of the insistence of my client, we in fact went to court and, to a certain extent to my embarrassment but also to my delight, we won the case. The judge had a different opinion from me and the registrar.

I was sharing that view with Senator Cooney and others at a committee hearing the other day and Senator Cooney was gracious enough to provide a similar example from his legal career which highlighted the same point. He said to somebody, `Look, you've got no hope of winning.' The client insisted that they went to the High Court and they won. The best judgment of two doctors may well be wrong. I believe it would be a great mistake to allow two people to make such a determination.
Doctors are committed to life and they allegedly subscribe to the Hippocratic oath to which Senator Cooney refers. A section of the oath says:

SPEECH.PARA: To please no-one will I prescribe a deadly drug, nor give advice which may cause his death.

These words are very powerful. As doctors and as people in the field of medicine, doctors should not be engaged in activities which are clearly a breach of the Hippocratic oath. If doctors do engage in these activities they will undermine the culture of the medical profession for centuries and centuries. The decision of a person to refuse medical intervention is an appropriate decision which each and every person is entitled to make, but such a decision is a red herring in relation to this debate. In public debate, we frequently hear about the rights and the choices of the individual and it is said that these considerations are somehow paramount. Personal autonomy is an important consideration and it is one to which I am overwhelmingly committed. However, I also accept that the principle of personal autonomy, while worthy of support, must be appropriately balanced if we are to protect the moral structure of our society.

PARA.TAB: The sloganeering of autonomy, choice and rights without corollary and without countervailing responsibilities results in a self-centred perspective and in the ultimate destruction of a shared future and a view of society. For example, to exercise our autonomy by driving on the wrong side of the road impinges on the rights of others. Similarly, we as a society need to make a positive choice in favour of protecting the interests of the vulnerable members of society, even if this action has the unfortunate result of limiting the freedom of others. Whilst I submit that it is acceptable for a patient to exercise his or her right to refuse medical treatment, it must remain unacceptable for a patient to request to have his or her life intentionally terminated. There are two reasons which spring to mind. Firstly, exercising the patient's autonomy may well impinge on the autonomy of a doctor who may not wish to carry out that request. Secondly, there is the culture of doctors that they should provide such medical treatment as requested by patients. What about that culture?

Even if the doctor is willing, the performance of such acts would have a dramatic effect on the care of the more vulnerable members of our society. Surely one of the identifying features of a civilised society is that it takes care of the elderly, sick and disabled in the twilight stages of their lives. A civilised society should do nothing to make the elderly, sick and disabled feel unwanted.

In rejecting so-called euthanasia, we must enhance the need to fully provide for the adequate development and growth of palliative care services in hospices, hospitals and in the community. I am reminded by an article in the Australian of the wonderful work of Mother Teresa in helping the homeless, the dying and others in the streets of Calcutta. The greatness of her witness and her compassionate work is not that she goes around with a lethal injection saying, `You poor person. Your life is no longer worth living. I will put you out of your misery.' The greatness of her witness and her compassionate work is that she provides succour and comfort to these people and that she allows them to die with dignity and on the basis of knowing that their life, no matter how socially or economically deprived it may have been, was worth living.
I conclude by referring to Dame Cicely Saunders, the founder of the modern hospice movement in the United Kingdom. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: You matter because you are you, and we will enable you not only to die with dignity, but to live until you die.

These words ought be the basis on which we, as a civilised society, address the very real and difficult problems that a lot of people face in the twilight of their life. I hope and pray that the people of Australia never adopt the view that there are some lives which are not worth living.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to speak in this debate about the issue of euthanasia. I need to say, as I guess each speaker would say, that I offer a personal opinion rather than the opinion of the Australian Democrats. It is a personal opinion which is held rather strongly for a number of reasons. I want to address the various issues as I see them in this particular debate.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, I address the issue of choice. One of the key phrases in this debate is the phrase `dying with dignity'. This is a very important issue. Let me suggest what dying with dignity means. It does mean not to have life prolonged mechanically and unnecessarily. It does mean managing pain so that a person's quality of life is not so diminished as to be unbearable. It does mean providing the kind of care which enables a person who is dying to know that they are part of a loving concerned community.

Let me now examine these meanings in terms of this debate and against the background of any proposed legislation. I believe that the mechanical prolonging of life is not an issue in this debate. Legislation would not clarify that for us at all. The community accepts that life should not be prolonged artificially and that normally is the practice. I think it is overstated and so often used to illustrate that, somehow or other, the projection is that there are hundreds of instances of life being prolonged artificially. That is not normally what happens. The choice not to prolong life artificially is already available to us. In fact, I believe legislation would take away that choice or at least lessen it.

On the issue of pain and care for people who are dying, let me suggest that to legislate to provide for euthanasia would mean that the community would no longer need to provide care or seek to relieve pain because legislation would provide an easy way out. We would simply terminate the person's life. There is no incentive to provide palliative care if, in fact, it is much simpler to terminate the life of the person.

I understand that this is one of the issues in the Northern Territory. The very lack of palliative care in the Northern Territory is one of the incentives, I believe, for having this legislation passed. The problems of funding and of providing places where such care could be provided seem more simply solved by legislation.

Another issue in terms of choice is the whole issue of the right to choose. We must ask ourselves what we mean by that. What is the cut-off point in terms of the right to choose? We usually debate euthanasia in terms of the aged and in terms of their pain and suffering, but it is the same principle when we talk about euthanasia for a person who is 10, 20 or 30. We are horrified at the thought that people of that age may have the right to choose because, quite rightly, we would say that is not euthanasia, it is suicide.

By and large, this community rightly prohibits suicide, but if we want to talk about the right to choose then that is the principle we are really debating. We often avoid that by projecting euthanasia as being about aged people dying with care, but the principle of the right to choose is a principle about suicide and we need to put that very squarely in this debate. If the age category is taken away then the principle we are debating is our attitude to suicide.

Let me talk a little about the effect of such legislation. Senator Cooney and Senator Abetz probably dealt with this more ably than I can, because of their legal background, but I think it is worth reinforcing what they said nevertheless. I understand that in the Netherlands the practice has far exceeded the narrow limits of the legislation, and that is the problem of any legislation. So often, legislation extends the limits of community permission. Once we legislate, the practice goes far beyond the point at which we would want to say, `That is as far as we can go.' An example of this is the debate about consumption of alcohol. I can remember when the minimum age for alcohol consumption was 21, and the community was worried that 18- and 19-year-olds were abusing alcohol. The problem is that having lowered the minimum age for the consumption of alcohol to 18, we are now having a debate about 15- and 16-year-olds abusing alcohol. From that, we can see what happens when we legislate; and I believe that analogy applies in this instance as well.

There is the practice of treating pain with morphine, which all GPs know about. Occasionally they administer more than is necessary to treat the person, perhaps in order to hasten death; but let me say that practice is in the context of treatment, not as a means as taking life, and I believe that there is a big difference in principle in that. Also, it is without the legislative incentive.

Another issue in this whole debate is the balance that there always needs to be between community pressure and the human rights of the individual. I know that we usually say that euthanasia is about the right of the individual to choose, and that sounds reasonable. I want to ask the Senate and the people of Australia: is it really about the right of the individual to choose?

Let me suggest that an individual in the situation which we usually project in this debate is in a very inferior and vulnerable position, and that in the end it is not a choice for the individual at all. What do old people do if they are told, and constantly made to feel, that they are a burden to the family or to nursing staff? Surely their ability to choose in that situation hardly exists at all. What happens to old people in cases where relatives want to get their hands on the estate? Before people say that would never happen, let me say that there are recorded cases of pressure being put upon persons and pressure being put upon doctors to terminate life simply because of the greed of family members.

And what happens when there is a pressure on hospital and nursing beds? That pressure is becoming more and more acute. What will happen to that pressure when euthanasia is legalised? Will it not then simply become a part of the management practice to facilitate the flow-through of patients in hospitals and nursing homes? What starts as a human right of the individual to choose will become the right of others to manage their institution efficiently.

The final issue in the whole debate about euthanasia is the brutalisation of the community. Once the human rights of one person are threatened, the rights of all are threatened. I disagree with some details of the Pope's recent encyclical, but not with the theme. He is right when he says that there is a culture of death abroad in our world. There are many pressures and many things which contribute to that culture of death. A culture in which human beings are simply expendable for all kinds of reasons is alive and well, and to make euthanasia legal would simply reinforce that culture of death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Two weeks ago I raised the issue of euthanasia during a matter of public interest debate in the Senate. This was as a result of the rights of the terminally ill bill passed in the Northern Territory Assembly on May 25. I spoke of the concerns felt by many groups not only in Australia but around the world about euthanasia. I spoke about the importance of the duty of governments to safeguard life and the impossibility of ensuring that all euthanasia would be voluntary. I call for a greater attention to the need for palliative care and health research services.

PARA.TAB: Today I am pleased to be standing with my colleagues here in the Senate representing all sides of parliament, all parties and representing the great spectrum of Australian community. I believe this is an indication of the cross-community resistance to legalised killing, whether that killing results from a compassionate motive or a belief in an individual autonomous right. Euthanasia is not simply a state issue, its scope and nature demand a response from the federal parliamentarians and other community leaders. In addition, the Commonwealth Medicare program would be involved in euthanasia death, as confirmed by Senator Crowley in responding to my question some time ago. Medicare funding agreements, rebates and pharmaceutical benefits would subsidise the killings.

During debate on the bill in the Northern Territory, the opposition leader, Mr Ede, also made reference to the role of federal government in drawing the regulations prescribing the manner and substances to be used in administrating death. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The administrator or whoever will go back to the government and the government will go to the minister, the minister will go within his department to find the expertise which is able to say that these are the guidelines.

They probably will not have to develop them either, and it will go to the federal government. With the federal government, there will be a clause that will say that these are the particular sets of words that the territory government is looking for. They will be sent up here and published in the NT government Gazette.

While the territory government has passed such a law allowing the killing of patients, it still requires the federal government to assist before it can come up with the fundamental regulations about how a person is to be killed. I hope the health minister's representative in the Senate, Senator Crowley, is listening because I would like her comments on the role of the federal government drawing up killing techniques and regulations for the territory.

PARA.TAB: I now want to summarise some facts about the passage of the rights of the terminally ill bill. The original bill has 17 clauses and 45 amendments were agreed. The final bill has 21 clauses. It is peppered with the Chairman's amendments to make it all hang together in as orderly a manner as possible. Finally, I draw the attention of the Senate to the schedule of the bill. I seek leave to table that document.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The schedule is entitled `Request for assistance to end my life in a humane and dignified manner.' It is to be signed and dated by the patient. This is followed by two declarations of witnesses where there is a space for the signature of the patient's medical practitioner and a second medical practitioner. Where an interpreter is used, there is another declaration to be signed by a qualified interpreter. There is no requirement on this form for the witnesses to date their declaration or to do more than scribble their signature. There is no requirement that they spell out their name or provide a medical practitioner number. There is no provision to register the place of address at which the request or declaration was made.

PARA.TAB: A roadworthiness certificate has more formal signing requirements than a request to end a human life. Firstly, a roadworthiness certificate has a unique number. The approved examiner has a licence number which must be quoted. It is dated all over the place and the address is clearly stated, together with its own approval number. Moreover, the approved examiner must certify that the provisions of the relevant act have been complied with. The euthanasia schedule demands no such certification from the patient's medical practitioner. The second medical practitioner is required merely to be `satisfied that the conditions of section 7 of the act have or will be complied with'. Surely the disposal of human life demands more formal procedures than the disposal of a used motor vehicle!

I cannot believe that such a document will stand up in a court of law. Witnessing officers to a mortgage document must provide a signature, print their full names and describe their qualifications and the date of the document. Where a will is typed on more than one sheet of paper, it is a usual and desirable practice to have the foot of each page signed by the testator and the witnesses to counter a fraudulent attempt to interpolate pages into the document. Unless the request to end life is supervised by a solicitor, will this practice be followed, and will there be careful checking of signatures and dates?

I understand the Northern Territory's desire to simplify a form for an ill patient, but it is life we are talking about and that demands the utmost care, scrutiny, safeguards and formal witnessing procedures. John K. De Groot's Wills, probate and administration practice advises that `for future identification purposes, if necessary, both witnesses should print their names, occupations, and addresses after their signatures.' There is nothing on the request to end life form which would suggest the witnesses do this. The request form is integral to the euthanasia practice. No matter what else is said and done in the act or anywhere else, it is this form that is at the centre. If it fails to withstand legal scrutiny, then the act will be fatally flawed.
I would like to conclude by quoting from The manual of Queensland succession law by W.A. Lee, which I think is a useful guide on this issue. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: In modern law, prescriptions of form are invariably statutory and are justified for a number of reasons. The formalities prescribed for the making and execution of wills perform a variety of different functions. First, they perform an evidentiary function. All formalities serve as probative safeguards.
Later, he says:
Evidence of due execution is best supplied by the inclusion in the will of a formal attestation clause.

In this case, a formal attestation clause does not exist. There is no clause saying, for example, `Signed by the above-named patient in the presence of us, both present at the same time who, in her presence and at her request and in the presence of each other, have hereunto subscribed our names as witnesses.' I am not a lawyer. There were two lawyers in this debate and there are many here in the parliament. But I raise these issues because, whether you are for or against euthanasia, I am sure that everyone would want the tightest possible safeguards when signing away a human life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate those who have preceded me in speaking about euthanasia. I will not attempt to go over what they have so expertly dealt with.

PARA.TAB: I want to say to the 13 politicians in the Northern Territory, `What have you done?' Those 13 politicians in the Northern Territory have, for the first time, legalised by act of parliament the deliberate and intentional killing of one innocent human being by another. That is a first; that is a world first. Stripped of all its euphemism, euthanasia occurs, in the medical context, when the doctor and not the illness kills the patient. Those 13 politicians, by their decision, have legalised the lethal injection. At a time when civilised country after civilised country is abolishing the death penalty, when those of us in Amnesty are trying to get others to abolish the death penalty, those politicians have installed in the law a licence to kill. At a time when political, medical and community concern about suicide abounds, they have legalised assisted suicide and thus promoted a culture of death.

I ask those 13 politicians, `How did you do it? Was it done after the mature reflection that was required in this life and death issue?' The answer must be no. Oh, yes, they set up a committee in February of this year to receive submissions and that committee reported in May of this year, a mere three months later—with the Easter break intervening, of course. And what did that committee report? It merely reported the views of those who made the submissions—no, not the detailed House of Lords report, nothing like that; instead, something, in my view, done in indecent haste.

I have been reading the Hansard of the Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory and I am amazed. First of all I must congratulate a number of the speakers who indeed made very thoughtful contributions. But I was amazed more so when I started reading the committee stage of the debate. Dozens and dozens of amendments appear to have been pushed through in the early hours of the morning or late hours of the night. I know that we are not beyond criticism as being sometimes a ramshackle show in the committee stage, but I invite honourable senators to read the Hansard of the committee stage of the debate on the Northern Territory bill.
I ask those 13 politicians further, `Why did you do it?' Yes, they did it for compassionate reasons and at least the mover was motivated in part by a stunted philosophical view of autonomy.

No-one has the copyright on compassion. Compassion really does mean suffering with a person, not putting a person to death. In this utilitarian, excessively individualist and hedonistic society which appears to be descending upon us the value of suffering for personal growth and for the opportunity to love and serve is ignored. Anyone whose wife has died in his arms of cancer and whose mother, an Alzheimer's sufferer some years later, also died in his arms realises the importance of suffering with a person. Sometimes that realisation comes too late. But what you do know when that happens is that the person with whom life and love have been intimately shared your life does not go out of existence—does not die like a dog. That person who has shared abstract thoughts and ideas not associated in any way with corruptible matter does not die like a dog.
The motivation of the mover of the bill was described by his assistant in an article in the Australian by Elizabeth Wynhausen which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: `It's got nothing to do with his mother's death,' says O'Brien, contending that the issue of euthanasia had long pre-occupied the man—
that is the mover, Marshall Perron—
`His whole philosophy is geared to the individual, and the individual doing what they want to do . . .

How ironic in the exercise of that absolute autonomy over your life you destroy that life and with it your prized autonomy itself, and what if there is a life after death? What if you do not like the state into which you have plunged yourself? Where is the autonomy in that? Admittedly, public opinion held sway over some members of the Northern Territory parliament—I have read the Hansard—but the manipulation of public opinion by sections of the press was absolutely deplorable. Some of the questions asked ran something like, `Are you in favour of a dignified death or would you prefer to suffer a protracted death in persistent unrelievable pain?' or, `Are you in favour of burdensome and futile treatment?' That sort of nonsense is a disgrace and a great disservice to the community. I cannot elaborate on that because I do not have time.

PARA.TAB: Who will be affected most by the decision of these 13 politicians? I believe it will be the marginalised, the sick, frail aged and those who have lost self-esteem or whose society does not affirm their esteem. A recent study of clinical trials of new drugs has shown that most of the human subjects of the trials are those very persons. It does not address the question of fear of death and the need to inculcate the importance of experiencing death as part of life. Only the other day a nursing sister of long standing in the geriatric area said to me that even now patients say, `Is that too much of a burden to you?'

If this goes into force, of course they will feel too much of a burden to those who are caring for them. Obviously, this legislation will not be implemented in a social vacuum, free from social pressures or familial pressures or from the financial pressures that were described by Senator Woodley. It is important to have educative programs in which persons can understand the difference between euthanasia and the treatment for pain and palliative care. Palliative care, as Senator Woodley said, is going to be the loser. There should be education of doctors and, more particularly, of families as to what morphine and other drugs might do, but this has to be handled extremely carefully.

I come now to a particular area of concern to this parliament: Aboriginals and our Aboriginal power conferred upon us by the amendment to the constitution. This decision of 13 assembly members runs counter to Aboriginal respect and reverence for life. Of all people, Aboriginals know life's fragility and the need of the tribe to defend its sanctity. The Central Land Council made it clear in a statement reported in the Australian of 13 June. The Chairman of the Central Land Council described voluntary euthanasia as `culturally inappropriate' and warned that many Aboriginals would be `afraid' of visiting hospitals and health clinics if the law were enacted. The spiritual basis of Aboriginal culture has been radically vilified by the legislation.

I believe great harm is done to the body politic by the legislation. It threatens to undermine the cornerstone of society, which depends upon the inviolable nature of the right to life of every individual human person. On that inviolability rests the equality and dignity of each human being and the edifice of law which protects that life and advances that person's benefit. From that inviolability flows the human solidarity needed to achieve justice for all human beings—the reverse of the legislation whereby the value of life is eclipsed and a culture of death is inculcated.

The Universal Declaration of Human Rights makes two rights inviolable: the right to life and the right to liberty. The state will not condone people selling themselves as slaves. The cornerstone of any body politic is to ensure that the right to life is inviolable. The real purpose of civil law is to guarantee an ordered social coexistence in true justice. The principal function of a law-maker is to safeguard the inviolable right to life of the human person and to facilitate the performance of his or her duties. I believe that those 13 members of the Northern Territory parliament have done great disservice to the body politic.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to make some comments with regard to the debate that has been generated here on the issue of euthanasia. This is an important matter. The time for this debate has now properly come in Australia. The fact that the Northern Territory parliament has pioneered the parliamentary consideration of this important issue is, I think, of merit to that particular parliament. It has faced up to what is a very passionate, a very difficult, a very moral, ethical and intellectual debate, which now must be carried on right throughout Australia.

PARA.TAB: I know that my parliamentary colleagues of all political persuasions in the Northern Territory have had an extremely difficult but challenging debate in addressing this important issue. I have watched the debate very carefully in the parliamentary consideration in the Northern Territory over the past few months, and I have also had the opportunity to canvass the issue with fellow residents of the Northern Territory. In particular, I have watched the maturing debate on this issue in the open media of the Northern Territory, where all territorians—whether in letters to the editor, whether in feature articles in the print media, whether in active electronic media debate or whether in bar room discussions—throughout the community have actively participated in this particular and important consideration.

I must admit that at the beginning of the debate I was a cynic with regard to the proposals as they were first presented to the parliament by my friend and long-term colleague Marshall Perron, who recently retired from the Northern Territory parliament. Marshall Perron and I have a long personal history. We grew up together as classmates in the Northern Territory and we have certainly grown up together as politicians in the Northern Territory. I personally was persuaded by the debate in all its aspects—particularly with regard to the legislation, as to how it was considered and how it finally ended up after very comprehensive amendment.

I appreciate that a number of my colleagues in this place take a totally different perspective and different view. That is right and proper, and again reflects the community debate. But I must say that I believe a majority of people in the community are very much of a view that the time for this debate has come.

I would like to take the opportunity to make available information with regard to the debate as it has been considered in the Northern Territory parliament. I seek leave to table the second reading speech of the then member for Fannie Bay, the Hon. Marshall Perron, delivered in the Northern Territory parliament on 22 February 1995.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following that consideration, the Northern Territory parliament established a special select committee to look at the issue, and a report was tabled in the Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory in May 1995. That committee canvassed views throughout Australia. It received hundreds of submissions from within the Northern Territory constituency and also from right around Australia and even a few internationally. The report is well worth proper and due consideration, because it canvasses the moral, the ethical, the medical and all the administrative aspects of this legislation. I seek leave to table, for further consideration, the report of the inquiry of the Select Committee on Euthanasia.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of speakers today have referred to the debate which ensued in the Northern Territory parliament on Wednesday, 24 May 1995 and which was carried on until the early hours of the morning of 25 May 1995. All 25 members of the Northern Territory parliament participated in that debate. As Senator Harradine said, the second reading vote was decided, crucially, by a vote of 13 to 12. That must have required a torturous decision for a number of those members.

PARA.TAB: After the consideration of some 50 amendments to the legislation, it was interesting to note that the third reading debate was carried by a vote of 15 to 10. It is also interesting to look at the break up of the party political constituency, because this matter was considered as a conscience vote, as it very properly ought to have been. From memory, of that 15 to 10 final vote for the third reading, in the then government numbers at the time of 17, the vote was 10 for and 7 against. Within the Australian Labor Party membership at that time of 7, the vote was 4 for and 3 against and the independent member Mrs Padgham-Purich voted for the legislation.

That demonstrates that it certainly was a bipartism debate. I seek leave to table, for consideration of other senators, a copy of the Hansard of the debate of that particular day. I commend all 25 speeches. I think it is important that we have those speeches available here for the record.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Finally, I seek leave to table a copy of what I have available of the legislation, which is a copy of the third reading print proof issue of the bill. My understanding is that this is a copy of the bill incorporating all of the accepted amendments as part of the Northern Territory parliamentary debate. Whilst I appreciate the final copy may be slightly different from that, I would hope that it would not differ in any substantive form. It is important, for further debate in this place, that people have access to that document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the documents that I have tabled should be perused, studied and discussed very openly by any member of parliament as a basis from which to build any further debate on this important and constructive issue. It is fine for all of us to come to this debate with very quick and easy reactions whether they are based on our moral, ethical, medical or administrative understanding. At the same time, I believe the Northern Territory parliament has put before us for consideration a very fundamental and important issue. It will be very transparent and obvious that, as other legislation arises in this place—maybe to do with Medicare, the administration of health services or the funding of Aboriginal health—these issues will occur again and again. I believe that, in the next year or so, we ought to be properly challenged by this parliament, on a non-party basis, to deal with the fundamental issue. The time has come for much more active debate.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 1.58 p.m. to 2.00 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Why after 13 years of Labor government does the latest OECD survey show that Australia has the worst current account performance in the Western world?

—One can answer that question in several ways but the important thing is to answer it in its proper context of having regard to what the OECD survey shows about the entire Australian economy. This government has never hidden the fact that its policies are directed to addressing the current account deficit. That is indeed the reason why we moved strongly to tighten fiscal policy in the last budget and to create a level of national savings by the measures that we propose to introduce on superannuation.

—On the point of order of relevance, Mr President: the minister is not answering the question that was asked. The question was: you have been in office now for 13 years and the international tribunal says that your economic performance on this particular important index, that of the current account, is the worst in the Western world. Why after 13 years of your policies are we now in that situation?

—On the point of order, Mr President: what Senator Cook has explicitly and correctly said is that the only correct way to answer this question is in the context of the OECD report. Senator Hill has deliberately in his question tried to distort that report by selectively extracting one negative feature and does not like the fact that Senator Cook is going to outline all the positive elements. Nevertheless, the proper understanding of the point which he has made requires recognition of all the others.
—I do not believe there is a point of order.

—Thank you, Mr President. I am making the point that this budget that we have brought down introduces a national savings plan and engages in significant fiscal tightening. Those things are recognised by the OECD as positive things. Indeed, if you read the report, the OECD counsels the rest of the world to do those things. Australia leads in taking those measures.

PARA.TAB: But what else do we find in the OECD report? Australia has the highest level of economic growth in the OECD. It stands to reason, given the inheritance we got when we came into power, that we needed to open the economy, encourage greater international competitiveness by Australian industry and engage in a broadening of the base of our exports, that we would go through a period of transition as we internationalised the economy.

Let me remind you that under your government we had managed exchange rate variations. We had a whole range of other things that we have abolished to make this economy far more internationally competitive. One of the obvious things that flows from that is problems on the current account, given the need to import capital goods to replenish and rebuild our manufacturing base and the need for our economy to get a high level of international finance.

Those things are addressed directly and head on in this budget. If Senator Hill is concerned about these things—and the purpose of your question is to raise concern about them—then there is one thing that the opposition in this place can do to help, and that is support the passage of the budget bills.

If you do not do that, if you want to turn this budget from being in surplus to in deficit by unmaking the budget bills and if you want to remove the downward pressure we have placed on interest rates by creating uncertainty, you will be responsible for undermining the Australian economy. It is an exercise in gross hypocrisy for the coalition—in fact, it is an exercise in misleading the Australian community—to wax lyrical about concerns never in context and never realistically or accurately expressed but, when it comes to action, to have no policies and engage in what amounts to a sabotage of an attempt by the government to correct the current account deficit and have a level of national savings and a budget surplus which would reassure the markets in the appropriate way. To some extent, the answer to this problem lies with the opposition in backing the government's move to lower the current account deficit. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question relating to that pathetic response that it was the fault of the opposition that we have got the worst economic record in this area of the Western world after 13 years of Labor government. Senator McMullan invites me to refer to other aspects of the economy as reported upon by the OECD. Minister, isn't it the case that the OECD has now, from last month, revised down Australia's growth forecast, revised up Australia's inflation expectation and revised upward our unemployment expectations? And aren't we back on the same old roller-coaster: growth, recession—as we have seen in the past—excessive spending, unsustainable growth, a blow-out in the current account deficit, rising interest rates and rising unemployment? Isn't that in fact your record after 13 years of Labor government?

—The answer to that question is: no, it is not. The OECD forecasts are calendar year forecasts, and if you take account of calendar year forecasts and compare them to our budget forecast, which is a financial year forecast, the truth is that both levels of forecast are broadly similar. In our budget forecast, we have said that growth this year is moderating—moderating from a high level to a more sustainable level so we can have a regular, consistent and sustainable level of economic growth and reduce unemployment in this country.

PARA.TAB: I can say a lot more about the OECD forecast based on scenarios, rather than forecasts, in terms of unemployment, and not take into account other factors that are important to that subject. But in the end what we have had from Senator Hill is a trotting out of `you wish' scenarios by the opposition, which fundamentally believes that if it undermines the Australian economy, its electoral stocks will increase. The response of Australians to that will be to not vote for the saboteurs. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, Senator Schacht, will be absent from question time today as he will be attending in Sydney the 40th World Conference of the International Council for Small Business. In Senator Schacht's absence, Senator Bolkus will represent the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, and Senator Cook will take questions on small business, customs and construction.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that this week marks 20 years since the enactment of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act. Could the minister please detail to the Senate what has been done over that period to ensure the protection of our world heritage listed Great Barrier Reef for future generations?

—Twenty years ago, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act was passed with bipartisan support in the Australian parliament, which I think recognised the irreplaceable value of the Great Barrier Reef. The act enabled the boundaries of the largest marine park in the world to be declared. It also established the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, which began the process of developing zoning and management plans which have become models for the management of marine protected areas world wide.

PARA.TAB: The act banned mining and oil exploration within the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park and enabled the marine park to be zoned and managed for ecologically sustainable use. The Great Barrier Reef was inscribed in the world heritage list in 1981 in recognition of its universal, cultural and natural value. The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority has provided for the protection and wise use of the Great Barrier Reef, with a major focus on working cooperatively with the Queensland government, other government agencies, interest groups and the wider Australian community to ensure the active commitment of all stakeholders to the sustainable use of the reef. An active and comprehensive program of public participation, which is recognised in the act, is a key feature of the marine park authority's planning and management approach. This effective public involvement in the planning processes has resulted in a higher level of community acceptance of management decisions.

Understanding and commitment of reef users to ecologically sustainable use of the Great Barrier Reef continues to be the most effective means of ensuring that the reef remains the best example of a multiuse marine protected area. The reef contributes more than $1 billion per year to the Australian economy through activities such as tourism and commercial fishing. Use of the reef is expected to increase considerably, as is the economic benefit that is generated by this use. The marine park authority is addressing the issue of the resulting increase in environmental impact through its current management practices and forward looking plans. Last year the visionary 25-year strategic plan for the Great Barrier Reef world heritage area was launched by the Prime Minister and is now being implemented by the various stakeholder groups.

The strategic plan set 25-year and five-year objectives for the conservation and ecologically sustainable use of the world heritage area. The plan is supported by more than 70 government and non-government agencies, interest and user groups and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. The strategic plan is acknowledged as a world first in participative regional planning. I think it is fair to say to Senator Reynolds in response to her question that we celebrate 20 years of partnership in managing the Great Barrier Reef. I think we can also be confident that the Great Barrier Reef will be protected for the benefit of future generations.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer to Dr Lawrence's challenge to the validity of the Easton royal commission—an inquiry totally unrelated to her federal duties. If you consider it in the public interest to intervene in this matter, and thereby cunningly and effectively run this challenge for Dr Lawrence and possibly pay all her costs in any event, surely it is in the public interest for the process through which this decision was made to be transparent. Will you table the guidelines relating to the payment of ministerial legal costs? Will you also table on behalf of the Attorney-General: firstly, details within the knowledge of the Attorney, his office or his department of all discussions leading up to the decision being made and of any correspondence touching on the matter; secondly, any legal opinion relating to the decision; thirdly, an estimate of the cost to the Commonwealth of the decision, especially the costs to be met in the event of failure; and, fourthly, the names at least of any people who have provided an assessment that the action has a reasonable chance of success? (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —A couple of points need to be made in respect of this. Not only is this a politically motivated exercise instituted by the Court government in Western Australia but there is no doubt that if Premier Court was not in the business of trying to embarrass the federal government, he would not be going down this route. If he was not in the business of embarrassing a federal minister, he would not be going down this route. In that respect, one only has to refer to the comments of the Deputy Premier, Hendy Cowan, last Friday on ABC radio when he said:

ANSWER.PARA: This is not going to be very easy for people to say that this is nothing more than an exercise in politics, and for that reason the inquiry could be damned before it starts.
On the Sunday program he said:
The National Party does not believe taxpayers should pay for what is essentially an inquiry to achieve a political outcome.

Playing politics is what is going on in Western Australia. The federal government has a legitimate interest to protect not just its role in the constitutional structure but also a number of constitutional issues. There are longstanding constitutional issues involved here—issues which go very much to the separation of powers and processes that have been part of our parliamentary democracy for some 300 years or so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr President. Senator Bolkus knows as well as anyone else that he was asked a series of very specific questions relating to documentation and the policy processes leading up to this decision. What we have had is a deliberate attempt to avoid answering any part of that question and to start debating the merits of how this all came about. He is not being asked that in any shape or form and it ought to be a very simple matter for you to ask him to answer this question.

—On the point of order, Mr President. It is premised very much on a contention that the federal government had no legitimate interest in this matter. What I am answering at the outset of the question is that point of legitimate interest. I will then go to the specifics of Senator Vanstone's inquiries and address them as well. But I am not going to answer one part of the question and not the other.

—On the point of order, Mr President. It was not in those terms at all. It was about whether he considers it in the public interest to intervene and then he was asked to produce the documents. He was not invited to get into a debate about the legitimacy of how the royal commission was established. He was simply asked: if you think it is necessary to intervene, will you table certain documents?

—On the point of order, Mr President. It is just furthering a particular point. The first premise—and Senator Alston just said it is—is the legitimacy of the federal government to intervene. That is precisely the point I am addressing in the first part of the answer, and I have not even got halfway through my answer at this stage.

—On the point of order, Mr President. I have the wording of the question I asked in front of me. It is premised on the basis that the government has concluded that this is in the public interest. It does not question that. It questions the transparency of the process by which you came to that decision. It asks you to table certain information on behalf of the Attorney. If you want to keep all of this hushed up, why don't you just stand up and say that? Otherwise, why don't you answer and indicate what you will table and what you will not?

—On the point of order, Mr President. If Senator Vanstone was to go through her question to me and that aspect of it that relates to the Commonwealth minister's responsibility in this area, she would see that that goes very much to the question of legitimacy. That is the point that Senator Alston made and that is the point that I agreed with. I have to address that legitimacy and that is precisely what I am doing now. Senator Vanstone will get her answer in respect of the second point, but I have not even got halfway through my answer as yet. I am addressing the first part of the question.
—Order! The minister has explained his position and I accept it.

—Putting aside the political inspiration for this inquiry, there are fundamental constitutional questions to be answered: conventions representative of parliamentary democracy; the confidentiality of cabinet deliberations; allowing the executive to question and impeach; and the presentation of petitions. For instance, bills of rights have laid out processes which have been followed by parliaments for several hundred years. All those matters are of importance to the federal government and will be pursued. That is why we have taken the decision to provide assistance in this matter.

PARA.TAB: In terms of questions relating to legal opinions, Senator Vanstone knows that those opinions are provided in a professional privilege situation. They are not made available and they will not be. With respect to guidelines, I will pass that on to the minister to see whether he can provide information. In terms of estimates, I will also pass that on as well.

Let me close on this particular point: if Carmen Lawrence were not a federal minister of this government, there is absolutely no way the Court government would make a decision to spend millions of dollars of taxpayers' money to embark upon this political crusade. If that were not the case, we would not have an inquiry. If the inquiry did not raise matters of constitutional import, there would not have been any leg at all for the Court government to pursue it. It has thrown up these issues. We have a responsibility in them and we will pursue them both separately of the Carmen Lawrence challenge as well as our own representation. This is a matter that cannot be allowed to continue.

In closing, I ask Senator Vanstone: if the tables were reversed and if a federal government was interfering in the processes of a state parliament, would you not argue that we had a legitimate interest in this matter? Of course, you would; and you would not be making available the legal advice either. But, gladly, you will not be on this side of the parliament to experience that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for at least indicating that he is not going to be honest with the public about any legal opinions he has had in relation to this matter and that he will get the Attorney-General to give an estimate of the cost to the Commonwealth. I ask him again: will he table details within the knowledge of the Attorney, his office or his department of all discussions leading up to this decision being made and details of any correspondence touching on the matter? Will he also give the names—not necessarily the opinions—of people who have provided an assessment that the action has a reasonable chance of success? Since you think it is appropriate to fund a person to challenge the action of a state government, will you agree to fund any person who is legitimately challenging a federal government decision, or do your little mates get better access to justice than any other Australian?

TAB.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are far too many interjections on both sides. I do not know whether senators really believe they are getting some political advantage out of this but I ask you to watch the replay of question time and ask yourselves again, `What are we getting out of this?'

—I agree with you, fully, Mr President. The behaviour on the other side on this issue has been indicative of their disrespect for constitutional rights in this matter. I have already answered Senator Vanstone in respect of her inquiries. I said that I will pass on all of them to the minister. I have not promised to give you anything, Senator Vanstone, and you know that. You are in the business of distorting language—and you are doing it again. In respect of whoever may have given advice—you know this very well; you are in the business of the fraudulent exercise of trying to persuade the public that maybe something is happening that should not be happening—
—Order! Senator, I ask you to withdraw that.
—Don't get too sensitive about it, Senator Vanstone. You know what you are doing—
—Order! Senator Bolkus, I have asked you to withdraw that reference to `fraudulent'.
—I said it is a fraudulent exercise. I did not—
—You were talking about a senator being fraudulent.
—I withdraw calling Senator Vanstone a fraud but I will say this is a fraudulent exercise because she knows full well that legal advice given to the Commonwealth is subject—

—I take a point of order. It is just not good enough, Mr President. You asked him to withdraw. I presume what you asked him to withdraw was the inference that I was behaving in a fraudulent manner. He hasn't withdrawn that. You can sit there like a poonce and let him ride over you or you can make him give an unqualified withdrawal—and that is your job.
—You don't help your cause by using that sort of language, Senator. Senator Bolkus, I ask you to withdraw unconditionally.

—I will, Mr President. I will close on this point: Senator Vanstone, through her experience in this place, knows that legal advice provided to government is subject to professional privilege. In this case, the advice was provided not only to government but also for cabinet consideration.
—What about the other question?
—You can say it as often as you like. I have already told you, Senator Vanstone, that I will pass on your detailed questions and whatever answer can be given will be given. (Time expired)

—Mr President, I take a point of order. Senator Vanstone used an unparliamentary term in characterising you in the chair. There is such a thing as the dignity of the chair and the upholding of decorum. I ask that you request her to withdraw her remark. I know, Mr President, that it is not something you would want to do but I think the Senate should call upon you to request the removal of that unparliamentary term.

—I thank you for your attempt to protect me. I have broad shoulders. I think it was a rather silly comment, not an unparliamentary one, so I will not ask her to withdraw it. But it was a silly and childish comment.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. The most recent edition of the OECD economic outlook of June 1995 includes a set of short-term economic forecasts which track prospects in member countries for a range of indicators. Could the minister inform the senate of the OECD's forecasts and analysis? In particular, how does Australia's economic performance compare with other OECD economies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Foreman for giving me a chance to put the OECD report accurately before the Senate. The OECD's latest six monthly economic outlook was released in Paris last night. It reviews economic performance and policies in the OECD member countries, including Australia, and contains the OECD secretariat's forecasts for 1995 and 1996.

PARA.TAB: The OECD considers that the economic situation in most member countries remains good, although the OECD is now projecting a marginally lower recovery in the OECD region than expected six months ago. I would like to focus, though, on the economic outlook as it relates to the Australian economy.

First, it should be noted that the OECD forecasts are consistent with the budget forecasts. The former are on a calendar year basis while our budget is based, of course, on the Australian financial year. Real GDP growth estimates for 1995 and 1996 are 3.8 per cent and 3.5 per cent respectively. This is above expected growth of the total OECD, which is 2.7 per cent for both years. So Australia is enjoying among the highest growth rates in the OECD.

As for employment, in 1994 Australia's employment creation was more than three times stronger than the employment growth achieved by the whole OECD. For 1995 and 1996 employment growth is expected to be more than twice as fast in Australia as in the OECD as a whole. That means 225,000 new jobs in 1995—almost the number John Howard achieved over five years—five very long years!

Yesterday I talked about the strength of business investment in Australia. The international comparisons make that performance look even more outstanding. The actual outcomes for 1994 show that Australia's business investment grew by 17 per cent compared to the OECD average of 5.2 per cent. In 1995 the forecast for Australia is for 14 per cent growth compared to the OECD forecast average of 9.1 per cent.

I note that some commentators today have picked up on the implications of strong output, employment and inflation growth for inflation. It is worth setting out what the OECD `s actual analysis was. The report states:

ANSWER.PARA: An important factor underpinning the high growth in domestic demand during the past year has been the strength of business investment, which grew by around 17 per cent in 1994 and was fuelled by high and rising rates of capacity utilisation and improved balance sheet positions.
The analysis then points out that strong growth has reduced spare capacity in the economy and there is considerable uncertainty about how much spare capacity now remains. It then says:
As spare capacity of both capital and labour is used up, continued strong growth would tend to create inflationary pressures.

But—and this is the critical point—the report acknowledges that the government and the Reserve Bank have acted to forestall the risk of overheating by tightening monetary policy and by delivering a significant improvement in the budget balance.

PARA.TAB: The government believes there is still considerable extra supply capacity in the economy and that micro-economic reform has increased the efficiency of current capital. The import figures yesterday point to continuing import of capital equipment which is continuing to expand our capital capacity. On the human resources side, the government has implemented an unprecedented program of skill development in Working Nation which is actively adding to the supply of skilled labour in the economy. So I think we can say that in the proper context, set against the rest of the peer group economies to which we compare ourselves, the Australian economy is performing better than most.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. It is another OECD outlook question. I want to concentrate on the shameless `shift the blame to the Senate' campaign with respect to interest rate rises that you and the Treasurer are indulging in and ask: didn't yesterday's OECD outlook warn that, in fact, it is persistently high current accounts which will lead to persistently high long-term interest rates? Based on your last answer, do you agree that the higher inflation predicted by the survey for next year will also lead to higher interest rates? Don't we already have the highest interest rates in the OECD because of the government's failure to address recurring current account problems over the last 10 years? Really, any interest rate rises sit fairly and squarely at the government's feet, don't they?
