—Let me take the last point first. I have here a copy of the OECD report, which contains a table showing the interest rates of the 25 OECD member countries. I commend it to you, Senator Kernot, and to the opposition. We do not have the highest interest rates in the OECD. That is exhibit 1, as proof of that. The OECD suggests some further tightening of monetary policy may be needed because the OECD's estimate of the output gap suggests that little or no slack remains in the economy. With unemployment at about 8 1/2 per cent and continuing solid investment growth, the government believes there is considerable extra supply capacity in the economy.

PARA.TAB: The OECD's output gap measure, like other static measures of excess capacity, also does not take account of the dynamic influences which can affect the amount of spare capacity in the economy. For example, in Australia a decade of micro-economic reform has improved the way in which we use labour and capital resources and therefore the responsiveness with which the supply capacity in the economy can respond to increasing demand.

Nevertheless, the government and the Reserve Bank remain ready to act decisively if necessary to address excessive inflationary pressures as growth continues. Monetary policy is not set in a mechanical way in response to any one indicator such as capacity utilisation. The Reserve Bank and the government set monetary policy in a forward looking way, taking into account a wide range of indicators of future inflationary pressures. The government has been very successful in reducing inflation and business and consumer inflation expectations from the high levels seen over the past two decades.

The underlying inflation rate of 1.9 per cent through the year to the March quarter 1995 continues to show there is a lack of generalised inflationary pressures in the economy. Monetary policy will remain on guard to ensure that any future rise in inflationary pressures does not become entrenched in rising inflationary expectations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now, could you answer the question?
—No, I have answered the question in terms of what the OECD's scenarios for future projected inflationary pressures in the Australian economy are. It relates to the capacity utilisation factor.

PARA.TAB: So in snapshot, let me conclude by saying that we do not accept necessarily that view of the OECD because it does not take account of the extra facility and the extra efficiencies with which we utilise the resources we have by virtue of the micro-economic reform and the labour market reform programs in which we have engaged. If you go from that point, I think you will agree, Senator Kernot, that the rest of your question falls to the ground. Having corrected the last part of it, on the question of interest rates, the whole of the question, with the greatest respect to you, should fall to the ground as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. No, I do not agree, minister. I ask you again—
—But you are still being irresponsible, whatever you say.

—No, you are wrong, Senator McMullan. I ask the minister: what is likely to have a greater effect on interest rates—and I ask you to look at what happened to the markets on the day of the announcement of the denial of the building tax increase and what happened yesterday with the current account figures—a $27 billion-plus current account deficit or the denial of a tax which affects one-sixth of one per cent of Commonwealth revenues?

—Mr President, this question is probably out of order because the tax is on the Notice Paper. Let me answer it by saying that what the market which deals with interest rates is pleased to see is a government which has moved its budget into surplus, which has a medium-term national savings plan and which is addressing these problems. What you are trying to do is cover yourself with an alibi that you will not be responsible if you remove the downward pressure on interest rates placed on interest rates by our budget. If you interfere with the budget, wreck the budget, remove that downward pressure on interest rates, I have to tell you, Senator Kernot, that you and John Howard will both be responsible for an interest rate rise on Australian home loans. That is what you will be responsible for. No amount of alibis by you will escape that fact. According to the principles of the OECD in its report, this budget has in place the right mechanisms to reduce that pressure.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. I note that the Prime Minister today launched in Sydney the government's major trade policy to the year 2000 known as Winning markets: Australia's future in the global economy. What are the major initiatives announced in Winning markets? How will they benefit Australia and Australian businesses?

—I am very pleased that the Prime Minister chose to launch Winning markets today, because his support for the priority of this policy is a clear indication to the Australian public and the Australian business community of how important this policy is and the priority that Australia gives to the question of trade policy. I do not pretend that trade policy will by itself be a medium-term strategy to resolve the current account deficit. It needs the other three elements that Senator Cook related to: the macro policy, micro policy and industry policy elements. Those four elements need to come together. This is an important fourth element. Therefore, I am very pleased that it has come out today.

PARA.TAB: This is a key element of dealing with the current account deficit in the medium term. People prattle about it, but those who think about it know that the decisions which affect the status of next year's current account deficit to a great extent have already been made. These things change very slowly, and necessarily so. Taking new investment on stream takes a long time. The import replacement proposals take a long time, as do changes in demand. A lot of the capital equipment that will come in next year has already been ordered. So the flows of imports and exports will not be changed dramatically over the next 12 months. Over the rest of this decade there is a chance to make a substantial change to it. Winning markets is designed to be a part of that. Therefore, we launched the broad strategic framework of Winning markets, which I spoke about on Friday and which the Prime Minister spoke about at length today.

I would like to talk about some of the more particular short-term initiatives to help Australian businesses succeed in their international efforts. For example, there is the proposal of Austrade to enhance and streamline its client service policy. The private sector continues to tell me that it believes the reformed Austrade is a great asset to it in its export capacity. In fact, many opposition as well as government senators who travel overseas come back with positive reports about the role of Austrade in the posts which they visit. That is correct. We are trying to improve the services that we supply and make better use of taxpayers' money. We want to target it particularly to the new and potential exporters and the small and medium enterprises that we are trying to attract into export.

A second area is that of the air freight inquiry. One thing that struck me much more than I expected in the business consultations we had in the lead-up to Winning markets was the extent to which small business, particularly in the outlying states—Tasmania and Western Australia—but also in Victoria and Queensland, raised a concern about the problems of the supply of air freight; that it was not available reliably and at a competitive price. With the changing pattern of Australian exports and the capacity to export into niche markets, particularly in overnight products like fresh foods, et cetera, air freight becomes particularly important.

We have asked for an inquiry—there will be one—into air freight. We want to know whether there are any systemic deficiencies in the supply of it—for example, whether the way that passenger air services are regulated is contributing in some way to the supply problems in air freight. That is an important initiative that will be welcomed by many in small business. They are particularly concerned. There is a proposal for an export barriers reporting scheme, which many businesses asked us for.
In the time available, I also refer to the proposed new chair and centre for the practice of international trade and trade policy. (Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer to Attorney-General Lavarch's commitment to fund Ms Carmen Lawrence's costs of challenging the validity of the Western Australian royal commission into the Penny Easton tragedy. As the royal commission is inquiring into an incident prior—I repeat the word `prior'—to Dr Lawrence's becoming a member of federal parliament, let alone a minister, is there any precedent for funding on this basis? Given that Dr Lawrence said that she was prepared to take this matter as far as the High Court at the possible cost of hundreds of thousands of Australian taxpayer dollars, has any limit been placed on how much the Commonwealth is prepared to spend? If so, how much is it?

—I think I have already given an answer to this question to Senator Vanstone. The point I was making then was that this inquiry is nothing but a political manoeuvre. That has been recognised not only by this side of parliament but also by the Deputy Premier of Western Australia. It is a political manoeuvre, and it is geared to target a Commonwealth minister. Because of that, the federal government has made a decision to assist with legal aid in relation to the inquiry. At the same time as that, it throws up a number of issues of constitutional importance.
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order on relevance. The question was: is there any—
—Don't you like the answer; have a lot of trouble with the answer?

—I think the Left ought to keep quiet for a few days—job-sharing and all of that. Is there any precedent for funding a federal minister when these events related to circumstances before she became a member of the federal parliament? That was the first question. The second question was: has the Commonwealth government capped the funding that it is making available to Minister Lawrence in this matter? They were the two simple specific questions that were asked. There has not been any attempt to answer them.

—Mr President, on the point of order: I have had 45 seconds to get to the answer. Secondly, the question is based on the inquiry as to why we are providing funds, legal assistance, in this particular matter. I am addressing that. If you cannot cop the answer, Senator Hill, don't write the questions for your lackeys on the back bench. I am going to give you a full answer, and the full answer goes to why the federal government is involved; on what grounds, both the political as well as the constitutional; and why, in fact, there are precedents for federal ministers to get involved in matters when federal laws are not directly involved. There are those sorts of precedents involved. You cannot raise questions about the federal government's involvement in funding this particular course of action without expecting to get a full answer, and that is what I am giving. Give me more than 45 seconds to get to it, will you.

—Mr President, on the point of order: Senator Bolkus stands condemned out of his own mouth. This is not a question about why the federal government is involved. It is not a question about the political manoeuverings, as he expressed it, that led up to the establishment of the royal commission. It is a very simple question—it has two prongs to it. You ought to be able to clearly distinguish between what he is trying to do and what he ought to do. He is being asked how much, and he is being asked about precedents for funding when the matter did not arise in relation to federal duties. They are very specific and narrow matters. That is no licence at all to go off and talk about why they have gone down this track, and you ought to direct him to answer those questions.
—They are matters which the minister just said he was about to answer. He is 40 seconds into his answer, as he has just said.

—Because the matter does raise issues of importance to the federal government structure, and because the matter is one that targets a Commonwealth minister, the government has decided to give assistance in relation to the inquiry—not only in terms of representation before it but also in relation to the inquiry. In terms of the amount, I will take that question to the Attorney-General to see whether anything has been contemplated in that respect, but my understanding is that when assistance is given in these sorts of actions it is for a purpose rather than an amount. The costs are, at the end of the day, taxed.

PARA.TAB: Commonwealth attorneys-general from time to time have always got involved in matters that raise questions of constitutional importance. In fact, it was only in 1993 that the federal government got involved in the matter of Stephens and Theophanous, which dealt with whether the defamation laws of a state were subject to an implied constitutional right of political speech. They were matters arising from state law. There have been other matters before; there have been other matters since.

What is involved here is very much about the issues of cabinet confidentiality and separation of powers. A whole process of government is, in a sense, being inspected by this royal commission. If you, Senator Panizza, are concerned about costs, let me remind you of one way that this matter could very easily be put to an end with the taxpayer being satisfied; that is, for you to talk to your colleagues in Western Australia—whom you are aiding and abetting in this political exercise—and remind them of what Hendy Cowan, the Deputy Premier of Western Australia, said on the Sunday program. He said that the National Party—
Senator Panizza interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You were talking about costs; you'll get a bloody answer on costs.
—Order!

—Mr President, I take a point of order. It seems to me that the minister has sunk so low he's about to embark on tedious repetition. We have already had this quote once. The question has nothing at all to do with what Hendy Cowan said. Mr President, I thought you said that he was about to get to answering the question. He rabbited on about some other court case, which had nothing to do with the precedent for getting involved over someone's actions as a state member of parliament, and he has said nothing at all about the ultimate cost. We want to know if it is going to cost hundreds of thousands of dollars. That is the issue. It has nothing to do with any of this other nonsense.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—On the point of order—
—I have just said there is no point of order.
—Mr President, on a point of order: I think that you ought to—
—Oh, do you now!
—Yes, I do, actually, but you do not know yet what I think. I think the language was inappropriate for this place.
—Oh, rubbish!
—Well, he is not at a meeting of the Left.
—Order! The point of order was not about language.
—He is not at a meeting of the Left. I am inviting you, Mr President, to suggest to the minister that he use language appropriate to this place and—
—You're kidding, aren't you!
—You think that is appropriate language in here, do you? You think this is a meeting of the Left. It is not. It is a national parliament and he ought to act accordingly, and you ought to tell him to.

—On the point of order, in some ways I agree with the substance of Senator Hill's point of order. I heard Senator Bolkus withdraw, and I am sure he will repeat that. It is just the double standards. With the language that has been coming from the other side today, for them to jump up and take these points of order, it is hypocrisy at its highest point.

—On the point of order, Mr President: it seems to have escaped some members of the other side—I only mention it just in case it has escaped your attention—that you were not in fact called a poonce. A proposition—

PARA.TAB: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you like to hold on? Tap it down there, sweetheart!
—Order! Why don't you take it up with me later.

PARA.TAB: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Vanstone, on the point of order—if you think it is really necessary. Don't you think you could tell me outside?

—No, because I think it is relevant to this particular point of order. You were not in fact called a poonce. A proposition was put to you that, if you chose to follow a certain course of behaviour, you may so be judged but that the proper thing for you to do was to choose the other course of behaviour, in which case you clearly would not be judged a poonce. I am pleased to say that you chose the appropriate course of behaviour. I just remind the other side, since they are obviously not up on the Queen's English, that you were not in fact called a poonce, whereas in this case you have a minister of the Crown saying, `If you want a bloody question about this, you'll get that bloody answer.' Now, that is inappropriate language.

—Order! Thank you very much for very little, Senator Vanstone. On the question of the point of order, I was not asked to rule on language but I do think that language is inappropriate, just as I have thought that language used on this side many times is inappropriate, and I have said so occasionally. I do not always say so, otherwise question time would never get on. I understand that Senator Bolkus has already withdrawn in any case.

—Thank you, Mr President. The question went to whether there is a precedent. The answer is: the Attorney-General regularly intervenes in cases which involve significant constitutional issues. That is the answer to your question. In respect to costs, I have already given you that answer but I will give you a supplementary answer in respect to costs, which is just as critical.

PARA.TAB: We could save the taxpayer a lot of money if we took Hendy Cowan's advice, and that is: the National Party does not believe taxpayers should pay for what is essentially an inquiry to achieve a political outcome. That is a view the federal government agrees with on this matter, Senator Panizza. You can go back and tell the cowboys in the Western Australian government that they ought to disembark on this process and save the taxpayer a lot of money.

All we are doing here is embarking on a political exercise—with some fairly lethal constitutional issues involved in it—at the taxpayers' expense, to satisfy the political imperatives of Mr Court in Western Australia. He has done it once before, you know, on the Mabo legislation and got wiped. He was clean bowled on that one—at the taxpayers' expense. Total disregard for taxpayers' money at the Western Australian end is something we should be concerned about and something we will continue to be concerned about, especially if it has constitutional implications.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. However, before I ask the supplementary I wish to tell Senator Bolkus that I am no-one's lackey and I wrote the question myself.
—Order! You will just ask the supplementary.

—Will this decision to fund Dr Lawrence's court case establish a precedent which will allow any federal MP—including Senator Bolkus, me or any backbencher—to have legal costs met for matters occurring prior to his or her election to the federal parliament; and if not, why not?

—The concise answer here is that if Carmen Lawrence was not a member of the federal government there would be no way that this inquiry would be continued. Secondly, if there were no constitutional issues raised, matters like this would probably not have given Mr Court the footing on which to base this inquiry. I say to Senator Panizza once again: listen to the words of Hendy Cowan, the deputy premier of Western Australia, when he says that this is an exercise in politics and for that reason the inquiry should be damned before it starts. So it is damned, but the federal government will protect the interests of federal ministers in constitutional imperatives in this matter and that is why we are involved.

—My question is directed to the minister representing the Treasurer. The government's own Economic Planning Advisory Committee has stated that `labour shedding' has been important in generating improved productivity in public utilities. EPAC has also stated that these productivity gains have been `passed on to government' in the form of increased dividends. I ask: why should the government think that consumers should be grateful for micro-economic reform if it means that they do not get the productivity gains? How are families better off if they do not get big cuts in charges and have to pay more tax to support those thrown out of jobs?

—I understand where Senator Harradine is coming from in his concern for people who may have been in government employment but who are now outside of government employment. The obligation on a government is to deliver the public services that it provides to the community and the defence services that it provides to the nation at the cheapest and most efficient cost. That means that with increasing access to new technology and more efficient ways of managing change there is downward pressure on employment numbers in the Commonwealth. That is appropriate because Australian taxpayers clearly do not want to pay for inefficient government delivery of services and inefficient provision of programs.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, this Commonwealth government has always been concerned at finding the most productive way of delivering those services. I will check these figures because I want to be absolutely sure in giving Senator Harradine an answer, but as I understand it in terms of the Commonwealth public service the result has been not to put people out of work but, rather, to not to fill positions when they become vacant and thus shrink the size of the public sector in comparison with that of the rest of the economy.

Having said that, I have to say that in some areas of state government operations people have been put directly out of work in a way which raises questions about proper management of industrial relations procedures and proper handling of redundancy arrangements. In some cases this has been done under a quite nebulous guise which is not, in the view of this Commonwealth government, the most efficient way to go about delivering those services. I will look at Senator Harradine's question again in the Hansard, but the essential point is that we have a fundamental obligation to deliver high quality services at the least possible cost and ensure that the Australian public sector is in fact an efficient deliverer of those services.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could the minister in his response also attend to the other question that the productivity gains have been, as EPAC says, passed on to government and presumably not to consumers? Could the minister have a look at that and come back to me?

—I certainly will have a look at that question. As I recall, EPAC was saying that the gains reaped by greater efficiencies in government business enterprises and in other sectors of the delivery of government services created productivity gains overall. Of course, they come through in the form of less pressure on taxation, or less pressure on fiscal measures and less pressure on the budget in terms of deficits. I will take on board your question and I will give you a fuller answer when I have consulted the Treasurer on what you have put forward.

—My question is also directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. On 31 May you told the Senate that the budget framework puts pressure to lower interest rates. On 14 June the Reserve Bank Governor, Bernie Fraser, indicated in a speech in London that rate reductions were not imminent and that the inflationary pressures of a weak dollar were cause for concern. You also stated that under the last Liberal government Australia `had higher rates on average' than under the Hawke and Keating Labor governments. In fact, average real interest rates under Labor have been 8.8 per cent—more than double those under the previous Liberal government—and Australians do pay amongst the highest real interest rates in the OECD. Since you did not table your OECD report, I seek leave to table page 111 of last week's edition of the Economist which will show that that is the case.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you mislead the Senate about the government's abysmal record on interest rates?

—Of course I did not. I, too, read the speech delivered in London by the Governor of the Reserve Bank, Bernie Fraser. It is the sort of speech that a prudent, sober and responsible governor of the Reserve Bank should make. It is the interpretations of his words that have created the problem, not what he said. I suggest that you actually go and read what he said.

PARA.TAB: Surprisingly, I saw one headline in a reputable national paper which sort of suggested that he had said `upward pressure on interest rates'. If you actually look at what he said, you will see that that is not what he said at all. While the headline blared that, the body of the article did not actually report that and the specialist commentary in a box in italics alongside that article by the economics writer did not support it either. So one has to be very careful to actually read exactly what he says and understand the gravity of his meaning. He conducts himself, in my view, with all the sobriety, responsibility and proper balance of conservatism that a governor of the Reserve Bank should do.

The reason why I have not tabled the report is that my copy is the only one I have. But it is on the public record and you can look up those tables. I am sure the library will provide them to you. You will see that Australia does not have the highest real interest rates in the OECD—something that the opposition has been parroting as a slogan in order to try to get into public consciousness something which is fundamentally not true. Just look at the tables. The tables show—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is so true.

—It is not true. Senator Short, you ought to know better because you at least have some training in this field and know how to read these tables. So don't you debase your professional qualifications by misrepresenting what the OECD report says.

PARA.TAB: The other issue at contest in this question seems to be about the comparison between the last period of conservative government and its record on interest rates and this current period of government under Labor and our record on interest rates. It just so happens that I have some figures of comparison here. Comparing the coalition to the government, when Mr Howard, who was Treasurer for most of the period of the Fraser government, left office, the bank housing loan rate was at 12.5 per cent. What is the current bank housing loan rate? It is 10.5 per cent. How do we compare with the coalition? A damn sight better!

When Howard left office, building society loans were 13.9 per cent. The current rate is 10.5 per cent. The bank housing loan rate was 13.5 per cent and 14.8 per cent. The current rate is 10.5 per cent. So, in the housing sector, you cannot make the case.

When Mr Howard as Treasurer left office, the official interest rate was 9.9 per cent. The current official interest rate is 7.45 per cent. Let us have a look at the 90-day bank bill rates. When Howard left office, the 90-day bank bill rate was 15.9 per cent. The current 90-day bank bill rate is 7.65 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shouldn't it be `Mr Howard', Mr President?
—It should be `Mr Howard'.

—Mr President, on a point of order: I presume `Cook' was referring to `Mr Howard'. The question was about real interest rates—a very simple proposition. We have now had almost three minutes of talk about everything but. You ought to at least direct him to answer that part of it.

—Mr President, on the point of order: the very important point that Senator Cook was making that I think the voters and the listeners want to know is what rates people are actually paying for buying a house. And that is exactly what he was giving and that is why they did not like it. That is why the `pain barometer' went up—because he was being hurt.

—Mr President, on the point of order: Senator McMullan simply exacerbates the wrong. The question was on real interest rates. Senator Cook may want to give those other figures out and he is entitled to do that any time he likes but not in answer to a question on real interest rates. You should direct him to answer the question on real interest rates, not on other interest rates that he may want to quote at some other time.

—I have told you many times before that, on the question of relevance, I can only judge in terms of the general relevance of the answer. I cannot judge the accuracy of specific answers in areas I am not expert in. On the question of language, I do think it is appropriate that you refer to Mr Howard as Mr Howard.
—I correct myself: I refer to him as Mr Howard. I certainly would not want people to misunderstand who it is I am talking about—the Leader of the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: When Mr Howard was Treasurer and left office, the prime rate was 15.75 per cent. The current prime interest rate is 10.7 per cent. One could go on, but it seems to me that that is a fair representation of how effective interest rates apply in Australia and the comparison is, indeed, an entirely unflattering one for the opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I did read what Bernie, the Reserve Bank Governor said.
—Mr Fraser.

—Mr Fraser, and I read it very carefully. But I also read, Minister, what you said in the Senate. You said average interest rates were higher under the former Liberal government than they have been under your government. The reality is that they are twice as high under your government in real terms and in nominal terms they are also marginally higher under your government. Will you now tell me why you mislead the Senate?

—On the first point, if you did read what the Governor of the Reserve Bank, Mr Fraser, said, I do not think you would have phrased the first part of your question in the way that you did. But, on the second part, I have given the fairest comparison between your performance as a coalition in government and our performance in government. On that comparison, let me say: game, set and match to us.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Mr President, under the 30-day rule contained in procedural order No. 15, I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator McMullan, for an explanation of why I have not received an answer to question No. 2123 which I put on notice on 1 May 1995 concerning the Ministerial Media Group and the National Media Liaison Service. That answer is now becoming urgent, given the supplementary estimates that we are about to face.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The only advice I have on this matter is what I had discussed with Senator Abetz before and relates to the resources and time required to compile this very complex answer. I do not have any further information to my previous discussion, but I will see whether there is anything I can do to ensure that the information is available before the estimates hearings and if I can get further information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: This question has been with the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) for some considerable period of time now. The minister refers to `complex questions'. They simply are not complex, they are not detailed and they are matters which ought to be available very easily.

PARA.TAB: The first question was: what is the name, designation, office location and remuneration of each member of staff for the Ministerial Media Group and the National Media Liaison Service as at 13 March 1995? I would have thought that at least that part of the answer could have been provided without any difficulty whatsoever. The second question was: which staff members are permanent public servants and what was each person's level prior to taking up their present position? I would not have thought that is exactly a complex question requiring a complex answer. I would have thought that the minister and the department would have been able to provide a response very quickly to that one as well.

The third question was: what is the entitlement of each staff member for telephone or car allowance, Commonwealth car for personal uses, and any other entitlements? I would have thought that that answer also would have been readily available to the department and to the minister. The fourth question I asked was: in relation to ex-ministerial staff members who have been employed with either the National Media Liaison Service or the Ministerial Media Group since January 1 1990, what was their name, ministerial designation, remuneration—including overtime allowances, Public Service status and termination payment received on termination of ministerial employment—and what was their designation, office location, remuneration, et cetera?

In pursuing the question of the National Media Liaison Service and the officers within that service—or propaganda unit for the government—we have already been advised that there have been only seven people who fit into the category of question No. 4, and their names have now been supplied to me. So the research for seven names of seven people has taken the government some considerable period of time. It is quite clear that each time the opposition asks any questions whatsoever about the National Media Liaison Service, the government seeks to delay and seeks to obfuscate and is most anxious that the truth is not obtained.

Senator Kemp, the shadow minister for administrative services, has pursued similar questions and has received answers which indicate that answers given to us at estimates committees have not been as truthful as one may have wished or hoped—or demanded, given that the answers have been given through the parliament to the people of Australia. This is another example of the tardiness of this government, or its deliberate obfuscation, in relation to the National Media Liaison Service, and it is to be condemned for that.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), to a question asked by Senator Hill this day, relating to an Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development report concerning the Australian economy.

SPEECH.PARA: I asked the minister why it is that, after 13 years of Labor government, Australia has the worst current account performance in the Western world. Firstly, the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) started to talk about the future and said, `We are taking steps to remedy the situation,' which rather avoids the fact that his government has been there for near enough 13 years and is responsible for that situation. So there was no attempt to explain how the economy could be in such a poor state under its control.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, Senator Cook blamed the opposition. In some way it was our fault, even though we had been out of government for about 13 years. This issue is critical because the Australian people have every right to judge the government on its performance over such a long period of time. The sad fact is that, when we look at these very serious aspects of the Australian economy, we see that the government's performance has been dismal. We had an estimate in the budget of a $27 billion deficit for next year, on top of a $27 billion deficit for this year. With a current account running at that level, the government will have no alternative but to keep the value of the dollar up. To do that, it will have to keep interest rates up. Whereas they might drop in the short term because of the crash in the housing market, in the longer term there is no other alternative under this set of economic policies than a result of high interest rates. That will be the continuing record of this government.

As was pointed out in a subsequent question, real interest rates under this government are among the highest in the Western world. Its record of real interest rates is double that of our government's record when last in office. So it is a high interest rate government. The consequence of high interest rates is that it makes it more and more difficult for Australian business to be profitable or to be competitive. That is starting to show up in the OECD report already. We are now seeing a forecast of reducing growth.

This government told us that to reduce unemployment—and there are still over three-quarters of a million Australians out of work under this government—it would need growth of at least 4.5 per cent a year. In its own budget this year the government forecast growth coming down to 3.75 per cent. When we look at this OECD report, confirmed by the Treasurer, we see that the OECD is now talking about growth of 3.5 per cent. Under this government we have high interest rates, business which is less profitable, growth which is starting to fall and, sadly, later this year, with no alternative to these policies, unemployment which will start to rise again.

The boom-bust cycle that we have under Labor reminds me of what Professor Sloan warned us of some time ago; that is, as we move through each cycle of recession, when we start moving into the next downturn, we start with an unemployment level much higher than it was at the same point in the last cycle. Sadly, in this instance we are starting in that part of the cycle with over three-quarters of a million Australians still out of work. That is the record of this Labor government.

To make it worse, the OECD report tells us that inflation is starting to rise again. All the ingredients are there for a deteriorating economic position later this year. Interest rates are rising as a result of these unsustainable current account deficits, inflation is starting to rise, profitability is starting to fall and unemployment is sadly again on the rise. That is the record upon which this government will be judged at the next election, and it is an appalling record. The Australian people will have every right on that performance to throw the government out of office.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Hill's comments in response to that incredible non-answer by Senator Cook today to the question from Senator Hill. Senator Cook's answer to the dorothy dixer from Senator Foreman was just as bad—even though he was reading from a bit of paper—as the response to Senator Hill.

PARA.TAB: The simple fact is that in 13 years of government the Labor Party has done nothing at all to break the vicious cycle of boom-bust that has so restricted the opportunity for growth and better living standards in this country. The reasons it has not done it are manifold. You just have to look at the symptoms of them.

Even today, five years after the onset of the induced recession by then Treasurer Keating—the recession we all say in the popular language of today that Mr Keating said we had to have—we should never let Australians forget that it was the recession that we should never have had to have. The only reason we had that recession was the gross incompetence and mismanagement of the government, of which Mr Keating was the prime economic architect. He was the self-adulatory puller of the levers, the person who had the Treasury and the Reserve Bank in his pocket and the person who said that leadership in Australia was all about having these people in his pocket and pulling levers. He did all of that; he self-admitted it.

The tragedy today is that five years after the Treasurer pulled those levers in 1990 the number of people in full-time employment in Australia is still less than it was when those levers were first pulled. For half a decade there has been great tragedy and hardship thrust upon the Australian people because of lack of work. We still have not returned to the time when we had full-time employment a long and hard five years ago. We have had pain, pain, pain and no gain.

The situation, as Senator Hill said, is worse than it was when this government came to office in terms of the starting point for the recovery and the putting of the economy right that is so essential. Unemployment is one, but the other killer—it reflects on our lack of competitiveness—is the foreign debt. We have a situation today where we are still as uncompetitive as we were a decade ago but we have a foreign debt level seven or eight times what it was then. We have a situation where the current account deficit is six per cent of GDP. That is the same level as it was when Mr Keating made his infamous banana republic statement at almost this time in 1986. In that time nothing at all has been done to solve the critical restraining problem that we have in terms of the growth potential of this economy.

There is an enormous amount that should have been done by proper government policies. As a result of them not happening, we now have—regardless of what Senator Cook tries to thrust down our throats—virtually the highest real interest rates in the world. I am not sure that Senator Cook knows what real interest rates mean, but we do have the highest real interest rates in the world, we have the highest foreign debt in the world and we have every problem and prospect of inflationary pressures, balance of payments pressures and falling exchange rates putting more pressure on interest rates, upward interest rates, recessed growth, back to the old cycle of rising unemployment and a great loss of opportunity to capitalise on the great potential that we have in this country. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus), to a question without notice asked by Senator Panizza this day, relating to Government funding of legal action involving federal ministers.

SPEECH.PARA: I asked a very simple question at question time today. My basic question was: was there ever a precedent for the federal government to fund a federal minister—or a member for that matter, but in this case I refer to a federal minister—to commence an action to challenge the validity of the WA royal commission into the tragic Penny Easton affair, where we lost a very innocent life?

PARA.TAB: I am not talking about something that happened to ministers, members or senators while in this place; it was a prior event. What did I get when I asked the question? I got total abuse. That is the old trick. People do it now and again in this place and elsewhere when they do not have an answer: they start abusing the questioner. That was the only defence Senator Bolkus had today; he abused me because I asked the question. I point out to Senator Bolkus, in his absence—in case he and other members of this chamber did not hear me when I told him this in question time—that I am no-one's lackey. He said today in an interjection about me that Senator Hill was writing questions for his lackey.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—You can laugh as much as you like, Senator McKiernan. I will get back to you in a minute. I point out that I am no-one's lackey and that every question I have asked in this place and every speech I have delivered in this place I have written myself. If Senator Bolkus and Senator Faulkner want to call me a liar, let them come outside cowards' castle—as Senator Ray is always inviting us to do—where we can do something about it. I make that challenge right now.

PARA.TAB: The only defence Senator Bolkus could use, apart from abuse, was Hendy Cowan's statement, a statement he was supposed to have made at some time, that this inquiry was a total waste of time. All I say to Senator Bolkus and everyone else in this chamber is that I know Mr Hendy Cowan far better than Senator Bolkus and maybe anyone else on this side of the chamber will ever know him. As I think most people in this chamber know, I used to belong to the National Party. I will let the matter of Mr Hendy Cowan's actions rest there.

I asked what I think is a legitimate question: is there going to be an upper limit on costs? That ceiling can be put on any time, here or in private enterprise. People want to know what they are up for. All Senator Bolkus could do was give us Hendy Cowan's solution. That was a waste of time.

I will give a good solution that will cut down on time, cut a lot of the costs to the federal government, which is funding Dr Lawrence to commence this action, and cut the costs of the Western Australian state government which will be running a royal commission. I will give Senator Bolkus and both governments a solution: for Dr Carmen Lawrence to come clean on the matter and admit what she did. That is all she has to do. Mr Richard Court said that for well in excess of a fortnight before he called a royal commission. He asked her to come clean and she did not do so, so he went ahead. I say to you, Madam Deputy President, let her come clean on what action she took which cost the life of a very innocent woman who was far removed from politics, who had nothing to do with politics. We are in the cut and thrust of politics—

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. The comment that Senator Panizza has just made about the actions of a member of another place costing the life of somebody else is not only unparliamentary; it is disgraceful. I ask for it to be withdrawn.
—I do not believe that I have transgressed with anything I have said; and I don't intend to withdraw it.

—Madam Deputy President, I insist. A member of another place has been virtually accused of taking the life of another human being. I do not think that any standing orders of this place or of any parliament in this country would allow an accusation like that to stand. I ask you to rule that the comment made by Senator Panizza is out of order and should be withdrawn.
—Senator Panizza, it is not in order to make an imputation about a member of another place. I think it is necessary for you to make it clear that you are not doing that.

—I am not making any imputations about a member of another place. If you read the Hansard tomorrow, Madam Deputy President, you will see that I have not done that. I did not make an imputation. I merely said—and I will repeat it—that if Carmen Lawrence came clean on what Richard Court offered her, the matter would be finished tomorrow. It is as simple as that. (Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion. I think that there is a principle involved which is of wide application and concern to all senators, in fact to all members of parliament; that is, just how far the government of the day will go in assisting any member or senator in embarking on legal action which might involve the public interest. It seems to be on that basis that the government has made a commitment to undertake to meet Ms Lawrence's legal costs in challenging the validity of the Western Australian royal commission.

PARA.TAB: Senator Panizza made a valid point when he said that this was the funding of the commencement of proceedings. It is not as if Carmen Lawrence is being sued or charged in any way; quite the reverse. Senator Bolkus cited the case of Theophanous as a precedent where the government provided funding. That, too, involved a member of parliament taking action about statements that had been made about him in the press. That was an action of defamation. The government, according to Senator Bolkus, saw fit to underwrite those legal costs as well.

It is quite appropriate in these circumstances for the coalition opposition to question the government as to what guidelines are applied, by what process the government arrived at this decision to spend taxpayers' money in this manner. If there is a policy that ministers and members of parliament are funded in this way, then it should apply equally to members of the opposition and members of other parties. It is not a fund or principle or policy that applies only to ministers or government members; it is something which should apply universally. Therefore, the government should come clean and say, `In this instance we are funding Carmen Lawrence. We will also, in the appropriate circumstances, fund any member from the opposition or the minor parties who finds themselves in the same situation.' We did not get that answer from Senator Bolkus.

I put it to the Senate that this matter must have gone to cabinet. It must have been discussed and decided, and the opposition wants to know the position. Are you going to make a policy? Are you going to apply this evenhandedly across the board or is it only for government members that this course of action will be applied and only they will have the enjoyment of such subsidy in matters involving them? I think that is the more important question. It is a question of transparency. It is a question of how the government funds legal actions in these situations.

Really, it has little to do with the Penny Easton inquiry. Even if that inquiry was not justified, the government still has to turn its mind to how it is going to address the circumstances in which members of parliament find themselves in these situations. I might add that Carmen Lawrence was not a member of the other place when this whole matter arose. In fact, it was prior to her coming to federal parliament. That is something that I would like the government to address as well when applying this policy or these guidelines. Will it also fund instances where a member of parliament has to answer for something which he or she did prior to coming into parliament?

I think that is a valid question which Senator Panizza put to Senator Bolkus and which I do not think has been answered. In the public interest it must be answered. The taxpayers have a right to know in these instances how their money is going to be applied, how these decisions are going to be arrived at. As well, the Senate and the other place need to know just what the government will do in any given situation. That is the crucial aspect.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with much of what Senator Ellison said. I think there is considerable scope for people who are in parliament now and who are sued in a variety of circumstances to have the assistance of taxpayers' money in defending the position in which they are put. In other words, I think consideration should be given to assisting people who, because of their political work, are sued, and that should go right across the board. Of course, I am speaking for myself; I cannot speak for the government. But I agree entirely with what Senator Ellison said.

PARA.TAB: Senator Panizza has raised a very important point. Senator McKiernan took him up on a point which I do not think Senator Panizza intended to come out in the way it did. Where taxpayers' money goes to paying for a commission such as the Marks commission in Western Australia, where taxpayers' money goes to erecting a commission against a person who sits in this parliament, there is a good basis for this parliament replying to that by paying the costs of the person who is put in that position—in this case, the member for Fremantle, Dr Lawrence. But I agree with Senator Ellison that that principle should be applied across the chamber and should apply to every party. If a member of parliament—I have said this before, as has Senator Ellison—is put in this position, consideration ought to be given to paying the costs of that person.

I wish to say a few words in light of what Senator Panizza said. He said that Dr Lawrence should be frank about the matter. But the only answer that would satisfy him and Mr Court is for her to admit what she is accused by the government of doing. Of course, that is the whole point—she denies that position and it is for that reason that the royal commission has been set up. Why do Mr Court and Senator Panizza not accept what Dr Lawrence says? She says that there was nothing to this. Why does the Liberal Party in Western Australia, represented by Mr Court, not accept what Dr Lawrence says? Then you would not need to have this commission. The very fact that she has made this denial has led to this publicly funded commission.

If political action is taken against her which is publicly funded, why is it wrong for her to resist that with public funds? If Mr Court had financed this action himself, I would be the first to say that Dr Lawrence should finance her defence herself. But once a political action is taken which is publicly funded, then public funds should follow right through. That is consistent with what Senator Ellison said. So what I say is, yes, there is a lot of merit in what Senator Panizza says, but he must apply the principles that he has put forward not only to Dr Lawrence but to Mr Court. Let us be fair and consistent. We are not being consistent by giving public funds to a political prosecution and not giving public funds for a political defence.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to address this question. I will try to put into context in this debate what was said by Senator Bolkus today in answer to questions by both Senator Panizza and Senator Vanstone. Had the first question from Senator Vanstone been answered, I doubt whether we would be having this debate now. The fundamental problem is that he refused to answer her question as well Senator Panizza's question, which asked about the rules surrounding how this is being governed. It goes to the issue of funding an individual for a particular case or action prior to their coming into this place. Those guidelines were refused when Senator Bolkus gave his answer to those on this side of the chamber.

PARA.TAB: While it is claimed to be a political exercise, it must be remembered that, following the tabling of a petition by Mr John Halden, Penny Easton took her life. That is a very sad and disappointing occurrence. Following that and the debate that occurred through it—the debate was not always nice and palatable; these things are not nice and palatable—two senior ministers of the Lawrence government disputed what Dr Lawrence had said then and has said since about that aspect of it.

Senator Cooney says, `Why not accept the word of Dr Lawrence?'. It goes a lot deeper than accepting the word of Dr Lawrence. It also goes to what Mr Keith Wilson and Mrs Pam Beggs said about it. It also goes to the question of why so many of her senior ministers have remained silent on the issue.

The current leader of the Labor opposition in Western Australia, Mr McGinty, has said that it is a matter of cabinet confidentiality. When one starts talking about these issues—the death of a person, what has occurred behind it and what Mr Keith Wilson and Mrs Pam Beggs have said—it goes far beyond that. It is being used as a smokescreen.

As Senator Panizza quite rightly said, Dr Lawrence was given the opportunity to quite clearly document an answer to what has been claimed by others, including a Channel 7 reporter. The reporter talked about interference with a story that was to be published that day. She said that she had a much greater one. I do not know how much was discussed in cabinet—I do not think anybody in this room would know—but we know that there should have been a proper process for which she was responsible in terms of bringing forward petitions of that nature and the way that they were tabled.

I reject totally the claim that this is just a political exercise. Unless this process is dealt with properly and we get to the bottom of it, it will remain forever a blight on the Western Australian parliament. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
