DEBATE.TITLE: MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1995FRINGE BENEFITS TAX AMENDMENT BILL 1995

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will continue my remarks on the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1995. I contend that this levy not only looks like a tax; it operates like a tax and has all the characteristics of a tax, other than the name given to it by this government. This levy takes money from the pockets of Australians to pay for a government program. It is a tax, and it is appropriate that it should be debated jointly with the Fringe Benefits Tax Amendment Bill 1995.

PARA.TAB: The government claimed that the Medicare tax was introduced to offset the government's expenditure on Medicare. Even from day one, this tax could not offset the cost of Medicare. In fact, it could not go anywhere near covering that cost. It still does not. I note from the budget papers that the levy is expected to bring in $3.6 billion next year—up $560 million from this current financial year. We should compare that with the total expenditure by the Commonwealth on health of $18.4 billion.

A former minister, Dr Blewett, claimed in 1983 that Medicare would be substantially self-funding through the one per cent levy. By August 1986, however, the government moved to increase the levy by 25 per cent to 1.25 per cent. At the time, it was claimed that this increase was the most equitable way of dealing with the increasing costs of the health system, even though the government also argued that the cost of health outlays had increased only in line with inflation.

We were therefore in a situation in 1986 of this Labor government continuing to urge the view that the Medicare system would be self-funded provided the rate at which we were required to contribute to the scheme via taxes was increased by 25 per cent. At that time we were again told there would be no need to increase the rate further. In fact, during the period 1983 to 1986, the community was told ad nauseam that there would be no need to raise the rate of the Medicare tax.

We all now know that the rate did go up again. In 1993, after the federal election, and after the people thought they were voting for a Medicare tax of 1.25 per cent, this government raised the tax to 1.4 per cent. We had heard all the denials before the election about this rate going up. Only under the coalition, it was said by the Labor Party, would health care costs increase. Fear and deception were the Labor Party's principles in February 1993.

Nevertheless, when the economic mismanagement of the government left the cupboard bare, it reached for the only fiscal lever the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, really understands. It increased taxes on the people of Australia. In the process, it raised the Medicare tax.

That was two years ago. Today, we are debating a bill that will see the Medicare tax increased again and, along with it, the rate of the fringe benefits tax. Not unexpectedly, and almost naturally, Australians have heard over the past 12 months the very highest acolytes of the Labor Party deny that there would need to be an increase in the Medicare tax. On 19 June last year, the recently installed Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence), with a passion, declared:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no proposal to increase the levy and there won't be.
And then, with a poisoned chalice for her Prime Minister, Dr Lawrence pledged:
Both the Prime Minister and myself have repeatedly ruled out any increase.
The statement was clear, the commitment unequivocal: no increase in the Medicare tax; no proposal; no need. An increase was repeatedly ruled out. Even a blind person could read this minister's lips.

PARA.TAB: What Australian's may have forgotten is that this was a pledge by a minister in the government of Paul Keating. As a consequence, this was a pledge made for and on behalf of the Prime Minister, Mr Keating. Sadly, as all Australians now know, any pledge, any promise, any commitment from Mr Keating is worth less than the Australian dollar, is as likely to occur as a French nuclear test ban, and is as valuable as shares in a Christopher Skase enterprise.

Why should the people of Australia be concerned about this decision? The Labor Party would say that this merely shows that the government is prepared to make the really hard decisions when it is necessary to do so. In fact, the government has not made any really hard decisions whatsoever. It has failed to address the fundamental instabilities in the health care system. It has failed to address its fiscal imbalance. It has failed to seriously cut expenditure through proper analysis of the priorities of the current expenditure programs.

The people of Australia should be under no illusions. In the lead-up to an election, this Labor government will never tell the Australian people what taxes it will raise if, unfortunately, it were to be re-elected. It will deceive. It will attack those who propose any alternative to its policies. It is autocratic and it does not countenance dissent. Quite simply, this government cannot be trusted.

The government holds no consistent position other than that which has short-term electoral appeal. The Prime Minister will say whatever he believes people want to hear. He is a human chameleon, changing minute to minute, appearing in all sorts of places around the country like a cardboard cut-out. Last week we saw him in Tasmania demonstrating his versatility: a softly spoken conservationist in the countryside near Hobart; a witless thespian in the city of Launceston; and a mealy-mouthed politician in the midst of his Labor Party comrades.

Let me make it clear: I have no problem with the Prime Minister behaving in this manner. He is a consummate and absolute politician. The Australian people can expect no less from this Prime Minister. At the same time, it is clear that the Australian people can expect no more from him.

Unfortunately, consummate and absolute politicians have let down the Australian people. Generally, Australians take their government at face value and seek to live their lives in accordance with the commitments provided by their government. Individual Australians borrow money and invest their savings in businesses and investments in the expectation that the government will fulfil its promises. They take risks with their lives and the financial security of their families and friends.

It is not only unfair but it is absolutely reprehensible that these courageous Australians should have their lives devastated by the glib and complacent decisions of this government. That is why the coalition opposes this tax grab. That is why the coalition argues that the Senate should take a stand now to require governments to abide by their commitments. The only guarantee in the reign of this government is that no matter what it says, no matter how firm its commitment, no matter how often the promise is repeated, the word of this government and the word of the current Prime Minister cannot be relied on. The coalition opposes these bills and urges all non-government senators to take a stand here and now to obtain responsible parliamentary government for Australia.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1995 which increases the Medicare levy from 1.4 per cent to 1.5 per cent as announced in the budget. I will explain why we are supporting the bill.

PARA.TAB: When the initial increase was announced we certainly had some misgivings, although the Australian Democrats have been calling for some time for an increase in the Medicare levy: indeed, a larger increase than we see now. We argued that a 0.2 per cent increase would have been about what was needed to make up for the shortfall in our public health system. However, when we initially looked at the government's proposed increase we were concerned that there was no clear indication from government as to exactly where this additional revenue was going. We wanted an assurance that it was going into the health budget. We wanted to make sure that it would not simply be syphoned off into a range of other programs.

As well as reading very carefully the budget documents which had lists of expenditure increases as well as considerable numbers of different bits and pieces of cuts, we decided to seek further clarification from the minister. We eventually received that clarification and, while we are not all that happy with the way in which the Medicare levy operates, it is clear that the increase is more than justified. I will shortly indicate why we believe that.

The Commonwealth government currently spends more than $17 billion on health each year. Roughly $7 billion of that is spent on medical services, the cost of which is increasing. About $5 billion is spent on hospital services. The Commonwealth has in fact been reducing the amount it forwards through to our public hospitals—as have many states. Australians are beginning to see the consequences of this. Some $2 billion goes on pharmaceuticals, and those bills are increasing as well. Some $2 billion goes to nursing homes and hostels. The coalition and the Democrats have been arguing that not enough is going into our nursing homes. We are seeing a situation where many nursing homes cannot even refurbish adequately.

A further $700 million is spent on other health services such as health research—and both the Democrats and the coalition have argued in this place that not enough is going into medical research—on AIDS programs, which no one would want to see cut; on immunisation which everybody agrees, and I note a recent speech by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, is not working in this country. We need to put greater effort into the immunisation program as well as our national drug program.

This represents a cost per head of population of around $950 a year. By 1999 the Commonwealth expects to be spending $21 billion on health care each year. The two biggest growth areas are going to be medical services and pharmaceutical services unless we make some substantial cuts in those areas. I am not sure that any political party is about selling those. We are seeing a drift to more expensive medical services and more expensive drugs. As we have an aging population, each of us is gradually using up more and more of the health dollars. Each of us is gradually seeing the medical practitioner just that extra day or so a year. It all adds up.

Our total health budget is now around $35 billion a year. The Commonwealth meets about 48 per cent of that; the states provide about 25 per cent; private health insurance contributes about 11 per cent; and individuals, via the extra out-of-pocket expenses that they have to meet, contribute 16 per cent. The Medicare levy currently raises around $3 billion per year. As has been noted, that is expected to rise to $3.6 billion. In the overall context, that is a pretty small contribution—about 17 per cent—to Commonwealth outlays on health. It is also a relatively small contribution—about 24 per cent—to the actual Medicare outlays themselves.

When we look at this year's budget, we see that the health outlays in 1995-96 are expected to grow by 3.1 per cent in real terms and a lower growth rate—about 1.8 per cent—is expected over the next four years. As this growth is equal to roughly $1 billion per year over the next four years, there is certainly some justification in the argument that the increase in the Medicare levy is not even fully covering the cost of natural growth within the health portfolio.

However, there are also significant funding reductions across the health portfolio over the next four years, including a $540 million reduction from changes to indexation arrangements, $54 million from a two per cent reduction in running costs and $100 million is planned to be gained from increasing the PBS threshold up to $600. Furthermore, real outlays for hospital services will decline in real terms by 0.7 of one per cent in 1995-96.

Some health organisations have argued that these reductions offset more than one half of the additional revenue raised by the increase in the levy. But the flip side of that argument is that there are also several new or additional programs planned in 1995-96. So, although the revenue from the levy increase goes into consolidated revenue, it is reasonable to argue that there is an overall increase of more than $4 billion in the health portfolio over the next four years, and this certainly more than covers the increase in the Medicare levy that we are talking about today. Therefore, in these circumstances, the Democrats believe it is reasonable to support the Medicare increase, as it will be going into the health portfolio.

In effect, although it is not spelt out anywhere, the increase is about ensuring that Medicare levy receipts make a greater contribution to the cost of the government's health programs. I have to say, however, that we remain far from satisfied with the way in which the Medicare levy actually works. As I said earlier, the levy falls a long way short of meeting the cost of publicly funded health care. In reality, irrespective of how the government likes to portray it, the Medicare levy really is very little more than a symbol rather than a substitute funding mechanism.

Mind you, I think some of the argument around this point is largely symbolic and semantic and I find it very annoying and a little pathetic that these issues are trotted out time and time again to oppose an increase in the levy. We could overcome these arguments and the problem of the levy not being hypothecated towards health costs by moving to spell out on the tax returns of all Australians exactly how much they are paying out each year through Commonwealth taxation for our public health system. To do that we would need to combine the Medicare levy with what is actually now being paid through general tax revenue and put the figure on the tax returns of all Australians. We can call this figure whatever we like. We can call it a levy. We can call it a public health insurance fee, a public health premium or whatever. I believe that Australians are entitled to see the actual contribution they are making to their health system.

When we consider what people get for their private health insurance premiums, and they average about $1,200 a year, many Australians would be pretty pleased to find out that they are paying less than $1,000 a year for access to what remains one of the best health systems in the world, as well as to all the other bits and pieces we talked about before—from medical research, to immunisation programs and through to all the other various things that this money goes to in the health budget.

We can see from recent surveys that satisfaction with Medicare is high. The community does support the system—a fact noted by the OECD's latest economic survey. It is also a fact which has not escaped the attention of the coalition. It is very pleasing to see that the coalition has made some attempts to pull back from its previous opposition to Medicare and from its plans to dismantle key elements of it, and that it is now basically in support of it. However, it is unfortunate, when it comes to the crunch, that the coalition still cannot accept the reality and the popularity of Medicare and therefore back appropriate funding of it.

Much of what Senator Gibson had to say about the fairness of the system was simply wrong. It is a far fairer system than relying on one where those who have the money to privately insure are able to jump queues and get a far better service than those that cannot.

At this point in time I really do have to ask the coalition what it is that they are actually planning. If we do not increase the levy, that will be $1 billion out of the health budget over the next four years. So how would the coalition cut that $1 billion out of the health budget? We have an aging population. We are all using more high-tech services. It is becoming essential, if we are to really look after the health of this country, to look at how we pay for services. So what programs will the coalition cut? How will they fund hospitals?

Should we be cutting age care programs? Will the coalition cut the level of reimbursement for medical practitioners—cut what GPs get or specialists, perhaps pathologists and radiologists? How are these cuts going to be made? Perhaps the coalition is expecting individual Australians to bear, on the basis of how healthy or how ill they are, most of their own expenses.

So I really ask the coalition: how can you claim to be fiscally responsible when you continue to oppose any revenue raising measure and then refuse to say how you will cut expenditure to match the lowering of the revenue base? Where will you cut services? What is more, the coalition continues to dodge the question of what it will do about private health insurance. It is one thing to argue the case again for the private system, to boost membership of private health insurance funds, but how will you do that?

The piece of legislation we had before us in this place only a few weeks ago was opposed by the coalition. So what method will you use?I am sure most Australians would like to know whether you are going to introduce tax deductions or tax rebates for private health insurance premiums. If you are, in the case of tax deductibility, where will the $1.4 billion to $2.9 billion come from out of the health budget?

If you are going to oppose this Medicare levy increase, then I really do think you owe it to Australians to say how you will deal with the issue of health financing. This is one area where it is simply not good enough to talk in generalities. It is an area where it is simply not good enough to oppose something just for the sake of opposing it. That does not mean to say that the Democrats do not see anything wrong with our public health system. Our many concerns are on the record—and I will go through just a couple of them, but I will not deal with all of them. We have other opportunities coming up in the next week.

On this occasion in particular, I believe that the Commonwealth government is neglecting its responsibilities to our public hospital system and that a very strong case can be made for specific targeting of increased funds into the public hospital system. The Commonwealth also needs to make a much better effort to prevent further state government expenditure slashing in the health area; in particular, in Victoria and South Australia. Far too many health programs, issues and services are falling between the cracks because of the state government cutbacks. We need to decide once and for all who is ultimately responsible for Australia's public health system.

The Democrats hold the view that if we want a decent health system, we are going to have to pay for it. The fairest way to pay for it is through the taxation system, a system based on one's income. That does not mean that the government of the day should not be alert to ways of reigning in health costs and becoming more efficient, and oblivious to ways of delivering more effective services. But, at the end of the day, if we want to make sure all Australians have access to a good standard of basic health care, then we have to pay for it through our tax system. As far as we are concerned, access to basic health care is a fundamental human right—a right that we have to all share in paying for through our universal system which guarantees that right. Access to quality health care should not be a privilege that you get only if you can afford to pay for it. That is not the Democrats' view of a just society.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating two bills cognately: the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1995 and the Fringe Benefits Tax Amendment Bill 1995. We have had two speakers in this debate. As I understand it, the opposition is opposed to these bills, but the Democrats support these bills. I have not heard anything from the Greens (WA) but I imagine they support the bills. Therefore, I hopefully predict that these two bills will carry the Senate. It is very appropriate that they do.

PARA.TAB: These bills are necessary to meet the government's economic strategy. They are budget bills in the sense that the changes proposed here were announced in the budget. We have had today during question time and, I am sure, in taking note of answers after question time, some debate about where Australia stands in the world in its economy, the direction of change and the nature of economic issues.

The OECD report, which has sparked this current spate of self-analysis, criticism and argument, shows that Australia has an economy which, measured against like economies elsewhere around the world—that is, among First World or developed nations—is strong in many respects. But the weakness in the economy, which the government has never sought to hide because the fact stands there openly and our setting in resolving difficulties is to be rational and logical about them, is the problems we have with the current account deficit.

This budget, as announced by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) on 9 May, has as its key theme putting the budget into surplus as well as a major key theme of developing a level of national savings, which is code or economic jargon for ensuring that Australians save more money than they spend. The method in the budget of doing this is, basically, through further superannuation contributions, which will mean that we will become a nation over time which borrows from itself rather than from the world and repays itself and, therefore, has a stronger internal economy. But the first element of our approach is, of course, to put the budget in surplus and that is a necessary housekeeping move. Not many similar developed economies in the world are in surplus; we are one of the few.

The OECD, in surveying the developed countries of the world, in essence is saying to us all that these steps are necessary. Without explicitly referring to us in general, although referring to us approvingly in particular when it comes to the country analysis for Australia, the OECD survey says that the fiscal tightening and the medium-term savings plan in which we have engaged are very positive steps that other countries, too, should engage in.

So when we turn to the fiscal tightening dimension, it is obvious that the government needs to go through, and has been through, a whole process of finding savings in its outlays, in its expenditure, which do not compromise its social justice goals, which work to ensure better program delivery, but which impose a lesser burden on taxpayers for the cost of government than otherwise would be the case. In that context, obviously, in a logical list of areas for examination, one would look at the Medicare levy. The proposal is that the rate will be increased to 1.5 per cent from 1.4 per cent and that the increase will be from 1 July 1995. The Medicare levy as it now stands only pays for 27 per cent of the cost of public health care in Australia. The rest is paid for by other means through government outlays.

But the Medicare levy only recoups 27 per cent of the cost of public health care. It is appropriate at a time when we need to exercise some budget stringency to look at a charge such as this and to have it bear a greater load than that, because the cost of public health has been escalating as people have been shifting out of private health care and relying more on Medicare. The increase in the Medicare levy will simply maintain the existing level of cost recovery. The increase in the Medicare levy will not affect single people earning up to about $13,000 and single income families with two children earning up to about $27,000.

Because we are making the adjustment to the Medicare levy, it is also appropriate for us to have regard to the fringe benefits tax because its settings have always been on the basis of the top marginal rate plus Medicare, so it is necessary to consequentially make a change to the fringe benefits tax. That is the measure that is before the Senate.

This is a very simple, almost one-line amending bill which affects one important component, but obviously many senators have chosen to use the vehicle of the Medicare levy—I do not criticise honourable senators for doing this—to address a range of issues relating to Medicare that they see as important. I note and will refer to the Minister for Health and Human Services (Dr Lawrence) any comments that have been made.

I think this is an important measure and one that is necessary for the government's economic strategy—an economic strategy that falls within the advice the OECD is contemporaneously offering and one that is quite sensible from a government strategy point of view for securing the longer term economic viability of the economy and for Australians to look forward to a better quality of life with a proper level of health care. I commend the bills to the Senate.
Question put:
That the bills be now read a second time.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Cook) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to amend the Industry Research and Development Act 1986, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Cook) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the revised explanatory memorandum and move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment of the Industry Research and Development Act 1986.

The Industry Research and Development Act 1986 is the legislative basis for a number of Government programs which encourage research and development in industry. The 150% tax concession is the cornerstone of this suite of programs, and it encourages companies to be more internationally competitive by:
increasing companies' investment in research and development;
encouraging better use of Australia's research infrastructure;
improving conditions for commercialising new technologies; and
developing a greater capacity for the adoption of foreign technology.

In 1987 this program was augmented by the introduction of syndication, which allows two or more eligible companies to register jointly for the concession. This development meant that the concession became available for those projects which were too large or too risky for a single company to undertake.

The great strength of the tax concession is that it runs on self assessment principles which allows industry to respond to changes in the market as they occur. A company simply invests in the research and development it needs to pursue, and claims back 150% of the cost of the eligible activities when it lodges its next tax return. This reduces the after tax cost of research and development to around 50 cents in the dollar.

Since the concession was introduced in 1985, business expenditure on research and development has doubled in real terms. The Government remains committed to the 150% tax concession as an integral part of building a nation that is more competitive in the international arena.

To help companies and other bodies use the concession effectively, the Industry Research and Development Act 1986 currently requires the Industry Research and Development Board to make guidelines addressing five key areas of the tax concession. These guidelines are:
Adequate Australian Content;
Registered Research Agencies;
Finance Schemes;
Commercial Government Bodies; and
Research and Development Activities Carried on Outside Australia.

These guidelines are disallowable instruments for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretations Act 1901, which means that they must be gazetted and laid before both Houses of Parliament within a prescribed period of time.

Until this year, guidelines covering the first four of these key areas—Adequate Australian Content, Registered Research Agencies, Finance Schemes and Commercial Government Bodies—were gazetted, but not laid before Parliament. As a result, the guidelines lapsed 15 sitting days after the guidelines were made. This was not brought to light until recently, and as a consequence, the Industry Research and Development Board has been making decisions using these lapsed guidelines in the belief that they were valid.

This discovery has caused an understandable amount of uncertainty in the business and research and development communities. In recognition of this, the Government has acted quickly by indicating its intention to proceed immediately with legislation to overcome the problem and give a clear signal that this Government continues to support innovation in Australian companies.

The amending legislation before you seeks to reinstate certainty and continuity for users of the tax concession. The guidelines were well understood within industry and are widely considered fair and effective.

This amending legislation retrospectively validates the lapsed guidelines, and the decisions made on the basis of these guidelines. This means that the decisions made by the Industry Research and Development Board and accepted by industry on the basis of the lapsed guidelines will have full legal force.

The amending legislation also provides that secondary decisions made on the basis of the guidelines, such as actions taken by the Commissioner of Taxation in response to certificates from the Industry Research and Development Board, are made valid.

Let me reassure you, that this validity provided by the amending legislation only extends to decisions and actions in as much as they relate to the lapsed guidelines. If some other component of a decision or action renders it invalid, then the amending legislation has no jurisdiction to change that. This legislation purely addresses those doubts caused by the failure to lay the guidelines before Parliament as required by law.

This validation of the lapsed guidelines does not in any way affect the power of Parliament to disallow the four sets of guidelines before the Senate at the moment, nor does it inhibit the power of Parliament to disallow any guidelines to be tabled in the future.

It is now widely recognised that developing an innovative culture which continually creates new areas of competitiveness, enhances efficiency and achieves greater productivity is a key factor in securing Australia's future. The 150% tax concession program is an important way of achieving these goals, and the amending legislation is essential for the continued success of this program. This action by the Government has the support of the major financial promoters of syndicated research and development.

The amendment bill also incorporates a time extension into the provisions covering the new grant approvals under the Industry Research and Development Act. The sunset clause amendment addresses the fact that the Industry Research and Development Board cannot enter into new grant agreements after 31 December 1995. The 1995-96 Budget initiatives for the Industry, Science and Technology portfolio included a commitment that the program would be extended to 30 June 1996 to allow the Government sufficient time to respond to the Industry Commission Inquiry into Research and Development. This is an extension of time only, and does not represent an increase in the appropriation.
I commend this bill to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned till the first day of sitting of the spring sittings, in accordance with the order agreed to on 29 November 1994.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators would be aware that the Patents Act 1990 commenced in April 1991. As would be expected once a degree of familiarity with the new patents legislation was established, a number of technical and drafting errors were identified. The review conducted by the Working Party on the Streamlining of the Patents Legislation, which consisted of the Law Council of Australia, the Institute of Patents Attorney of Australia, and the Australian Industrial Property Organisation, also identified some minor errors and ambiguities.

I would also add that in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal decision of the case of Re Franke and Anor v Commissioner of Patents and Anor (1993) AIPC 90-983, Deputy President McMahon suggested that the amendment of the wording of some transitional provisions would be desirable to clarify the intent of those provisions. According to Deputy President McMahon, the amendment is required, so that it does not in future become necessary to discern its true meaning from a consideration of external factors.

My Honourable senators, these amendments to the Patents Act are largely technical in nature and result from comments on the working of the new patents legislation. The bill is therefore consistent with the Government's commitment to providing a patent system that takes into account the needs of the users of the system.
The Government does not anticipate that the implementation of these amendments will have any revenue implications.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 9 June, on motion by Senator Sherry:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Civil Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 and the Air Services Bill 1995. These bills affect the most important organisational change to aviation regulations since 1988. The package of bills would divide the Civil Aviation Authority into two separate organisations—the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and Airservices Australia. The Civil Aviation Safety Authority, CASA, will look after the safety and regulation of aircraft, whereas Airservices Australia will be responsible for the commercial operations of the previous Civil Aviation Authority, that being air traffic controllers, firefighters and so on.

PARA.TAB: The government established the Civil Aviation Authority in 1988 as part of its deregulation of the domestic aviation industry. The authority's unitary structure, which combined safety regulation and airways management into one organisation, was inspired by the British Civil Aviation Authority. The minister at the time stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the task of regulating aviation safety must be regarded as an integrated system in which all elements are coordinated to achieve maximum reliability and effectiveness.

PARA.TAB: The operation of air traffic control and the flight advisory service is as much a part of safety regulation as the regulation of an aircraft and its crew.

SPEECH.PARA: The government and the Civil Aviation Authority have steadily moved away from that arrangement as its deficiencies became apparent. Unfortunately, the government did not take any action until we had two tragic accidents. Ralph Nader and Wesley Smith have described this sort of approach to safety regulation as the `tombstone imperative'.

PARA.TAB: The deficiencies in the air safety regulation system first began to emerge in 1993, when the Civil Aviation Authority commissioned the Terrell report into the operation of the then Safety Regulation and Standards Division. The steering committee set up to oversee the implementation of the report argued that the division structure did not adequately highlight the CAA's primary responsibility for safety regulation. The Safety Regulation and Standards Division was renamed and restructured as the Directorate of Aviation Safety Regulation.

The government, however, did not accept the need for radical change to the Civil Aviation Authority until the tragic air accident that occurred outside Young on a dark night in June 1993. On 11 June 1993, a Monarch Piper Chieftain slammed into a hill near the Young aerodrome. All of the seven people on board were killed, although one passenger—a little girl—suffered shocking injuries for another 10 hours. The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation report into the accident was scathing of the authority. In its findings, the bureau asserted that there were a range of organisational failures within the CAA. The government responded—a sort of knee-jerk reaction—with a poorly thought-out half measure that involved renaming the Directorate of Aviation Safety Regulation as the Aviation Safety Agency. It would have had discrete financial and accounting arrangements, but its head would have reported to the CAA's chief executive officer. The decision would have been a bureaucratic mess.

Then there was another accident, the Seaview crash, which revealed even more deficiencies than the CAA's operating procedures. The details of what happened on the Seaview crash are still emerging, but the many investigations into the accident have already revealed considerable managerial failures within the CAA. It was only after this second accident that the government announced that aviation safety regulation would be the responsibility of a completely separate agency.

The Civil Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill establishes the Civil Aviation Safety Authority as Australia's air safety regulator and includes a wide range of transitional provisions to split the CAA's assets and staff between CASA and Airservices Australia. The bill would require CASA to regard the safety of air navigation as its most important consideration. It would completely restructure part 3 of the act which deals with the regulation of civil aviation. The part would be restructured into four divisions, each dealing with a specific area of aviation safety.

Division 2, which deals with air operator certificates, is of particular interest. AOCs are the primary tool for regulating the safety of commercial air operations in Australia. Commercial air operators cannot fly without an AOC. At the moment the rules relating to AOCs are scattered between the act, the regulations and the civil aviation orders. The bill seeks to consolidate all of those provisions into the act. That move in the direction of simplification by putting such issues all into the one place is very welcomed.

The bill will also add a new subsection 28(2) to the act which would enable CASA to take into account the financial position of an applicant in satisfying itself of the applicant's ability to comply with aviation laws. This new subsection is a direct result of the Monarch crash. The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation pointed out in its report that Monarch had consistent financial problems. The company had significant difficulties in meeting its financial commitments as they became due. If the CAA had been alerted to these difficulties, it would have been able to monitor its operations more closely.

There has been some concern expressed to me about this particular provision in the act. However, I think what is there is satisfactory because it uses the word `may'. It does not use the word `shall' with regard to financial viability. The point about the Monarch crash was that the Civil Aviation Authority knew that Monarch was in trouble because it had not paid the bills for six or 12 months. That in itself should have waved a red signal that something was very wrong.

Subsequently, it became known—if one reads the BASI report on Monarch—that this company was not even able to pay its fuel bills in some areas and was carrying loads of fuel from Sydney for the return trip because it could not get credit in the rural provincial areas of New South Wales. I personally have no problems with the fact that CASA will be able, if it sees that there are serious financial problems, to see short cuts which could be a potential danger to fare paying passengers on these sorts of aircraft.

The Air Services Bill would set up Airservices Australia as a government business enterprise to operate Australia's airways system. Like CASA, Airservices Australia would be required to regard the safety of air navigation as its prime concern. The coalition strongly supports the dividing of CAA into two separate bodies—a specialist air safety regulator and an airways management authority.

We support the bills but do not support them uncritically. The government's original version of the bill proposed to insert a 238-word section into the Civil Aviation Act which would have set out its objectives. The House of Representatives inquiry into the bill pointed out that the clause was overly detailed. I would have thought that might have been an understatement by the committee. The inquiry proposed significant amendments to the objects clause. Its version would have read:

SPEECH.PARA: The main object of this Act is to establish a regulatory framework for maintaining, enhancing and promoting the safety of civil aviation in an effective and economical way, with particular emphasis on preventing aviation accidents and incidents whilst recognising the need for more people to benefit from civil aviation.

The government's redraft of the clause is broadly in line with the committee's recommendation but it omits the words `effective and economical' and the words `the need for more people to benefit from aviation'. The government redraft is a considerable improvement over the original version of 238 words, but the clause proposed by the committee is better. It has to be difficult, if not impossible, for the government to argue against the proposition that the regulation of civil aviation should be efficient and economical. Those words have been taken out by the government. It is difficult to argue against the proposition that more people should be able to benefit from civil aviation, the safest form of transport we have in Australia.

PARA.TAB: A further concern we have is that the Civil Aviation Authority has a history of imposing regulations on the industry without taking into account the costs of complying with them. Its public service culture is often incomprehensible to the operators it regulates, as Senator Collins, sitting opposite, would know. Civil Aviation Authority officers generally have a public service or military background. That in itself is not a criticism; it is a fact. In the main, general aviation operators are small business people.

The coalition believes that CASA should be required to perform its functions in a way that promotes and fosters aviation. A requirement of this sort would be broadly comparable to the American requirement that says that the federal aviation administration must adopt a policy of `the promotion, encouragement and development of civil aeronautics'. I point out that it is not the intent in the amendments we foreshadow in the committee stage of the bill that these organisations should develop a special section within their departments to promote it. We are saying that there has to be a change of culture and a change of attitude so that there is a cooperative attitude between those people within CASA and the industry itself in the promotion of safety and aviation.

In the House of Representatives the government argued that our suggestions would blur CASA's focus on air safety. I am not suggesting, and never would suggest, that CASA should adopt lower safety standards. I am suggesting that it should ensure that the regulatory requirements are straightforward and it should enforce them with the utmost attention to procedural fairness. CASA will not have and will not gain the respect of the industry until it does that. It is an industry where there is more than one player. It is not just the CAA, CASA or AA; it is the industry itself, and they have to work cooperatively.

The two bills would update the provisions relating to ministerial directions to bring them into line with current practice and the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act. In doing so, they would considerably reduce the minister's accountability to the parliament and the people for his or her decisions. Section 96 of the Civil Aviation Act currently requires that all ministerial directions to the authority be gazetted within 15 days. The bills will remove that section. Ministerial directions will be reported in the annual reports of the two bodies but nowhere else. This means we will have to wait for up to 12 months to find out what those ministerial directions are.

The House of Representatives inquiry partially recognised the lack of ministerial accountability in the bills. The committee recommends that the minister be required to table the final version of CASA's and AA's corporate plans. The government has accepted the committee's recommendations with respect to CASA but not with respect to Airservices Australia on the grounds that its corporate plan would be commercially confidential. In my view, the government's assertion in respect of this is absurd. I know that it is a general rule in respect of GBEs, but Airservices Australia could not in any sense be described as a commercial organisation. It is a monopoly; it has no competitors. It receives substantial sums of money through the budget. It received $27.6 million in 1995-96. Parliament surely should have the right to know what Airservices Australia plans to do with what money. It was pointed out that this will appear in the annual report, again 12 months later. There is a big lag effect.

We have all received a vast amount of correspondence from the aviation industry regarding section 20A of the act. Section 20A states that it is an offence for a pilot of an aircraft, recklessly or negligently, to endanger the life of a person. The offence carries a penalty of up to five years in gaol. The section also states that it is an offence for a pilot to cause danger to any person or property. The penalty is up to two years in gaol. The government decided to amend section 20A to make it easier for the CAA and the Director of Public Prosecutions to obtain convictions for these offences. The section originally said that a pilot's activities had to be likely to cause a danger. The government wanted to amend the section so that a pilot could be convicted if his or her actions had the potential to cause danger, not just the pilot but even an instructor.

According to an eminent Queens Counsel whom I consulted, the government's amendment could technically have made all forms of aviation illegal. After all, every form of flying has the potential to endanger someone, even if that someone is the pilot. I immediately put out a press release saying that we would block these amendments if the minister did not change them himself. Hundreds of pilots throughout Australia contacted his office to point out the flaw. After procrastinating for a week, the minister announced that he was abandoning the proposals and said he would refer the clause to the House of Representatives Morris committee.

The industry put forward an alternative version of section 20A which would encourage CASA to concentrate its scrutiny on pilots who endanger third parties rather than those who endanger only themselves. The amendment proposed by the industry is based on the ICAO agreement and is comparable to the relevant section in the United States air safety laws.

The government has proposed referring the matter to the Morris inquiry, but the matter needs to be dealt with now. If that amendment as proposed is accepted, it can certainly be referred to the Morris inquiry. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) may call an election well before the Morris inquiry reports, which means it may never get around to looking at that section of the act.

A number of government members in the other place have suggested that the only industry organisation opposed to their position on this issue is the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association. You can tell that those members are not on top of their mail. AOPA's proposal is supported by just about every aviation industry organisation in Australia, including the Sport Aviation Association and the International Air Pilots Association. In fact, a very strong release was put out by the International Air Pilots Association saying that if the clause had gone through, its pilots would have stopped flying into Australia.

The establishment of CASA and Airservices Australia is an opportunity for Australia to move away from the confusion and turmoil that has characterised the last few years of aviation regulation. It has an opportunity to end the faction fighting that has crippled the CAA. Difficulties are already emerging. Some people are quite apparently white-anting the new authority from within, before it even commences to operate. I am concerned that, in a few years, we may end up going through this sorry process again.

It is time the white-anting ceased. The officers who work for the CAA are world class. We have an excellent air safety record and it is time for the industry and the various tribes within the authority to work together to ensure that our safety record stays that way. More importantly, there has to be a restoration of confidence within the industry, within the minds of the general public and between the various sectors in the industry, including the new authorities to be set up. The coalition supports the bills but, as foreshadowed, I will be moving a number of amendments in the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not address the civil aviation bills as comprehensively as Senator Parer has done. I compliment him on the way he has addressed the legislation. I will deal only with section 20AA and the proposed coalition amendments.

PARA.TAB: Initially some attention was paid by the government to section 20AA. I understand that the government did not proceed with its intentions, due to overwhelming response from the industry. Section 20AA of the Civil Aviation Act 1988 provides in subsection (1):

SPEECH.PARA: An aircraft must not be flown or operated in a reckless or negligent manner so as to be likely to endanger life.
Subsection (2) provides:
An aircraft must not be flown or operated in such a manner or in such circumstances as is or are likely to cause danger to any person or property.

The concerns in these two subsections are twofold. In relation to subsection (1), the manner of flying or operation has to be either reckless or negligent. Furthermore, it has to be a manner which is likely to endanger life. This means that a pilot will commit an offence if he so operates an aircraft and his is the only life which is likely to be in danger. The manner of flying or operation has to be such that it is likely to endanger life. That is a more hypothetical test than that which is contained in the convention mentioned by Senator Parer, namely the International Civil Aviation Organisation Convention, which says:
An aircraft shall not be operated in a negligent or reckless manner so as to endanger life. . .

That is entirely different wording. That looks at the action which endangers life as such, not what we have at the moment which is that the manner is likely to endanger life. So the test we have at the moment in the Civil Aviation Act is perhaps one step removed and somewhat hypothetical. The amendment proposed by the coalition is more precise, more proximate and more definite; that is, that the manner of flying has to be such as to endanger life.

PARA.TAB: The United States regulation 91.13 has identical wording to that proposed by the coalition. I fail to see that there would be any problem with prosecuting the offences outlined by the coalition because I understand that, in America, that regulation in similar wording involves 70 to 80 per cent of air regulations prosecutions in that country.

There is also another aspect: at the moment, the legislation refers to any action that is likely to endanger life. That means any life, including the pilot's. In Australia we have stock mustering where there is a solo pilot, aerobatic flying with a single pilot and people in sporting clubs who fly on their own. For instance, a pilot flying over an empty wasteland on his or her own could engage in flying which could infringe this section. The same thing could occur with stock mustering out in the bush where there is no-one involved other than the pilot. There would just be the vast expanse of land below the aircraft and the stock being mustered.

I once saw an aerobatics exhibition where solo pilots would fly vertically towards the ground, then, at the last minute, pull out of the descent. That could be looked upon as being likely to endanger the life of the pilot. So the industry is very concerned that should the section remain as it is, the civil aviation authorities would concern themselves with these various scenarios that I have illustrated to the Senate. A good deal of time could be taken up in air safety investigations.

I am advised that some 27 per cent of the Civil Aviation Authority's time is taken up in regulating and investigating the sorts of situations I have outlined to the Senate. If the legislation was changed, the authorities would concentrate more on where the flying of aircraft involves people other than the pilot. That would include passengers both in a private and commercial sense.

For that offence there is a penalty of five years imprisonment. According to subsection (2), the aircraft must not be flown or operated in such a manner or in such circumstances as will or is likely to cause danger to any person or property. Again, the test is somewhat hypothetical: is it likely to cause danger to any person or property? That is a somewhat remote question to ask. It is not as proximate or definite as the coalition amendment which would propose simply that no person may operate an aircraft in a careless or reckless manner so as to endanger property or another person.

So there are two variations: firstly, that the property has to belong to another; and, secondly, that the person must be someone other than the pilot. Again, that distinguishes between the situations I mentioned earlier of a solo pilot in a remote situation or where there is absolutely no possibility of injuring someone else's property or person. The current section, as stated, contains that somewhat hypothetical test; that is, that it is likely to endanger the person or property. When a court has to ask itself that when trying a pilot—bearing in mind the penalty of two years imprisonment, a heavy penalty indeed—it could well say that virtually anything a pilot does is likely to endanger property. Flying over houses could well be said to be likely to endanger them. How long do you draw the bow? How wide a test is it?

Whenever you deal with a criminal sanction, you must be very careful when framing legislation to make sure that the behaviour which it is intended to address is treated in a specific fashion and that the causation of events is strictly related, so that you do not just cast the net wide and say that anything which flows from this action attracts criminal sanction. You might do that in the common law with negligence, but you certainly do not do it in the criminal jurisdiction.

I believe that the section, as it is promulgated, is deficient because it casts the net too wide for what is a criminal liability. In this situation it also casts the net wide as to how the civil aviation authorities are to address their minds to the question of air safety. If you widen the scope of liability, then you widen the burden on the regulating authorities. If you do that unnecessarily, then those areas which require their absolute attention, their absolute application of resources, can be denied that because the authorities have to cast too wide a net in their application of duty.

In any event, there is a question here of perhaps transgressing the established principles of law, and that is that you do not use principles of negligence or the civil law in the criminal jurisdiction. Whenever you say to the citizens in the country, `This is illegal; this will attach a criminal sanction,' then the elements of the offence must be explicitly set out and the actions which flow from the person's illegal behaviour must be clearly identified as being criminal. You cannot say that something which happens three steps removed from your actions can still warrant your being prosecuted for a criminal offence. For instance, if you do something in your daily life which causes something else to happen, which in turn causes something else to happen, it is starting to get a bit removed from your own actions, and it is generally only those direct consequences of your actions which the criminal law recognises as being attributable to your will, to your intention. To talk about anything which is likely to endanger property or a person is really casting the net a bit too wide.

I do not decry any step towards air safety. I use aircraft all too often. In fact, in Western Australia, which is the largest state in this country, air safety is absolutely crucial. But whenever we address a question of safety or a question of efficiency and use criminal sanction, we must be terribly careful not to transgress established principles of criminal law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Ellison pointed out, we have heard from Senator Parer quite an extensive resume of this legislation. I do not need to rehearse the broad thrust of this legislation, which we also will be supporting. But, like Senator Ellison, I would draw attention to section 20A, which many people have found offensive, and draw essentially the same point. That is that, while the government seeks to leave this as it is and refer the matter to a committee, which committee, as Senator Ellison pointed out, may not report before there is an election, we see no reason why the section should not be amended and the wording, as in the American federal aviation regulations, be put in there and that that be the basis of the wording which the committee reviews.

PARA.TAB: The Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Elliott), in his second reading speech, stated:
Section 20A of the Civil Aviation Act contains offences in relation to the flying or operation of aircraft in a manner likely to endanger life—

SPEECH.PARA: I pick up that word again, and I will mention it in a moment: or cause danger to person or property.
Of course, that includes—I am not sure if Senator Ellison stressed it sufficiently—the persons other than the person actually flying the aircraft. The parliamentary secretary continued:

The Director of Public Prosecutions advised that it was difficult in some circumstances to obtain a conviction under this section, principally because the risk of danger would have to be proved would be substantial or probable danger, even to the extent of actual injuries being sustained.

I think the record of cases that have been taken to the court shows that that is simply untrue, that there have been recent successes in relation to prosecutions and that that really is drawing somewhat of a long bow.
The parliamentary secretary continued:
The bill therefore contains amendments to section 20A along the lines proposed by the Director of Public Prosecutions.
The parliamentary secretary pointed out:

PARA.TAB: Concerns have been raised that the proposed amendment casts the net too wide in that legitimate aviation activities, such as training pilots, could be in breach of the revised provision.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, there have been a number of other objections raised to this section along the lines that a person who is willingly exposing himself or herself to danger, but not exposing another person to danger, should, in a reasonably free society, be allowed so to do.

PARA.TAB: When receiving delegations from pilots on this matter, I pointed out that I am quite a keen diver. One might argue that I am exposing myself to danger, that I might be gobbled up by a shark or attacked by the bends or something like that and that there should be some authority which protects me from those dangers. I would argue on the other hand that, provided I am carrying out those activities so as not to endanger the life or property of anybody else, I should be reasonably free to carry out those activities and that any public authority should not intrude into my personal liberty to enjoy life in the ways that I choose.

We will be supporting the opposition's amendment which, I understand, is to put in place the wording which is in the federal aviation regulations. Under the heading Aircraft Operations for the Purpose of Air Navigation, the regulations state:

SPEECH.PARA: No person may operate an aircraft in a careless or reckless manner so as to endanger the life or property of another.

I think that is the important point. These regulations should not catch those people engaged in sport aviation and those engaged in other aviation activities which do not or are not likely to impact on the life or property of another.

PARA.TAB: Other speakers have drawn attention to the word `potential'. There is considerable difficulty with that because the word `potential' indicates, to me at least, that any activity at all, even under the most extreme conditions, could be argued to have a potential to cause injury and damage. That activity would then be caught under the government's proposal. The very act of getting into an aircraft and starting a propeller turning could be argued to carry a potential risk. A few short years ago somebody walked into a propeller and lost an arm. So, clearly, starting an engine has the potential to cause harm. Contrary to what the parliamentary secretary said, that really is drawing the net too widely.

I conclude by saying that we will be supporting this legislation but we will support the opposition in relation to this change because we believe that it is far more appropriate for this amended clause to be referred to a committee, rather than the way the government seeks to leave the legislation.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Jacinta Collins, I remind honourable senators that this is her first speech. Therefore, I ask that the usual courtesies be extended to her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen J.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to enter this place at this time when the government is forging a refined national identity, for I am of a generation which has long questioned the relevance of the constitutional monarchy.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, I would like to pay tribute to my predecessor, Senator Olive Zakharov. Coming from different sections of the Victorian Labor movement, I did not have a personal acquaintance with Olive, but her work towards achieving social justice for several disadvantaged groups was well known and well respected. Olive did not seek reward in high profile other than in pursuing the issues she saw as important to Australians. She was, however, well known, liked and respected amongst the many people associated with this place and within the Australian Labor Party. Not a day has gone by in recent times without my receiving a reminder of the challenge I face in following her work.

I, too, adopt the Labor tradition of an overriding concern towards achieving greater social justice. There are three areas upon which I will focus on this occasion—that is, income distribution, industrial relations policy and the position of women in our society.

Recent commentary on income distribution has focused upon the extent of inequality within Australian society. Most recently, the opposition appears to believe it can gain the confidence of the Aussie battler as representing their interests towards a more just society. But let us look at the facts. As indicated in the Economic Planning Advisory Council income distribution survey released recently—and I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: Changes in the distribution of earnings in the 1980s and into the 1990s have been a concern both in Australia and overseas, with an increase in measured inequality in most developed countries.
Nevertheless, despite the increase in inequality shown by the figures, the dispersion in earnings in Australia has not been marked by international standards.

Recent studies have demonstrated that this government's policies are having the desired impact of reducing inequality amongst Australian families. The National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling has confirmed that the distributional impact of social wage measures significantly narrows the gap between rich and poor.

PARA.TAB: This government has improved the social wage, with measures such as: a 12 per cent increase in the real value of the base pension; a doubling in the real value of family payments to low income families and an extension to low income working families; the introduction and the maintenance of Medicare; a doubling in the proportion of the population with superannuation coverage; an enormous increase in child-care provision; child maintenance measures through the Child Support Agency; expanded labour market programs; more than doubling the proportion of young people completing secondary education; and expanded assistance with housing and rental assistance.

Such measures mean that the average incomes of the top 20 per cent of Australian families fall from 13 times to only four times those in the bottom 20 per cent once the benefits of government expenditure on social wage are included. But the government has not viewed these indications as grounds for complacency. As indicated in the EPAC report:

SPEECH.PARA: The extent of income disparities are such that questions arise whether the social and economic needs of the disadvantaged are being met and whether the economy is operating as efficiently and as equitably as it might.

Recent initiatives have focused on ensuring that these issues continue to be addressed—for instance, those under the government's employment white paper, Working Nation, last year, that is, the jobs compact, the parenting allowance due to operate from 1 July this year, and also the current budget initiatives of the maternity allowance, expanded child-care initiatives and increases in the guardians allowance and rental assistance.

PARA.TAB: Non-cash benefits are strongly redistributive and act to reduce income inequality. Increases in the social wage strongly suggest that focusing on cash incomes only exaggerates the extent of inequality. Yet the opposition would focus upon cash incomes. For the conservatives, equality and social justice seem secondary to the efficiency of the free marketplace. Their promises of tax cuts would be funded by cuts to government spending in those very areas which make Australia a more equitable place in which to live.

The opposition has played up some recent reports on the level of inequality in Australia in a bid to attract the vote of the Aussie battler. But, as pointed out in the Weekend Australian of 3 June, an Australian underclass is a myth, and Australian voters deserve more respect on these issues. They knew at the last election that the GST would impact unfairly on the Aussie battler. They knew the importance of access to health care and the likely impact of proposals to end bulk billing. The Aussie battler knew what ending unemployment provisions after nine months would mean.

Australian voters made a different choice from New Zealanders in their choice of federal government. In New Zealand, which seems to be the opposition's model, the only income group better off over the period March 1981 to March 1994 were the top 20 per cent. My commitment is to work to ensure that this does not occur in Australia; to work to maintain systems which lead to improvements in living standards for all Australians; to ensure that the level of growth is fairly distributed between all income levels.

Industrial relations reforms were a significant component of the conservative government's changes in New Zealand leading to a decline in living standards for all but the top 20 per cent income group. As the EPAC report noted:

SPEECH.PARA: The growing number of "working poor" has been a concern in a number of countries. In Australia, the effect of award and minimum wage arrangements have set a floor for wages for most workers but there are concerns that moves to less centralised wage bargaining would give rise to very low wages for some workers.

Once again, the Aussie battler knew this at the last election. She still knows that the opposition policy of emphasising wage increases solely through productivity based enterprise bargaining would apply only to a privileged few. The opposition has retained its Jobsback policy which leaves workers vulnerable. Many women workers are not in a strong bargaining position. For instance, the 16-year-old casual shop assistant working for a major company like Coles Myer or Woolworths is not in a strong position to bargain.

PARA.TAB: Under successive accords the Aussie battler has accepted wage restraint, which has allowed for more distributive improvements to the social wage and workplace reforms under considerable industrial harmony. Despite this, opposition policy would see more deregulation without the protection of adequate social or industrial safety nets.

Enterprise bargaining opposition style would not involve any no-disadvantage test. The Labor government's record of improvements to the position of the disadvantaged groups within the work force would be laid bare to the free hands of the marketplace. The closing gap between men's and women's wages would be put clearly into reverse.

The federal opposition proposes minimal, if any, award protection, like the Victorian government, which has succeeded in cutting conditions to the core and which recently sought to reduce centrally fixed wage rates to a single across-the-board $8.60 per hour. Even employer groups, such as the Australian Chamber of Manufacturers, have called for a multi-tier minimum wage system and greater consistency between the state and federal industrial relations systems.

Victorian style unconstrained individual contracts may not survive in conservative vogue with scandals such as the Smith affair. However, despite the announcement of the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) overnight, the federal opposition has made no significant changes to Jobsback except to specify that the Industrial Relations Commission would be able to set and vary safety net wage rates. But any such rate is likely to be similar to the single across-the-board $8.60 per hour being sought by the Victorian government rather than an adequate safety net.
The federal opposition has also proposed a flat across-the-board youth wage of $3 per hour. The Aussie battler remembers these things.

The opposition's agenda is not hidden behind its beat-up against the principles of natural justice and procedural fairness incorporated within the unfair dismissal provisions in the Industrial Relations Act. The total number of unfair dismissal claims has not risen over the last 15 months as evidence of an unfair advantage to workers. Rather, there has simply been a shift from state jurisdictions to the federal level.

It is important to note that these reforms, along with national minimum entitlements, such as the right to a fair minimum wage, 12 months unpaid parental leave, protection for workers with family responsibilities and equal pay for work of equal value, are based on International Labour Organisation conventions and the use of the external affairs powers, which the opposition will not support.

Members of the opposition have expressed in my time here on several occasions the view that there are too many unionists represented on the government's benches. I have been privileged to represent Australia internationally, where our record of Labor government and trade union participation is well respected. I am pleased to have been part of the reshaping of the trade union movement in heightening its relevance to young women workers.

I cannot, and I would not wish to, overlook that I am the sole woman Labor representative from Victoria in this federal parliament. I am confident, though, that this will change significantly after the next federal election. Women comprise a disproportionate level of persons in several disadvantaged groups, for instance, low income earners and sole parents.

I believe that the government has been heading in the right direction in recent policies and initiatives, such as the parental and the maternity allowances. They acknowledge that women are not an homogenous group but rather that they have varying interests which should be addressed.

The parental allowance acknowledges the work performed by a parent for children at home. The maternity allowance recognises that women often move in and out of the work force at different stages of their working lives.

However, the opposition seems to continue to perpetuate division between women in the work force and women at home. It has jumped upon the government's record on superannuation as not encompassing women at home without acknowledging the base from which this government's reform agenda arose. That is, very few women previously had access to superannuation at any stage in their lives.
Labor can be proud of its record of achievements for women. I am committed to working towards further improvements in the position of women throughout Australian society.

In closing, there are some people whose support I would like to note. I am happy to acknowledge my background of 15 years within the trade union movement. There are many people who have assisted me within the shop assistants union and the broader industrial and political wings of the Labor movement.

There is one man in particular I will recognise, as have others from this place in commentaries on the Labor Party. I first met Jim Maher as a 16-year-old shop assistant. His career has demonstrated a strong and selfless commitment to improving the lives of ordinary workers. Jim Maher has been a significant force in the modernisation of the trade union movement. His leadership of the shop assistants union saw it grow manyfold to a membership of over 200,000. His stewardship within the union was well ahead of current initiatives promoting the participation of women and young workers within trade union structures.

The vast experiences I have had access to from within the union movement commenced, for instance, with an early version of the current ACTU recruitment traineeships. Many of these experiences have been as a consequence of the support of Jim Maher.

My parents have also been a significant support. Their guidance and friendship have been and will continue to be vital components of my life. Finally, my presence here—or should I say our presence here—would not be possible without the unconditional support of my husband Daryl. My confidence is that we will meet the significant challenges that lie ahead. In conclusion, I look forward to participating in the framing of our nation's future identity to reflect the Australian ethos of a fair go.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I want to make a brief report and present two draft codes of conduct for the consideration of senators. Senators will be aware that a working group chaired by Mr Speaker and me and including representatives of both houses and all sides of politics has been considering a code of conduct for members of parliament. The membership of the group was Senators Bourne, Chamarette, McKiernan, Ray, Reid and Tambling, and Mr Mack, Mr Price, Mr Scott and the Rt Hon. Ian Sinclair. Mr Speaker and I thank all members for their contribution to the group.

PARA.TAB: The working group grew out of a similar group in the previous parliament and was convened on the initiative of the Senate as part of the response to the resignation of the former Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Mrs Kelly. The working group was asked to consider a code of conduct both for ordinary members and for ministers. It drew on existing documents, including the constitution, Remuneration Tribunal determinations, the Bowen committee report, the work of the Electoral and Administrative Review Committee in Queensland and various guides to ministers issued over the years.

Discussion within the group ranged widely—like another contemporary debate—basically polarising between maximalist and minimalist positions. Should the document seek to be all-embracing and detailed, or a short statement of principles? The majority of the group favoured the minimalist approach but accepted that two documents were required: one for members and another for ministers, presiding officers and parliamentary secretaries.

I will not canvass at this time the various issues the group discussed. The purpose of tabling the document at this time is to allow senators to consider them and, at a later date when the pressure of business is somewhat less, to debate them at length. I am sure that the proponents of the different positions in the group will present their arguments at that time.

It will be an important debate. Members of parliament are not held in particularly high esteem. The adoption of a code of conduct that demonstrates that members observe high standards of public and private behaviour may go some way to redressing that perception. Its existence will also stand as a constant remainder to members of their duties and obligations to the people of Australia. I commend the draft framework documents to the Senate.
Motion (by Senator Reid) proposed:
That the Senate take note of the documents.
Ordered that further consideration of the motion be adjourned till the first day of sitting of the spring sittings.

DEBATE.TITLE: CIVIL AVIATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995AIR SERVICES BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before turning to the detail of this legislation, I might suggest to Senator Jacinta Collins that, while we welcome her first speech, if she plays as fast and as loose with the facts in future speeches in this chamber as she did in this particular episode, she will not be treated as gently as she was on the occasion of her maiden speech, which she just completed. I just highlight one unsubstantiated claim which she made in that speech, and that was that the coalition retains its jobsback policy. I do not know what evidence she has for that. She certainly did not provide any evidence to this chamber in her speech, and she might get a surprise when that policy is released.
—When will we see the policy?

—You will see the policy in due course. When are we going to see the election? We are good and ready to face an election at any time. Just bring it on, and then you will see the policies that we will have to put before the Australian people.
—Why don't you talk about the civil aviation bill?
