—As I turn to the Civil Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill 1995, can I say that the opposition supports with some vigour this belated initiative of the government to restructure the Civil Aviation Authority into its two replacement bodies: the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and Airservices Australia. As to the stated intention of the government to also introduce separate legislation to increase the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation's capacity to conduct what it describes as `more sophisticated, systematic investigations and analysis', we certainly await that legislation with interest and the opportunity to comment upon it.

PARA.TAB: My colleague the member for Hume in the other place, Mr John Sharp, should be given credit for the tireless campaign which he has waged on the issue of aviation safety to get the government to take some cognisance of this particular issue and to address it in policy, and also for his continuing work on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure in its inquiry into air safety standards.

The CAA has been described as having `a cowboy approach to life', being `out of control' and acting `according to its own agenda' and `clandestinely in the name of what it thought were its corporate responsibilities'. Those comments were not made from this side of the chamber; they were made from a member of the government, who also stated that the CAA `deliberately set out to mislead the public' and was involved in `serious breaches' of its duty. The CAA has also been described as `unusual', `poorly administered', `bureaucratic', `expensive', `inward-looking', `self-defensive' and a `complete shambles'. This is quite a list of incriminating adjectives for a government business enterprise responsible for administering aviation safety in this country.

In some ways, it is amazing that there were so few accidents, but it is an indictment on the government that it took the fatal crashes of Monarch in June 1993 and Seaview in October 1994—resulting in the deaths of 16 people—to goad it into action. I suspect there are some startling parallels to be drawn between the cultural problems experienced within the CAA and those which we have witnessed recently and which, to some extent, are still occurring within CSIRO and have been highlighted by recent investigations of the Senate Economics Committee. They exemplify this government's incapacity to manage.

Certainly, and at least to some extent encouragingly in this instance, the government has accepted the majority of the recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, which examined the bills which we are debating this afternoon and issued its recommendations in an advisory report on 11 May 1995. The appointment of Mr Leroy Keith as head of the new Civil Aviation Safety Authority is also welcomed by the opposition as assisting in the reparation process of this organisation.
The problems of the CAA have been evident for some time. The 1993 election aviation policy statement, issued by the Liberal and National parties in February of that year, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Coalition believes that present arrangements are not satisfactory in providing advice to Government and in creating unity within the aviation industry. This situation has contributed to animosity between Government agencies and parts of the aviation industry.

My colleague Senator Parer, the shadow minister for tourism and aviation, in his address to the Aerial Agricultural Association recently said of the CAA that its `public service culture is often incomprehensible to the general aviation operators that it regulates'—who, by and large, of course, are in the nature of small businessmen.

PARA.TAB: In his second reading speech on this bill, the parliamentary secretary to the minister stated that these bills `will provide a much clearer focus on aviation safety regulation and ensure there is no conflict with the more commercial goals of the service provider'. This is to be achieved by placing the aviation safety regulatory function with the new Civil Aviation Safety Authority and the provision of airway services with Airservices Australia, which will be established as a government business enterprise.

CASA's functions will include standard setting, safety surveillance of the industry and enforcement of standards, entry control, and licensing. It was stated in the second reading speech that the minister has issued a direction to the CAA to establish a formal system to trigger an automatic increase in safety surveillance of any operator found to be in financial default. This is in line with the recommendation of the Council of the Australian Division of the Royal Aeronautical Society in its review of the safety of general aviation in Australia. In its position paper issued in December 1994, the council recommended:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the CAA/ASA must have powers to investigate all aspects of financial viability of GA commercial operators.

The second reading speech notes that the Civil Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 provides that CASA has a safety regulatory role, but does not provide CASA with the powers of an economic regulator. It goes on to say that the bill:

nevertheless allows CASA to take into account information about financial viability [and] empowers CASA to have regard to information about the financial viability of a particular operator in deciding whether or not to conduct a detailed safety audit of the operator.

In a somewhat contradictory statement, however, the difference in interpretation is based on the mandatory nature of CASA's responsibility to apply the financial viability test, and whether or not that would interfere with CASA's responsibilities as a safety regulator. Given the convoluted and contradictory explanation provided in the second reading speech, one might wonder whether overseeing the financial viability of aircraft operators will improve relations between the safety authority and the industry or, indeed, exacerbate existing problems.

PARA.TAB: Certainly the explanation given by the minister is not too convincing. This is an important point, given the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation's report on the Monarch Air Piper Chieftain fatal crash in June 1993, which was released in July 1994. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the inference that could be drawn from the way in which Monarch operations were conducted was that there was a significant management bias towards commercial operations at the expense of safety.

It is clear that the government has good intentions in this regard. Its response to the BASI report was to establish an inquiry into air safety for the commuter and general aviation safety sectors, which I mentioned earlier. It went further with its reactions to the Seaview air accident by appointing a new director of aviation safety, announcing the establishment of the Civil Aviation Safety Agency, announcing a judicial inquiry into the operations of the CAA, and increasing surveillance of low capacity passenger and charter operations. Significantly, it also allowed for an increase of 57 staff in the safety regulation area of the CAA.

PARA.TAB: The bill inserts new provisions dealing with applications for the issuing of conditions that apply to air operators certificates. The Bills Digest states that `CASA may take the financial position of the applicant into account when determining if it is satisfied' that the applicant has or is capable of complying with safety rules. The issue will be how successfully the Civil Aviation Safety Authority will implement and manage the financial viability test in carrying out its primary role of safety regulator, while at the same time mending the difficult relationships between regulator and regulated.

In relation to amendments to subsections 20A(1) and 20A(2), which have been the subject of lobbying by the Aircraft Operators and Pilots Association of Australia, the subsequent withdrawal by the government of those amendments—in the light of advice from the Department of Public Prosecutions, the Attorney-General and AOPA, which represents a membership of some 10,000—was appropriate. However, the coalition believes that the existing wording of the act does not comply with our international obligations under the International Civil Aviation Organisation Regulations, nor is it comparable with regulations in effect in the United States, New Zealand or the United Kingdom.

Logical arguments have been put forward for the amendment of the original section 20A, and Senator Parer has proposed amendments to those subsections which we will move in the committee stage of this bill. That is notwithstanding the minister's preferred option to have these concerns referred to the House of Representatives inquiry on aviation safety for examination. Further, we will be seeking an amendment requiring CASA to perform its functions in such a way that aviation in Australia will be promoted and fostered.

This is a consistent approach for the Liberal and National parties, and acknowledges in part the significant and substantial role that general aviation plays in the training of the industry's pilots. This includes the private commercial sector—which employs pilots for charter, freight and pilot training from small commuter airlines—and the rapid passenger transport sector at the private level. Similarly, a proportion of the pilots employed by the public—though soon to be private, according to the government—RPT sector, Qantas, are drawn from general aviation backgrounds.

In her book, My God! It's a Woman, Australian aviator Nancy Bird refers to a female Qantas pilot, Sherelle Quinn, now a captain with Qantas, who went to extraordinary lengths to conceal her flying training from her parents, and had several jobs, including picking strawberries, to pay for flying lessons. Another pilot, from my home state of South Australia, now a first officer with Qantas, started his flying training at Parafield airport and had three jobs at once—one of them as an aircraft refueller—to pay for his flying lessons. Both of these pilots, and many others, paid enormous amounts of money in order to obtain their qualifications. This point is relevant in that the dedication and commitment of these and many other individuals have contributed significantly to the outstanding safety record of Qantas in a field of international players.

I should also mention another group that operates with the assistance of privately funded general aviation—the Air Training Corps and the Australian Air League. The valuable service to the country provided by these two organisations is frequently overlooked, as is the fact that many of the cadets, who have subsequently joined the armed forces or assumed commercial aviation careers, had their initial passion for aviation fostered by the individuals who comprise this dedicated group of volunteers. Many sacrifice their annual leave and donate many hours of private time to conduct training camps and to pass on their skills to the youth of Australia. It is sad that we saw the demise, some years ago, of the various university squadrons of the Air Force Reserve which had operated for many years and also provided an initiation to aviation for many young people.

It is partly the personal commitment of pilots and other volunteers, such as those I have just mentioned, that has contributed so significantly to the pool of pilots available to the industry. It is precisely these, and other aircraft owners who operate pilot training enterprises which achieve minimal or no profits, that the Liberal and National parties believe should be encouraged. It is the benefit to the Australian aviation industry as a whole which provides the mandate for us to foster aviation in this country.

There is another reason. Australia enjoys a uniquely favourable environment for pilot training. Weather conditions are generally fair, which assists with navigation training. The sheer size of the Australian land mass, together with its large tracts of flat terrain, offers extended uninterrupted flight in safe conditions—not over water nor with the risk of infringing foreign airspace. A stable political climate provides that aircraft, certainly training aircraft, are not used as terrorist targets.

These conditions provide Australia with a unique opportunity to exploit this combination of factors and to benefit from acknowledgment of our situation by the countries which send their pilots to Australia for training. In Adelaide, Perth, Tamworth, and through a range of universities Australia-wide, pilots from Hong Kong, Malaysia, New Guinea, Singapore, several African countries, as well as from the RAAF, Qantas and Ansett, undertake basic and advanced training.

I welcome the fact that on a recent visit to Taiwan I had discussions with its Department of Civil Aviation about the likelihood of Taiwanese pilots undertaking training here soon as well. There is a significant vested interest for Australia as a whole to encourage and foster aviation and to ensure that CASA's regulatory regime, while not compromising safety, is not onerous. Undoubtedly, there are significant export dollars to be earned from the training programs we can provide to pilots from overseas.

Parallels have been drawn with some other recreational activities to support a sport aviation category of flying. With some reservations, I support this proposition, although I must say that I draw the line at comparing aerobatics with abseiling, as has been suggested in some quarters. Frankly, apart from both requiring coordinated motor skills, that is about where the comparison ends. The level of skill varies considerably, not least in the degree of training required, and some very specific physical factors also distinguish the two.

Having said that, pilots—from which I exclude paragliders, hang-gliders and parachutists—have achieved a level of skill and have been exposed to a comprehensive testing regime prior to engaging in activities in the sport aviation category. Consequently, I see no reason for not supporting a sport or recreational category for flying, with the cautionary note that flying skills require maintenance. I understand that occasional flying can be dangerous. Therefore, those who engage in recreational flying must ensure that their skills are maintained and adequate. With those comments in regard to the legislation and some of the issues that relate to aviation safety, I join with Senator Parer and others on the opposition side of the Senate in supporting the legislation, subject to the amendments that we will be moving in the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, before speaking to this Civil Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 and the Air Services Bill 1995, I table a correction to the revised explanatory memorandum. I do not pretend to have had enough time in the last 12 months, with an obvious preoccupation with my own portfolio, to have followed closely the development of this issue—the establishment of these two bodies—nor, in particular, the opposition's principal amendment foreshadowed by Senator Parer. In fact, I only came down to the chamber this evening because I was on chamber duty at the time this debate was about to proceed. That is when I picked up the opposition's principal amendment to the government's proposal and read it with total disbelief.

PARA.TAB: I cannot believe this, Senator Parer. Over the last six months or so, the government has talked about the blinding hypocrisy of this coalition. Just the other day we canvassed in here the revelations of the shadow minister for regional development about a leaked draft document. That revealed the extent of the opposition's hypocrisy. But nothing, Senator Parer, can touch this backflip.

I hope that some of the specialist aviation writers will pay some attention to the amendment you are moving, in consideration of everything you have said and done over the last 12 months on this matter. The government significantly restructured the Civil Aviation Authority—

TALK.START.PARA: —So you should have.

—Correct; so we should have, and we did. I am talking about the previous restructure. That resulted in massive savings to the airline industry: hundreds of millions of dollars in lowered charges—a rare event in this world of ours. That was, without question, an achievement and a success of the restructuring of the Civil Aviation Authority.

PARA.TAB: But there was a problem identified with that restructuring; a problem that resulted, as Senator Parer quite correctly said, with the Terrell report. Captain Alan Terrell, as the Senate has been previously told, was deliberately appointed to the board of the Civil Aviation Authority to correct that problem. What was the identified problem? The identified problem was the dual responsibility of the Civil Aviation Authority.

The question of splitting the organisation into two completely separate and identifiable arms—one a commercial arm and one a regulatory arm—had been canvassed on a number of occasions previously. It was decided at that time not to proceed with it. But it was obvious that the identified problem was just that. The Minister for Transport, Mr Brereton, to his credit, acted decisively and with the support of the opposition, as I understood it, and split the organisation into those two bodies, each one with a clearly identified role.

In other words, the dual responsibility was finished. There was a commercial arm to the operation and an unblushingly and unequivocal safety arm to the operation. I thought, considering everything that the opposition has said in the last 12 months, that that would win the support and, indeed, the plaudits of the opposition. I have never seen a backflip of these proportions—and we have seen a few in here!

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you talking about?

—Have a look at the amendment. We are talking about dual responsibility. The opposition has made that the centrepiece of its attacks on the CAA over the last 12 months. There is a pile of this stuff two inches thick. I am not going to keep the Senate here for ages while I read them all, but I will just read the flavour of it. The shadow minister for transport in the House of Representatives, Mr Sharp, said on 20 October 1994, `The very core issue of this whole problem, the unholy relationship between the CAA, the policeman of our airlines, and the airline operators themselves.

PARA.TAB: I refer to two press statements, but there are many more, as Senator Parer knows. In April 1994 Mr Sharp said, `The attitude that prevails within the Civil Aviation Authority gives greater priority to commercial concerns of air operators rather than the safety of passengers.' We have another press statement from Mr Sharp which says this, `Mr Sharp said that the report'—that is the Monarch report—`had pointed the finger at the CAA's placement of commercial considerations above its primary function of the regulation of air safety as identified in the act.' You cannot get it much clearer than that. So, what does the minister for aviation do? The minister for aviation, Mr Brereton—

TALK.START.PARA: —You should know better as you were the minister.

—That was 18 months ago. The minister for aviation split the organisation and removed the commercial arm—the absolute centrepiece of the opposition's concerns over the last 12 months—and set up CASA, which has unblushingly been given a mandate to concentrate on safety and nothing else; precisely what the opposition says it was after. I am truly astonished—and I only found out about it when I walked into the chamber—that the opposition is now proposing an amendment to alter the objects of CASA, the safety regulatory arm, in this way:

SPEECH.PARA: The main object of this Act is to establish a regulatory framework for maintaining, enhancing and promoting the safety of civil aviation in an effective and economical way,—
the amendment speaks of an `economical way' not `efficient' or `cost effective'—
with particular emphasis on preventing aviation accidents and incidents—
and listen to this!—
whilst recognising the need for more people to benefit from civil aviation.
That is utterly astonishing. Where are you coming from on this issue?

TALK.START.PARA: —Because the House of Representatives committee unanimously decided that that is how it should read.

—So what! Have a look at your rhetoric over the last 12 months. You and Mr Sharp said, `Don't mix commercial and safety concerns.' The government having done precisely that, you now wish to amend the act to take it further back from where it was previously. You are talking about economical safety.

SPEECH.PARA: I will canvass this a little more broadly in the committee stage, but I cannot emphasise it enough in the second reading debate. I refer to the absolute hypocrisy of the opposition in moving this amendment. I hope the wording of this amendment has been noted by some of the aviation writers who have followed all of the extreme statements that have been made by the opposition on this issue over the last 12 months. I have just read three of them.

PARA.TAB: The phrase `efficient and effective' in the government's proposals has been put there deliberately and is well understood by the bureaucracy and by this parliament. I will give the Senate the Finance Department's definitions of `efficient' and `effective'. `Efficient' is defined by the Department of Finance to mean the extent to which program inputs are minimised for a given level of program outputs or program outputs are maximised for a given level of inputs. `Effective' is defined as the extent to which a program's outcomes achieve its stated objectives—clear-cut, precise and supportable.

I am an ordinary user of the English language. The word `economical' has a clear inference of affordable safety—the very concept that the opposition has been bucketing for a year and a half. The opposition wants to put it back in the CASA legislation. CASA is the organisation that is not concerned with the commercial arm of the operation but unblushingly has a mandate for safety. The opposition wants to turn it back and reverse everything it has said in the past year and a half. That is an astonishing piece of blatant hypocrisy. In sheer policy terms it must have everybody in the aviation industry scratching their heads and wondering just where these people come from on any given day on any particular issue.

I also foreshadow to the Senate that we will be vigorously opposing the proposed amendment in respect to the section dealing with reckless flying. I will save that for the committee stage of the debate because I wish to give some examples as to why we object to the opposition's proposal. I noted that Senator Parer quoted Ralph Nader with approval in his speech on the second reading of the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did.

—Yes, you did. I also note that the opposition's amendments introduce the question of cost and talk about an `economical way' in bringing back the dual responsibility for this organisation. These are based on similar provisions of the Federal Aviation Administration in the United States. It is a fact that the current provisions of the dual role of the regulator in the United States—that is, having a role of regulating and fostering the industry at the same time; the very intent of the amendments that the opposition is moving here this afternoon—are under great scrutiny.

PARA.TAB: It is under no greater scrutiny than that of Ralph Nader himself whom Senator Parer is quoting with approval. I will tell Senator Parer what Mr Nader said about the dual role of fostering the industry and regulating it, which is precisely the concept that Senator Parer wants to reintroduce. In his book The truth about airline safety: collision course Ralph Nader said this:

SPEECH.PARA: Eliminate the dual mandate. As we have seen, the FAA's purposes for existing are often at cross-purposes. On one hand, the agency is charged by law to promote the economic health of the aviation industry. On the other, it is required to foster safety. When the two purposes come into conflict, money wins over safety almost every time.

That is precisely the situation the Minister for Transport has corrected with the legislation, which is before this house, that establishes these two arms. It is, therefore, as I have said, absolutely astonishing and in direct contradiction to every statement made both inside and outside the Senate over the last 12 months by the opposition that it is amending the objects of the act to reintroduce not only the question of efficiency or cost-effective but also the question of economical safety. In fact, it is going so far as to say that this organisation has to recognise the need for more people to benefit from civil aviation.

PARA.TAB: It is not beyond imagination that at some future time, when an operator is being prosecuted by CASA under one section of the act in which a safety regulation is being breached, that action might be mounted—and probably will be mounted; it is worth a try—by the same operator, should these amendments be carried, saying that the action that is being taken against the operator does not recognise the need for people to benefit from civil aviation. In other words, it is not for the benefit of the industry.

It is astonishing that the opposition is moving this amendment. I look forward, in the committee stage of the debate when the amendment is moved, to hearing a credible explanation from Senator Parer as to how he can sit this amendment for economical safety—not just affordable safety—with all of the statements that have been made by him and by the shadow minister, Mr Sharp, over the last 12 months.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: CIVIL AVIATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Schedule 1, page 12, item 14, omit the item, substitute the following item:

PARA.TAB: "14. After section 3:

TAB.TAB: Insert:

PARA.TAB: `3A. The main object of this Act is to establish a regulatory framework for maintaining, enhancing and promoting the safety of civil aviation in an effective and economical way, with particular emphasis on preventing aviation accidents and incidents whilst recognising the need for more people to benefit from civil aviation.'.".

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bob Collins just delivered the most hypocritical diatribe I have ever heard in this place. It is not unusual; the man would be better off in the theatre! He was the man who was the minister for aviation and who was responsible for the very criticisms that have brought about the division of the CAA into two areas—because of the criticisms of so-called affordable safety.

PARA.TAB: There is a reason why we have moved these amendments. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, in its May report of 1995, recommended that the objects of this clause be as we have written them. Typically, this government's first proposal, before it went to the Morris committee, was for a 238-word section on objects.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's gone.

—Of course it has gone. The committee had some commonsense that the government did not have. The minister is objecting to two words—`effective' and `economical'. How could anyone with any sort of commonsense complain about putting in the words, `The Civil Aviation Safety Authority, CASA, should be effective'? What is the minister saying—if we leave them out, it is okay if they are ineffective?
—They have been so far.

—Exactly, Senator Calvert. Senator Collins objects to us putting the words, `That this new authority, CASA, should be effective'. He also says that he objects to the word `economical'. He goes back to his old complaints about so-called affordable safety. He says that `economical' equates to `affordable'. Mr Chairman, do you know what the antithesis to that is?—that it is okay if it is uneconomic. He is happy for it to be uneconomic. In other words, `Go ahead, spend money willy-nilly without worrying about the cost of operating the department.'

PARA.TAB: I repeat that this was the view of the House of Representatives committee. Guess who was on the Morris committee. Peter Morris was the chairman. Other Labor members were Mr Dick Adams, from Tasmania, Mr Graeme Campbell, Mr Colin Hollis, Mr Peter Knott, Mr Gavan O'Connor and Mr Wayne Swan. They were the people who supported those words.

Senator Collins then goes on in an absolutely hysterical fashion complaining about a few words—`effective' and `economical'. He goes on to say that he does not like the words `Recognising the need for more people to benefit from civil aviation'. Senator Collins praises Minister Brereton. Minister Brereton reacted only after two air crashes—tragic that they were. It was a knee-jerk reaction.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a load of rubbish.

—Senator Collins knows and I know that Minister Brereton found a few scapegoats. When that did not work, he went through a knee-jerk reaction. What has come out of that has been something we have been proposing for quite some time: that is, as Senator Collins says—although he distorted the reasons—that we recognise the fact that we separate the commercial arms from the safety and regulatory arms. But that does not mean that we should not include as an object—and it is a broad object; an object supported by a committee of which his party has a majority—
—`Promotes and fosters civil aviation'. You find that in the Morris report.

—I am talking about the first amendment. I will come to the second amendment in a minute. I would like to hear your response to the distortion of words that you used. You are saying that you do not want CASA to be effective and you do not want it to be economic. In other words, you are saying that you want it to be ineffective and uneconomic.
—What a load of garbage.

—That is exactly what you are saying. You are saying that there is no need for people to benefit from civil aviation. We have put in the words, `Recognise the need for people to benefit.' By excluding those words, you are saying that you do not recognise the need for people to benefit from civil aviation. They are the reasons we put it in. It was a recommendation of the House of Representatives committee—a very good committee chaired by Mr Morris. He has done a good job.

PARA.TAB: The new organisation is critical because of the problems the CAA has had. I do not envy its problems. I do not like what has happened, because it has affected the confidence of aviation in this country to a large extent. It would be better if these particular words were included. We must bear in mind that safety is the first consideration and we do not move away from that. In fact, the object as promoted by us is to maintain, enhance and promote the safety of civil aviation.

If Senator Collins wants it to be ineffective and uneconomic, that is up to him. It is typical of this government. That is what it has done for the last 12 years—it has been uneconomical and ineffective. If he believes that there should not be a need for people to benefit from civil aviation, then obviously that is what he is subscribing to by opposing the inclusion of these few words.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that Senator Parer has the unenviable job that we all have from time to time of trying to defend the indefensible. I am well aware that the Morris committee came down with that recommendation and I concur with Senator Parer in saying that the Morris committee did a commendable job. That is why the government adopted so many of its recommendations.

PARA.TAB: But there was one recommendation of the Morris committee which the government rejected. And this happens with committee reports from time to time—governments do this, as do parliaments, the House of Representatives and the Senate because committees are creatures of these chambers. It is finally the houses of parliament that determine the final result. The Morris committee report was a good piece of work, as you would expect from the former transport minister. Most of the recommendations were accorded the respect that they deserve. But the one that was emphatically rejected by the government, and rightly so, was this one. This particular amendment, in all the reliance that Senator Parer is placing on the Morris committee, has to be read with the even more crucial amendments that the opposition are about to move, because all we are talking about doing at the moment is amending the objects of the act.

What we are about to hear from Senator Parer are amendments that, in fact, relate to nothing the Morris committee recommended, that actually get to the very centre of the act, and that is the functions of the organisation—not the objects of an act but the very functions of the organisation. Find this in the Morris committee report or anything like it! Because this is not ambiguous; this is unblushingly dual function—the very thing that Ralph Nader is preaching against in the United States and which the opposition, and I have quoted just three examples of it, are saying should not happen. It is not simply `economical and effective'. Anyone who speaks the English language knows the inferences that we all place—it is a subtle language and deliberately so—on `economical'. But there is nothing ambiguous about `promotes and fosters civil aviation'.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the second amendment.

—They all have to be read together, Senator Parer. In a court they all have equal effect. That is the object of the safety regulator—to promote and foster civil aviation. As I just said, I anticipate that if this amendment is carried—not that it will be accepted in the House of Representatives because it fundamentally destroys the very purpose of splitting the organisation into two—if the safety regulatory arm, not the commercial arm, of the organisation has to promote and foster civil aviation, what has suddenly happened, Senator Parer, to the concern that has been at the centre of the opposition's criticisms over the last 12 months about the unholy concern the Civil Aviation Authority has had with the commercial operations of airline operators, which is why the thing got split into two?

PARA.TAB: It is, in my view, certain that if this should be carried and accepted by the government—it certainly will not be accepted by the government—if it got put into law the way the opposition wants to see it and if an airline operator at some future stage under this proposed amendment to the actual functions of the organisation, the centrepiece of the bill, is charged with an offence of severely breaching safety regulation, no doubt one of the arguments that will be put in court would be that the action is against the functions of CASA of `promoting and fostering civil aviation'. It is this dual responsibility concern raised by you and the coalition, and responded to very decisively by the minister, that is being taken apart in these two bills, I would have thought, with your total support considering everything you have said in the last year.

I would like to hear from you, Senator Parer, at the appropriate time on the next amendment where you find a recommendation from the Morris committee that you would actually insert into the CASA Act, not the commercial arm of the organisation, into the safety regulatory side of the organisation, a responsibility in its function of not just looking after safety but `promoting and fostering civil aviation'. I tell you: it is not in there; it does not even come close in the Morris committee's report.

In respect of your furphies about accountability, as the second reading speech of the minister explained, the government decided that the industry's legitimate concerns about doing it properly, effectively and efficiently would be best addressed if the relevant provisions in the legislative instruments bill were brought forward in their application to CASA. These provide for full public consultation and cost benefit analysis of regulatory changes and they represent a clear and unqualified means of taking costs into account in developing safety regulations. The second reading speech has given a commitment by the minister that he will issue a direction to this effect immediately CASA is established.

There is no need to bring in the very important considerations—and I do not think anyone could accuse me of being unconcerned about these over the years—of having a cost effective system. I just indicated in debate that one of the things the CAA did accomplish was to bring down its charges by hundreds of millions of dollars—that was certainly accomplished. But all this business of only reacting, Senator Parer, when there were some accidents is a nonsense.

You know as well as I do that the very purpose of appointing Captain Terrell with all of the years of experience that he had as a check and training captain with one of our major airlines was for the very purpose of chairing a safety subcommittee of the board, because of concerns in the government then that there was too much of a concentration on fostering and promoting the civil aviation side of the operation rather than an undiluted safety concern. That is the very reason that the minister acted to split the organisations, with the commercial arm clearly and unblushingly separated from the safety arm.

In other words, out of everything you have called for in the past 12 months, you now want to put back a responsibility on the safety regulator to both `promote and foster civil aviation' which is more properly a commercial concern. You will find that, Senator Parer, nowhere in the Morris committee's report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am getting worried about Senator Collins. He has become incredibly erratic. It is quite indicative of where this government has gone. Panic buttons are being pushed all over the place and all the efforts they have made to try to win back the electorate have been falling over one by one. As someone said the other day—I think it was my leader, John Howard—they fired all the big guns and they have all been fizzers. They have even fired Brian Howe and that looks like being a fizzer too. But it just shows the erraticism of the government.

PARA.TAB: I will go back—he has jumped the gun; he has gone to the next amendment. I will be happy to talk about that when he gets to it. I presume that when we get to that next amendment, Senator Bob Collins will get up and repeat exactly what he said in this particular part. I draw his attention to this fact: he may not wish CASA to be effective and economic, because he obviously does not like those words; he does not want it to be effective and economic.

TALK.START.PARA: —Promoting civil aviation.

—That is the next amendment, Senator Collins, and we will get to that. The other thing is that he does not like recognising the need for more people to benefit from civil aviation—he takes exception to those words.

PARA.TAB: It is curious. In the House of Representatives report they offered two options: one included the words `effective and economic'; and the second one deleted those words. We had great difficulty with this. Why would you say any organisation should not be effective and economic? But they did leave in the words in the first and second option, `while recognising the need for more people to benefit from civil aviation.'

There is enormous scope for people. Australia has always benefited from civil aviation and there is no reason why it should not continue to do so. All those words do is support that particular aspiration—that not only the general aviation industry, not only the major airlines but also the general public would like to get the benefits that come within civil aviation.
I cannot say much more except that I am amazed that a minister would say that a department should not be economic and not be effective.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said nothing of the sort; I said quite the reverse.

—He does not like the words. He does not want it to be economic. I think he referred to the cost benefit analysis. I am quite aware of that because it is the intention, after the legislation is passed, for the minister to say that any regulations, new or amended, should be subject to a cost benefit analysis. But that flies in the very face of what the minister just said. It flies in his face. On the one hand, he is saying that `economic' means `affordable', which is not true; and, on the other hand, he is saying, `Let's have a cost benefit analysis which goes back to the affordable stage.' We all can play with words and semantics.

PARA.TAB: After all the gusto and all the blustering, when it comes to the bottom line you are saying that you do not like us to include words that say that an organisation should be effective and economic, and the antithesis is to be ineffective and uneconomic. Ex-Senator Walsh would have a real picnic with you on this, Minister. I remember him debating, as you might recall, that the opposite of rational was irrational. I think that description best describes you and this government because, if you object to those particular words, you are showing a degree of irrationality that would make ex-Senator Walsh write a wonderful column in a coming issue of the Financial Review.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am moved to rise and support Senator Parer. I cannot understand the position of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins). Has he really got the right piece of paper in front of him? Does he know what those words mean? They are not in any way exceptional. I will read the words:

PARA.TAB: The main object of this Act is to establish a regulatory framework for maintaining, enhancing and promoting the safety of civil aviation in an ineffective and economical way—

SPEECH.PARA: Who could find fault with that? Surely that is what the act is about—
with particular emphasis on preventing aviation accidents and incidents whilst recognising the need for more people to benefit from civil aviation.

That is a proper function for the government to impose on the new authority, the CASA. I think the most charitable thing the chamber can do, if the minister is to go down the line that he is taking, is to ask him to pause, read the amendment, take a deep breath and say that he supports it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator MacGibbon was late to the chamber, and I will not do as Senator Parer suggested. I will not read just three—
—That makes a change.

—No, I will not read out again, unless provoked—and Senator Parer has got the hide to talk about theatre—three of the quotes from some of the over-the-top statements that have been made by the coalition about the central problem of confusing commercialisation with safety. With respect, Senator MacGibbon, have a look at what Senator Parer said about our alleged disregard for `effective' and `efficient' and at what is being proposed by the government in terms of the purposes of the board—that is, the government is proposing that CASA perform its functions in a proper, efficient and effective manner.

PARA.TAB: The minister has made clear in his second reading speech precisely how he will do that. Of course cost is important. Senator MacGibbon would recall as well as I would many of the committees that this Senate sat through talking about affordable safety and hearing the criticisms that I think were very unfairly heaped on Dick Smith for those statements. As Dick Smith pointed out, affordability has also been—and always has been in the real world—a factor of any safety regulation, whether it is road safety or air safety; otherwise, as Dick Smith used to say, you would insist that every aircraft in the world had four engines and not one.

There has always been an element of affordability. Senator MacGibbon, it is the word `economical' that we object to in all the inferences that that has. As a speaker of the normal English language, I know what the inferences of `economical' are. We are saying `effective' and `efficient' as understood. Senator Macgibbon, I read the definition into the Hansard. Have a look at the actual definitions of those words by the federal Department of Finance. These are proper accountability words that are well understood by the bureaucracy and the courts.

What puzzled me most was the wording. Senator MacGibbon, perhaps I could refer it to you—I do not know whether you left a few words out. I was quite open about the fact that I was not even familiar with these amendments until I walked into the chamber. The curious wording—and it is very curious; more so than `economical'—is this tag on the end of the objectives: `more people to benefit from civil aviation'. What does that mean precisely? Why don't you at least say, `We will not be supporting these objectives. We will support the government's objectives'? But to make it clear that safety is indeed the main priority of the safety side of the organisation, as well it being efficient and effective in paying for it, why don't you say something like `more people to benefit from a safe system of civil aviation'? The words there trail off into midair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because it's already covered in the previous words.

—This is a very important section, Senator Parer. This is the object of the act. When you are talking about more people benefiting—in some amorphous way—from civil aviation, why don't you at least re-emphasise that what we want them to benefit from is a safe system of civil aviation?

—If the nub of the concern of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins) is the word `economic', I should perhaps take the time to explain that we are concerned that the new authority directs its activities in an efficient way where those efforts ought to be applied. One of the great criticisms of the present regulatory arm of the Civil Aviation Authority is that it misdirects the resources it has and, because of the misdirection, it does not have enough people in the relevant areas. Something like 24 per cent or higher—I forget the figures—of airworthiness surveillance is directed towards the private sector, where the risk to the travelling public is minimal.

PARA.TAB: It is this misdirection within the Civil Aviation Authority which is at the heart of the opposition's point on this. If the Civil Aviation Authority has a direction to do some sort of analysis as to where it puts its efforts—because its efforts in turn are related to the costs of the operation—we will be very happy. But, at the moment, we see a very inefficient organisation as a consequence of the legislation that is on the books at the present time. In that light, I am sure that the minister would agree with the amendment.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Parer's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Schedule 1, page 14, item 23, after proposed subsection 9A(2), add the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: "(3) Subject to subsection (1), CASA must exercise its powers and perform its functions in a manner that, as far as practicable:

TAB.TAB: (a)is economical and effective; and
(b)promotes and fosters civil aviation.".

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Collins mentioned earlier, this amendment is a functions clause. It says that CASA must exercise its powers subject to subsection 1. That is very important. Subsection 1 relates to safety being the priority. Subject to safety being the priority, CASA must exercise its powers and perform its functions in a manner that, as far as is practicable, is economical and effective and that promotes and fosters civil aviation.

PARA.TAB: The CAA has a history of imposing regulations on the industry, without taking into account the cost of complying with them. Its perceived culture is often incomprehensible to the operators that it regulates. Senator Collins would know that from his own Darwin background. The coalition believes CASA should be required to perform its functions in a way that promotes and fosters civil aviation. To clarify that, there is no intention that the department should set up a separate organisation to go around promoting and fostering. In the exercising of its powers, which are very important in controlling safety, it should take on board the fact that the industry itself needs to be promoted and fostered.

The amendment is not identical to the American requirement, but it is constructed so that the safety of air navigation remains the authority's principal responsibility. There is no doubt about that. The `promote and foster' clause is subject to subsection 9A(2), where CASA must regard the safety of air navigation as its most important consideration. Interestingly enough, subsection 9A(2), a government subsection, states that CASA must perform its functions so that the environment is protected. If the government's argument about my amendment is correct, its argument must also apply to subsection 9A(2), which states that CASA should take the environment into account. All we are saying is that CASA should be economical and effective and that it should promote and foster civil aviation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated earlier, the government will be strongly opposing these amendments. We find them even more objectionable than changing the objects of the act because they go one step further. This is the heart of the bill, the heart of the separate organisation that will now unblushingly concentrate on air safety and not on commercialism. The amendments, which do not relate to anything in the Morris committee recommendations, go further than saying that CASA has to be economical and effective. They say that CASA has to have the dual role of promoting and fostering civil aviation.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps I should have made this clearer earlier: the government's concerns and my own personal concerns have been raised to very great heights indeed. I have seen statements made by the shadow minister over the last 12 months. In fact, I have just read three of them into the Hansard. Safety was the CAA's primary responsibility. The old CAA is exactly the same. The concern that Mr Sharp had was that CAA officers were more concerned about maintaining the viability of a particular airline, and these were the border line operators. I can find a dozen quotes of where Mr Sharp said that.

We were extremely alarmed to read what Mr Sharp said, after all that he said about viability being more important than safety for the CAA in keeping airline operators in the air rather than grounding them. This is what Mr Sharp said in the House of Representatives in debating these amendments:

SPEECH.PARA: CASA—
that is not the commercial arm, that is the safety arm, should—
do whatever it can to assist in fostering the industry; to assist the industry to, if you like, remain viable.
That is what the shadow minister said and that is why we will be opposing these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Future historians, in looking at Australian civil aviation, will be quite astonished in future years to read the minister's comments in relation to this amendment before the chamber at present. By way of explanation, I should say that the government altered the program today and I did not know this bill was coming on, otherwise I would have had quite a deal to say at the second reading stage. Somewhat late in the debate, I want to make a contribution to support Senator Parer's excellent amendment that he has moved on behalf of the opposition.

PARA.TAB: It really is not valid for the minister to hold the Morris committee report up as some sort of guide of best practice in aviation. It is an interesting report but in no sense does it incorporate all that needs to be done for the benefit of aviation in this country. With respect, the minister is still missing the point when he argues that because there is a requirement in the amendment for CASA to operate in an economic and effective manner, that means keeping airlines in the air that are unsafe. With the best will in the world, there is no logical connection between what Senator Parer and I are saying and the interpretation the minister is putting on it. I presume that the minister must be overtired or something.

We want the civil aviation regulatory authority to operate in an efficient and economical way for those in the aviation industry. Anyone who has ever operated, owned and maintained an aeroplane knows the often illogical constraints that are put on them from a modification point of view by the Civil Aviation Authority, allegedly in the interests of safety. I think of one of many instances that have happened to me in the last 30 years. One of them relates to the mandatory changing of hoses in the engine compartment of the aircraft I own. The particular manufacturer's hoses that were fitted to my aircraft were Dunlop hoses that had a wall thickness of about one inch. Because they were more than five years old—the hoses that I had fitted were actually new; they had been in service for about 12 months, but they had been manufactured outside the five-year period—I had to remove them at very considerable expense and replace them with an American aeroquip type hose.

Forgetting about the cost that I had to bear for the hose, the point was that there was a degradation in safety and there is a degradation in safety in my aeroplane at present as a consequence of that dogmatic requirement that the hose had to be changed. The hose that was changed would have survived a fire to a far higher temperature for a matter of hours. The approved hose that it is now fitted with, which keeps the Civil Aviation Authority very happy, is a hose that will withstand a much lower temperature for minutes, whereas the hose that was perfectly satisfactory in its place would have survived a far higher temperature for a matter of hours. There are numerous examples of that nature. It is perfectly proper for the opposition to require the regulatory authority to operate in an economical and effective manner, subject of course to the overriding requirement of safety as the primary concern of the authority.

There is a far more intangible and important reason behind this amendment than the minister recognises. Sadly, what we have in Australia is a regulatory authority which is openly antagonistic to the aviation industry. As someone who moves around the world quite a bit and has had a very long interest in aviation, I know of no other country where the regulatory authority has daggers drawn for the aviation industry.

The real message behind this amendment that Senator Parer is moving to promote and foster civil aviation in Australia is to engender some feeling of cooperation between the regulatory authority and the industry that it should regulate—to have an amicable partnership between the two. Unless you have that, I do not care how many laws you pass through the parliament and I do not care how draconian the penalties that the regulatory authority has, you simply cannot make the rules work without the cooperation of those you are trying to rule.

It is important that there is a change in the atmosphere—the way the civil aviation regulatory authority approaches the aviation industry in this country. It relates very much to safety because when you have this antagonistic adversarial attitude where you have surveyors and field investigators who quite openly boast in public that one should never trust a pilot because pilots always lie, it just shows the extent of the poisonous atmosphere between the regulatory authority and the aviation industry in Australia. That has a very direct impact on safety. Regrettably, at present we have reached a situation where the aviation industry as a matter of policy restricts all contact with the regulatory authority. It does not want to talk to it unless it is forced to. There is a degree of deception in the industry because it is very hard out there.

As a consequence of the economic policies of this government, it is hard to earn a living. People like the third level and commuter operators, to say nothing of the major airlines, are extremely cost conscious and they are not talking to the Civil Aviation Authority when they have problems. They are not saying that they have these defects and are finding these failures with equipment or operational procedures. They are going their own way and they are concealing things because of the intense antipathy between the industry and the authority. That is wrong. You can never promote safety while that exists. There must be a cooperative partnership between the regulatory authority and the industry.

At the end of the day, safety is an attitude of mind and an attitude of cooperation. It is not a matter of law and it is not a matter of allowing people flashing a CAA badge to kick a door down and go in and see files and summarily remove the licence from pilots and all the other thousand and one draconian acts that this government, particularly under Senator Collins, has introduced into aviation.

As a pilot and an aircraft owner, someone involved deeply in the industry for over 30 years as a private individual, I find the climate totally unacceptable and objectionable. It is not the climate that existed when I first learnt to fly or bought my first aircraft.

I look forward to a time when we can have an equal partnership between those in the industry and those in the regulatory authority. I cannot conceive of any good coming out of the present atmosphere that we have. I can only see concealment, evasion and non-cooperation, with a disastrous effect in the longer term on the safety of aviation in this country.

I genuinely beseech the minister to think about this motion that is before the chamber at present and support it as enthusiastically as he can because in no way is it at variance with, or contradicts, any of the things that he genuinely wants to see for aviation in Australia.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Parer's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3.Schedule 1, page 17, after item 51, insert the following item:

PARA.TAB: Omit the subsection, substitute:
`(1) No person may operate an aircraft in a careless or reckless manner so as to endanger the life of another person.'.".

SPEECH.PARA: 4.Schedule 1, page 17, after item 51, insert the following item:

PARA.TAB: "51B. Subsection 20A (2):
Omit the subsection, substitute:
`(2) No person may operate an aircraft in a careless or reckless manner so as to endanger the person or property of another person.'.".

SPEECH.PARA: 5.Schedule 1, page 36, item 135, omit the item, substitute the following item:

PARA.TAB: `Repeal the section, substitute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Tabling of directions or notices of the Minister

PARA.TAB: `96. Where the Minister gives a direction under section 12, 12B or 45 or a notice under section 12A, the Minister shall cause a copy of the direction or notice to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the giving of the direction or the notice.'.".

SPEECH.PARA: It is in the interests of the Senate that we treat these amendments cognately. The first two amendments refer to a person not operating an aircraft in a careless or reckless manner so as to endanger the life or property of another person. The third of these amendments relates to the CASA bill. Regrettably, we are not yet in a position to move to the Air Services Bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate Senator Parer's courtesy in moving the amendments cognately. It would be nice to get this legislation through. We oppose these amendments. I know we do not have the numbers on any of them, and Senator Parer has. We will not be calling divisions on them.

—I want to support Senator Parer. The need for these amendments would never have arisen if we had a civil aviation authority with any feeling at all for the aviation industry. The proposals that led to these amendments were really quite indefensible. In the interests of time, I will say no more. I wish we had had support for the earlier amendments in the way we have had it for these because the aviation industry will be much better as a consequence of passing these amendments into legislation.
—I support these amendments, as I supported the previous two.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Progress reported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon, in moving to take note of an answer by Senator Bolkus relating to Dr Carmen Lawrence, I did say, amongst other things:

SPEECH.PARA: I say to you, Madam Deputy President, let her come clean on what action she took which cost the life of a very innocent woman. . .

I said at the time that the point of order was taken that I would like to read the Hansard. I have done so. Having read it, perhaps I should have said, `Let her come clean on the action which she did not take.' To put it in plain language, perhaps I should have made sure that I said, `Let her come clean on the events which cost the life of a very innocent woman.'
