SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Some 26 treaties subject to ratification are being tabled. However, when one has regard to the other international instruments which are listed in the annexure to the red today, one sees a total of 117 international instruments. Of those instruments, some are conventions, some are ILO conventions, some are amendments to treaties and some are amendments to conventions. They are all instruments which are capable of having effect under the external affairs power in section 51(xxix) of the constitution, yet we do not have those available to us. I inform the Senate that my office requested copies of all those instruments. The only ones that my office has been able to obtain so far are the 26 treaties subject to ratification. I note that Senator Kemp, Senator Abetz and Senator Woodley have had the same experience.

PARA.TAB: Recently, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has said on a number of occasions that the tabling of treaties and international instruments every six months was a satisfactory way to inform the parliament, to inform the Senate, of the treaties and conventions that Australia was considering or had signed up to. This is a totally unsatisfactory state of affairs. In fact, tonight I have only five minutes in which to comment on any one of these international instruments listed here—all 117 of them.

There is remarkable diversity contained in this document—the Conference on Disarmament, the test ban treaty, agricultural research, ILO conventions, the Antarctic, plants in the Pacific, genetic breeding, world intellectual property, international atomic energy, just to name a few. There are conventions dealing with human rights and discrimination against women, the rights of the child, and various amendments to that dealing with child labour and the like. So an extremely diverse area is covered by these international instruments and we have them all lobbed on us, as it were, in one bundle—all 117 of them—and this is the chance we get to comment on them.This is entirely unsatisfactory. The only consolation I take is that the external affairs power is being considered by the Legal and Constitutional References Committee.

This is evidence as to why there is disquiet in the community at large in relation to the whole treaty signing process, the whole negotiation process but, more importantly, the lack of scrutiny as to how we sign up to international instruments. This is what the representatives of the Australian people get—five minutes in which to comment on 117 international instruments on the diverse subjects that I have mentioned. I think it is entirely unsatisfactory and the government must rethink how it deals with this.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not planning to intervene in the debate tonight but I was very much taken by the comments of my colleague Senator Ellison, who drew our attention to the fact that over 110 international instruments and treaties have been brought to the attention of the Senate today. This shows what a total farce the current system is. Of the ones which the government has apparently decided to ratify, we at least get one page which tells us what is included in the particular treaty. But there is no explanation for the rest of them—we have a heading and a contact number. If ever there was a demonstration of the need to get some proper process in the consideration of treaties, the tabling today of over 110 international instruments demonstrates that fact.

PARA.TAB: Mr Acting Deputy President, you have taken a great interest in the treaty making activities of this parliament. I have noted the contributions you have made on this important issue, the concern you have expressed about the complaints that this government has allowed Australians to take to UN committees and your concern about the composition and procedures of those committees. It seems to me, looking through the information which has been given to us, that a number of other UN committees may well be able to receive complaints regarding Australian domestic disputes. It only looks to me this way; I have not received any advice on it. In fact, it is impossible in the short time available to ascertain precisely what this government is doing.

It is interesting that it was regarded as an enormous initiative and leap forward that the government decided nine to 12 months ago to tell the parliament what particular treaties it was planning to negotiate. This was the great leap forward by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans, and the Attorney-General, Mr Lavarch, in allowing greater scrutiny by the Senate—they would actually inform us of current treaty negotiations under way. I have five minutes in which to address over 110 instruments which have now been notified to the Senate. Of course that is an utterly impossible process.

Senator Evans, I am pleased to say, has comprehensively lost the debate on the role that parliament should play in relation to international treaties. Senator Evans, Michael Lavarch and the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, are the only people still standing who believe that there should not be in this parliament some proper process by which it can be brought to the attention of the parliament precisely the types of treaties which this government is planning to negotiate and the impact this will have on the Australian community.

I do not often praise the Democrats in this chamber. However, the Democrats have recognised that the current procedure by which parliament is involved in the treaty making process is entirely inadequate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Appalling.
—Senator Woodley says that it is appalling. As I said, Senator Gareth Evans, Mr Lavarch and Mr Keating would be the last people standing who believe that parliament should have no particular role.

PARA.TAB: I bring once again to the attention of the parliament the fact that this process is a total farce. Explanations are not even given to this parliament for the very wide range of treaties that are being negotiated, some of which are of great importance. I suspect that quite a number of them may well enjoy very strong support in this parliament. Some of them may be regarded as controversial. Nonetheless, the explanations are simply not there. Again, as I have urged before, something has to be done to ensure that we establish a proper process in this parliament so that we can see what Senator Evans and his colleagues are doing in the international forum.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to join with my colleagues in condemning the treaty making processes of this government. Treaty making under this government is undermining the sovereignty of this country, undermining the legislative role of the parliament and subverting the constitutional division of powers in this country between the Commonwealth and the states. It is in desperate need of reform. There must be much more public and parliamentary scrutiny of the treaty making processes in this country.

PARA.TAB: The disaster that is occurring is that the parliament is being made quite irrelevant to the treaty making process. That is important, because the treaty making process is one of law making. That is what was demonstrated in the Teoh case just recently. Great notice was served upon this government that, unbeknownst to it, it was now required to operate in its executive actions according to the 900 treaties that it has signed. It has caused absolute chaos in the law of Australia.

The government regularly accuses us of having no policies. That is its current mantra. I want to commend to the Senate a speech by the esteemed shadow minister for foreign affairs, who spoke at a constitutional centenary conference just recently on this very subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —And a good speech it was.

—It was an outstanding speech in which he set forth the case for reform of treaty making processes in this country in a most comprehensive manner. He set out the reform program that a coalition government will implement when it gets into government very soon. It also gives the lie to the constant mantra from the government that we have no policies.

PARA.TAB: The proposals put forward by Mr Downer on this issue include the preparation of cost benefit analyses of treaties prior to signature, which is a most important reform, and the tabling of treaties with the proper provision for debate. As my colleagues have said, to give people in this chamber five minutes each out of a total of half an hour to talk about the treaties which this government just contemptuously throws on the table in this chamber is quite inadequate.

The establishment of a treaties council as part of the Council of Australian Governments will be an important reform of the next coalition government. There will be the implementation of domestic legislation prior to the ratification of treaties; a joint house treaties committee; and, most importantly—I am very pleased to see that this was put forward by the shadow foreign affairs minister—the parliamentary ratification of treaties. As a former foreign affairs officer, Mr Downer has paid respect to the proper role of government in this area. But, because of the actions of the government over the last 12 years, he has been brought to the view that it is now important that there be a proper process of the parliament ratifying treaties. That has been amply demonstrated by the consequences of the Teoh case.

The current treaty making processes involve dictatorial behaviour of the worst kind. We really have a situation where the laws of this country are changed simply by the stroke of a ministerial pen. For the government to be running its whole republican agenda on the issue of sovereignty is absolutely and utterly laughable when we see the sovereignty of this country being stripped away by the whole treaty making process. The coalition will, upon its entry to government, restore the parliament to its proper role in the processes of law making in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to follow on from what Senator Minchin and Senator Kemp have said. They have put forward protests which have been heard over the radio. This is a political debate, and they ought to go through. But both Senator Kemp and Senator Minchin should have given some praise to their colleagues Senator Ellison and Senator Abetz, who are doing sterling work on the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee. The reason they did not is that they have not quite kept up with the pace that the Legal and Constitutional Committee is setting. Senator Abetz would agree that it sets a very vigorous pace, including considering the treaty making power of the parliament and the role that the executive plays in it.

PARA.TAB: There is a move to see that parliament plays a bigger role in external affairs than it has hitherto and which was traditional in England. I see that Senator Abetz is here. I praise him for his work. I hope that Senator Ellison is listening to this. I praise his efforts as well as those of people on my side, such as Senator McKiernan, whom Senator Kemp mentioned, and Senator Neal.

In that context, I should also give considerable praise to our secretariat, which comprises Anne Twomey, Steven Bull and Peter Thomson. They have a great amount of work to do and have spent considerable time and effort on doing work in this area. I might mention in this context—Senator Ellison and Senator Abetz would agree—that the people from the department who have come before the committee have been very cooperative and very anxious to accommodate the wishes of the committee and to accommodate a position where parliament can play a bigger role.

There has been a considerable listing—criticism has been made of it—of the treaties table in the Senate. It was pointed out to us that it requires a lot of work. It was suggested by Senator Abetz that the treaties should be tabled one by one. That was not put aside, but it was stated that there is a lot of work in doing what was done here today in the listing of these treaties. I say out of fairness to the department that it is willing to listen and take on board what parliament has to say, particularly through its Legal and Constitutional Committee. It would be wrong not to acknowledge in this speech its efforts.

I do not think this is an area where, as it were, there is great opposition to giving parliament a greater role. The Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch), the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) have been mentioned in this context. That is not the situation; it is not that they oppose reform. The reality is that in foreign affairs there is a tradition that that role is conducted by the executive. Historically, the parliament had to approve the expenditure by government of sixpence, but the king could take the country to war. Certainly that situation has changed and ought to have changed. But it is proper to point out that it is not as though the executive has usurped the power that parliament used to have. It is rather a question of parliament taking on its duties in the light of changing conditions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The tabling today in the Senate of 26 treaties which are currently subject to ratification serves to highlight the need for better mechanisms for parliamentary scrutiny of these treaties which the Australian government enters into. The Senate currently has before it legislation which would enable more adequate and meaningful scrutiny to be given to any of these treaties. It was recently introduced by my Democrat colleague Senator Vicki Bourne. I believe such a mechanism is very much needed, and I urge the Senate to give its support to Senator Bourne's bill at the earliest opportunity.

PARA.TAB: A quick glimpse at just a few of these treaties shows that they are substantial documents and they are dealing with what, to some, may seem minor subjects, but which are not. For example, among the various treaties tabled, there is an agreement between Australia and Japan relating to Japanese tuna long-line fishing in Australian waters. It is only a subsidiary agreement to a previous agreement, but it is 10 pages in length. A question on notice I recently asked of the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) established that tuna long-line fishing kills a huge number of albatross each year and is driving such albatross species close to extinction. I do not know whether or not this agreement addresses this issue at all. It may add to the problem, or it might help alleviate it. I simply do not know.

However, the real point is that the parliament is inhibited by overload and by the presentation in this form of so many treaties at one time. If we believe there is a problem of any sort with this treaty or any of the other treaties tabled today, there is nothing we can do about it. In effect, on each and every one, the government is saying to the Senate and to the people of Australia, `Trust us.' Given the enormous potential implications of many treaties for Australia and the globe's environment, economy and overall security, it is ridiculous that they are all implemented without any form of scrutiny.

Among the other treaties tabled today are ones which deal with the use of the Shoalwater Bay training facilities by the Singapore armed forces; an energy charter and protocol on energy efficiency and related environmental aspects, which is close to 200 pages long; and an international tropical timber agreement, which is 40 pages long. None of these are minor matters, yet they are not able to be considered by the Senate in any meaningful way.

I am not opposed to the adoption of international agreements. On the contrary, the Democrats believe it is crucial that issues be considered on a global scale, and Australia should be involved in the consideration of these issues at a national government level. I am not even suggesting that the Senate knows better than the government what should be in such agreements, but what the Democrats are saying is that there should be a role for the parliament, particularly for the Senate as a house of review. This is the purpose for which the Senate was established—as an elected chamber which would serve as a check on government. This is why the Senate should support Senator Bourne's bill, for it provides a mechanism for scrutiny of the actions and decisions of government on issues which are of national and global importance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to take away the speaking rights of any other speaker, but I wanted to ask for some clarification. Normally when we get lists of treaties, if we speak on a particular treaty, that particular treaty is reserved for the next time it comes up for consideration, which might be some time from now. So, not wishing to take away the speaking rights of any other speakers, I was wondering if I might seek leave to take note of Nos 1 to 26 individually and seek leave to continue my remarks.
—That has already been done.

—No. What I am saying is that it should be for each individual one, so that when it comes up we have the right to speak for five minutes on each treaty, rather than this ridiculous situation whereby each speaker has five minutes to speak on the whole lot. I am asking whether I can take note individually of treaties Nos 1 to 26 and seek leave to continue my remarks. That means that each speaker will then have five minutes to speak on each treaty, and a person can choose which treaty they want to speak about.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—You can do that, Senator Margetts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Therefore, under item 4, I propose that the Senate take note of each treaty individually. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to join in discussion in relation to—
—Move a motion in relation to item No. 4.
—I was going to do that at the conclusion of my remarks in relation to those.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—No, you need to do that at the commencement, Senator Abetz.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are we still considering item No. 4?
—Senator Margetts sought leave to continue her remarks.
—So that has closed off the debate today?
—You can still move to item No. 5, Senator Abetz.
—What I was hoping to do was to make remarks in relation to item No. 4 and then ask for leave to continue my remarks in relation to item No. 5, as listed on the red.
—I would suggest that you would need to seek leave in relation to item 4.
—I will not, because when item No. 4 comes back up, undoubtedly I will be able to join in the debate on that occasion. Therefore, I will address myself to item No. 5, and move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: My desire was to talk in relation to both matters but, of course, time does not allow me to do so. We have had a very shoddy treatment of the Senate today by the government's tabling of documents. First of all, we had the 26 treaties which have been referred to by Senator Margetts and other speakers. Now I turn to item 5 on the red, which deals with `Multilateral Treaties Under Negotiation or Under Consideration for Australian Government Signature or Adherence (see pages 13—19)'. We are dealing, literally, with six pages of fairly tightly typewritten treaties and multilateral agreements to which Australia is already a signatory but to which alterations are being sought.

PARA.TAB: I was interested in some of those, so I sought from the Table Office advice in relation to some of these to get those documents. I was unable to do so. My office literally spent hours this afternoon pursuing these treaties and the changes that were being proposed. Indeed, it was as a result of all the phone calls—I think 20 in all—that my staff made that Senator Sherry came into the chamber to indicate that there was an error in relation to the government's agenda for the day in relation to this matter and that really what should have been tabled was, in fact, the document of the six pages that were attached to today's agenda or what is called `the government's red'.

That is no way to conduct government business. It is no way to conduct the international treaty making processes of this country. I still do not know in relation to those six pages, dealing literally with tens of treaties, exactly what is being proposed, why it is being proposed, and why it is important that these alterations be made. Standing in this place as a representative of not only the people of Tasmania but also the people of Australia, I believe I have a right to know, and I ought to be able to get that information without the need for my staff to make 20 phone calls during the afternoon and still be no better off.

I happen to have, for better or worse, the status of a senator. What on earth would the average person in the street do, after having made those 20 phone calls and been given the run around from the Table Office—and I do not blame them—and then to the various departments and ministerial offices, only to be given information which was deliberately removed from some of this documentation; namely, the telephone numbers and contact persons in relation to some of these treaties? The document we have has had those removed, but Foreign Affairs was able to fax it to our office finally, indicating all the contact persons that we could talk to about this. It really is indicative of the high-handed way this government deals with treaties. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Likewise, under item 5, sections 1, 2, 3, and 4, I propose that the Senate takes note of each individual item. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.20 p.m., I propose the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to take this opportunity to respond to the extraordinary attack on me in the House of Representatives today by the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Frank Walker. In speaking to the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1995, the minister said some quite outrageous things. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I know there is a group of people within the coalition parties that are probably closely aligned with organisations such as the League of Rights and that are campaigning actively against compulsory voting.

PARA.TAB: Senator Minchin has been very active in this regard.

SPEECH.PARA: He went on to say that members of the opposition should:

stop associating, I might add, as Senator Minchin did, with the League of Rights. He stood up on a public platform and joined with those ultra-Fascist, Nazi-like people in trying to bring down our democratic system. Compulsory voting is one of the key elements of democracy in this country and it should stay that way.

I cannot believe that a minister of the Crown is speaking in this way about Her Majesty's loyal opposition, or members of it. According to Mr Walker—Queen's Counsel, I note; the greatest hypocrite of all—everyone in this country who supports voluntary voting is, apparently, therefore un-Australian and also fascist. That is what we are being told by Mr Walker.

PARA.TAB: I have a pretty thick skin—when you have people like Mr Walker around, you need it—but these sorts of attacks are really the most extraordinary, unfair and outrageous attack. What we have from Mr Walker is propaganda of the worst kind: telling the most outrageous lie in a way that completely reverses the truth.

I take this opportunity to reject absolutely any association with the League of Rights, as asserted by Mr Walker in his comments today. I have never knowingly spoken at a League of Rights meeting. In fact, it is members of Mr Walker's own party who quite openly speak to the League of Rights. It is Mr Graeme Campbell, the Labor member, who speaks to the League of Rights.

I regard the anti-semitism of the League of Rights as utterly offensive and objectionable. My godfather is Jewish. I totally reject and am quite offended by what Mr Walker said about me in the context of that particular organisation. I should also say that it happens to be news to me that the League of Rights supports voluntary voting. I was not aware of that. In fact, I do not think it is true.

It is certainly true that I spoke to a meeting of the Network for Christian Values, an organisation headquartered in Canberra which supports voluntary voting. I am delighted that it does support it. It is offensive to that organisation to assert, as, presumably, Mr Walker does, that that organisation is somehow ultra-fascist and Nazi-like.

What are we to make of other public figures who support voluntary voting? Paddy McGuinness, Derryn Hinch, the Labor Party's own former pollster Rod Cameron, former leader of the Australian Democrats Don Chipp—these are all public supporters of voluntary voting. According to Mr Walker, these people are also fascists and un-Australian.

The Nazi-like behaviour in this country is actually coming from this government, from people like Mr Walker. Under this Labor regime, apparently, if you disagree with any of its policies you are un-Australian. The last time we heard a statement like that was from the National Socialist Party of Germany in the 1930s. It is McCarthyism. The committee which McCarthy chaired in the United States was called the House Un-American Activities Committee. Are we about to have a committee like that set up in this country, so that anyone who disagrees with Labor will be dragged before the Senate Un-Australian Activities Committee? Is that the next step on the path to the great National Socialist state which this Labor Party is trying to build?

The Labor Party is the true authoritarian in this country. What could be more authoritarian and less democratic than a system in which you are compelled to vote. Hardly any other country in the world operates such a system. It is Mr Walker QC who is responsible for putting in gaol people who do not comply with his laws that compel us to vote. As I have publicly reported, at least 41 Australians went to gaol because they chose not to vote at the last federal election. They went to gaol because of the law over which Mr Walker presides and for which he is responsible—the law that says, `You shall vote or pay the fine. If you do not pay the fine, you go to gaol.'

The essence of democracy is the right to vote and that must embrace the right not to vote. In a democracy you must have the right to choose whether to exercise your franchise. In this country you are denied that right. It is this Labor government that presides over that system. Labor is denying every Australian the right to choose whether or not to vote. It is nothing more than naked self-interest on the part of the Labor Party. Labor suffers from the delusion that it is the beneficiary of compulsory voting; therefore, the system must be maintained at all costs.

We are one of the very few democracies in this world that maintains this offensive law. All the world's major democracies have a system of voluntary voting. Their citizens have the right to choose whether or not to vote. Great Britain, France, Germany, the United States, Canada, New Zealand—the list of the countries that have voluntary voting is endless. The ones that have our offensive system of compulsory voting you can name on one hand.

Labor is the true authoritarian in this country. Under the Labor government you can go to gaol if you choose not to vote. Under the Racial Hatred Bill, you can go to gaol if you exercise your right to freedom of speech. It is Labor that tried to destroy the right to advertise your political opinions, a law that was thrown out by the High Court. Under this government it is an offence to advocate an informal vote—an unknown but offensive invasion of the right to free speech in this country.

It is this government which is behaving in a Nazi-like fashion, even to the point of accusing anybody who disagrees with it of being un-Australian. I am absolutely offended by Mr Walker's comments today. They are a disgrace but they reveal to the Australian people the very ugly side of this Labor government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to the Senate about ongoing concerns over the large scale land clearing in parts of Queensland. Along with other environmentalists, the Australian Democrats have raised concerns about the major threat being posed to, amongst other species, the mahogany glider—already recognised as a highly endangered species—by the clearing of some of the glider's few remaining habitat areas. Despite some belated action by the Queensland government, this threat to the glider has not been removed. Excessive or inappropriate land clearing can cause major danger, not just to the mahogany glider, but to a wide variety of other animals and to the quality of the land and water upon which we all depend.

PARA.TAB: I have received information through the North Queensland Conservation Council, based in Townsville, that some widespread clearing is currently happening in the Burdekin region near Ayr. The NQCC has received reports that the area being cleared is a koala habitat. The report spoke of koalas falling out of trees onto the roofs of the bulldozers, of those same bulldozers knocking the trees over, and of dead koalas being strewn over the ground and on the nearby roads.

Efforts are currently being made to confirm these reports. I am loath to criticise too strongly a specific activity without it being totally verified but I believe that the whole problem of excessive land clearing is so urgent and so critical that we cannot take the risk of waiting until it is too late.

The Democrats call on the Queensland government to ensure that significant habitat areas are protected by interim conservation orders to ensure that these areas are not cleared. Any action taken so far has been piecemeal and far too slow.

I know that the majority of farmers are responsible custodians of the land. I also recognise the economic pressures which weigh so heavily on so many of them. The Senate's Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee, of which I am a member, has been conducting an inquiry into land care issues. I have witnessed first-hand some of the great things being done by people in rural areas in trying to look after the land and restore some of the damage of the past.

Nonetheless, there are undeniably many major problems caused by some land management practices. Excessive and inappropriate land clearing is one of the worst of these. I ask any farmer who is thinking of engaging in indiscriminate tree-felling to think about the value of the vegetation and of the negative environmental and economic consequences which may occur down the track. Farming land covers vast and important parts of Queensland and is important not just for agricultural productivity but also for environmental productivity. Both of these aims need to be kept in balance. The Democrats call on the Queensland government to act responsibly in protecting the land and the significant species habitat in that state.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak about some documentation that was delivered to senators today on behalf of the Wilderness Society (Tasmania) Inc. It is a paper entitled `Tasmanian Forests Report' accompanied by a press release from the Wilderness Society attributed to Alec Marr.

PARA.TAB: The documentation and the press release purport to represent facts, but they do nothing of the sort. Many of the claims in these documents are nothing but blatant lies. I do not know whether opposition senators received these papers.

This documentation mentions the road that runs through the Tarkine. I think everyone on this side of the chamber was opposed to what we saw as a waste of money—not necessarily because of the road—because there are so many other important roads, including tourist roads, in need of recurrent funding for repair work or upgrading.

The documentation purports to represent the views of key Australians. However, a naive reader would believe that these are facts supported by these people. Under the subheading `Woodchip industry insatiable' it says in part:

SPEECH.PARA: Over 90% of timber extracted from native forests is woodchipped. Only about 5% of logged trees end up as sawn timber.

That is complete and utter rubbish. It is a total misrepresentation of the facts. Whilst I would agree that in Tasmania too many trees are woodchipped and not enough go to the sawmills, it is certainly not true that 90 per cent of timber is woodchipped. It is ridiculous to claim the contrary. Further down there is a subheading which reads `Woodchipping hurts our economy'. The article continues:

Woodchip companies and sawmills pay Forestry Tasmania money (royalties) for the wood they take. But the money the logging companies pay for our wood falls well short of covering the cost of growing back and managing the forests.
That is simply not true. Since Forestry Tasmania has been incorporated it has returned a dividend to the state. Under the heading `Woodchipping destroys jobs' the article goes on to say:
Since woodchipping started in Tasmania, over 4,000 jobs have been lost.

That is a total and outrageous misrepresentation of the facts. Jobs have declined in the forest industry per se because of technology. Woodchipping has had very little impact on the number of jobs that existed before or after its commencement. It is unfortunate that the Wilderness Society makes all these wild assertions. The Wilderness Society and many other conservation groups have conducted some very good and effective campaigns concerning the environment. Quite often they have carried out a very important community service and have brought to the fore an awareness that we needed to have about the environment. However, it is a sad reflection on the Wilderness Society that it makes these claims and then tries to attribute them to other people.

PARA.TAB: We see outrageous claims about `Plantations ready now!'. A statement is attributed to Mr Adrian de Bruin about the softwood industry. The facts are that in the softwood industry alone there are not sufficient plantations for there to be a sustainable softwood sawmilling industry in this country. We then have a heading `National Park Forest Crisis' and the article continues:

SPEECH.PARA: Tasmanian Members of the House of Representatives, Sylvia Smith, Dick Adams and Harry Quick lobbied Mr Keating and Cabinet to allow the Hartz forests to be logged.

It is implied that those members of parliament did that in order to allow woodchipping to take place. That is complete and utter nonsense. None of those members has ever lobbied anybody for the purposes of seeing woodchips produced. What the members lobbied for—and rightly so—was to protect some of the jobs in the sawmilling industry.

PARA.TAB: Whether the Wilderness Society likes it or not, it is a fact that the sawmilling industry needs to access some of its resources from native forests. This is an important debate within the community and it ought to be run on a factual basis. I encourage the Wilderness Society and other conservation groups to campaign on facts. At the end of the day it is true that our forests are a finite resource and we need to protect as much of them as possible.

This article is unfair to the members of parliament named. It is to be distributed to some 80,000 people throughout the three electorates. It is downright dishonest. I encourage the Wilderness Society to have the intestinal fortitude to front up to this issue and deal with it in the correct manner.

We have a concern for the environment and we should pursue the issues. What would happen if I were to say that the government took the view that we do not need the film industry or arts in this country because we could save a few dollars. I am sure people like Phillip Adams would not be too happy about it. I believe that people in Tasmania have expressed a genuine concern for the environment and I know that they would not support outright lies.

I hope that in future the Wilderness Society can take a more responsible approach to the way in which it deals with this issue. We all have the same objectives in respect of the environment. It may be that we do not necessarily agree on the course that we need to follow to achieve those objectives but in fairness to all Australians we ought to try to deal with facts, not lies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise with some regret to have to respond to the most scurrilous, filthy and crude allegation that could possibly be made against a member of the federal parliament. Could I read to you, with the indulgence of the Senate, a question that was asked today by Mr Kobelke, the shadow minister for police, in the Western Australian parliament? The question was addressed to Mr Wiese, the Minister for Police in the Western Australian government. The question was as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: What action does the Minister intend to take following the Federal Police interview conducted with the Premier's political mentor Senator Crichton-Browne in Perth last Friday in relation to very serious criminal allegations that Senator Crichton-Browne had made threatening and obscene telephone calls to a federal Liberal politician in Perth and Canberra, including death threats?
Is it also true that the Liberal member is now under police protection?

If the Minister claims he is unaware of these serious matters, will he ensure that the allegations against Senator Crichton-Browne are immediately investigated by the police and appropriate action taken.

I cannot think of a more vile allegation than one of that nature. It is utterly untrue. I have never been interviewed by the Federal Police in respect to any complaint about any matter. I understand that the Federal Police will be in the next few minutes putting out a statement confirming that fact.

PARA.TAB: I will make the obvious observation that I will of course pursue all legal avenues open to me, however minute the prospect is, to ensure that my reputation and that of my family is cleared of this scurrilous allegation. Mr Kobelke has, in my view, created a new low for politics in Australia. I understand that, following the question, he conducted a press conference outside the chamber. I shall of course be reading very carefully the words he used.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, you and other honourable senators in this place will recall that about three weeks ago a statement of concern about the fact that Arthur Tunstall had made a joke about Cathy Freeman and Lionel Rose was circulated, that a large number of parliamentarians across the political spectrum signed that particular statement and that it was forwarded on to the Commonwealth Games Association. I want to read the accompanying letter that was signed by Peter Nugent and me. We were two of the people around late on that Thursday night preparing the statement of concern to the Commonwealth Games Association and, as representatives of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, we signed it as a matter of form. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr Godkin
We write on behalf of 120 parliamentarians who have signed the attached Statement of Concern about the comments made by Mr Arthur Tunstall in a `joke' about Cathy Freeman and Lionel Rose.
You will note that among the signatories are the Deputy Prime Minister—
the then Deputy Prime Minister—
Brian Howe, Leader of the Government in the Senate Gareth Evans, The Speaker of the House of Representatives—
you, Mr President—
16 Ministers including 10 Cabinet Ministers and 3 Shadow Ministers.

Senator Abetz and Senator Campbell, the opposition spokesperson for sport, were also signatories, along with a number of other members in this place and in the other place who were concerned about this. It goes on:
We believe that the level of support for this statement reflects the concern of all Australians.
Therefore, we seek your response as to how the Commonwealth Games Association intends to work to end racism in Australian sport.
That is what we asked. The response came today. It is so extraordinary and obviously totally disregards 120 parliamentarians that I want to read it into the Hansard. It is from Mr Godkin. It states:
I am responding to the `Statement of Concern' and covering letter from you dated 1 June, 1995. The aspects raised therein have been duly noted and will be transmitted to all board members.
I hope Mr Godkin will do more than transmit the information. I hope it will be raised in a priority discussion with board members for action. It continues:
Firstly, it is now common knowledge that the utterance of Arthur Tunstall of which is the subject of review, was told privately to persons by him outside a Commonwealth Games meeting.

I do not seek or attempt to condone the comments made by Arthur Tunstall or to reopen the issue other than to state that my expressions were clearly recorded on national television, radio and by the print media. Following legal advice, all board members of the Australian Commonwealth Games Association were contacted by me at the height of the saga and as it is that body who has the immediate control of the Association, their advice was followed.
It would be completely baseless to ever suggest there is the slightest element of racism within our organisation.
That is notwithstanding the said joke and not to mention another statement that was made in Canada. It goes on to say:

If the question of origin or any aspects in respect of colour or creed were to be asked of the 350 members of the Australian Team to Canada in 1994, no answers could be given. All Australian citizens have the same opportunity of team membership and are treated equally without exception.

I have attached hereto two extracts from the Commonwealth Games Federation Constitution. (Article 7 and the First paragraph of the Gleneagles Declaration) A country must pledge to abide by these undertakings to be part of that Federation.

I can say without equivocation, that this country is held in high esteem within the Commonwealth for the assistance given to those less fortunate as far as equipment, clothing and the like are concerned.
Frankly, I find that a rather paternalistic statement. It continues:
This particular aspect was practised during the last games and it is needless to say which particular countries we assisted.
During my involvement with the Commonwealth Games I have always taken pride in the fact that Australia has never been included in the countries of concern relative to any form of racism.
Until now. This letter is really a total repudiation of the serious matters that were raised by so many parliamentarians. The second last paragraph states:

In respect of the final paragraph of your letter, whilst racism is not practised within the A.C.G.A, we are fully supportive of any actions that may be taken or invoked by the Government or other agency to enforce non racism within sport or any other arena.

But there is no mention to answer the question as to what steps the Commonwealth Games Association is itself taking. It will support anything that anyone else does but apparently not take any action itself. I find the final paragraph most extraordinary and personally quite irrelevant. It states:

It is worthy of mention that the so called `joke' linked to Arthur Tunstall originated from a commercially sold tape marketed throughout Australia from your State of Queensland, one of five tapes which contain approximately 225 minutes of racist references.

How that contributes to the debate and how that sets high standards within the Commonwealth Games Association is absolutely beyond me. I know that a number of the 120 who signed the original statement of concern, plus a number of others who have since indicated to me that they would have liked to have signed it before it went off—but these things are invariably done in a rush and it is difficult to get around to everybody—will be concerned. I hope the 119 other parliamentarians who did sign the statement and other parliamentarians will take whatever action they deem is appropriate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to submit to the Senate that the Income Tax Assessment Act is a deterrent to all best practice for most of Australian businesses operating under this regime. Not only does it impose extraordinarily high compliance costs on taxpayers, particularly on businesses, but many of the notions are outdated—dating back to 1936—and revenue driven. To start with, taxable income is not the same as net profit. This indeed is unfortunate. Rather than the gap between the two concepts of income narrowing, we find that recent government amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act result in a widening of that gap between those two concepts of income. That scenario is not good news for Australian business.

PARA.TAB: I remind the Senate that, in making international tax comparisons after factoring in certain non-allowable tax items that are peculiar to the Australian regime, the Australian corporate tax rate is not all that favourable when looking at comparable OECD country regimes. We have a competent team rewriting in simplified form our tax laws. The job has just started.

I submit that in hindsight in a few years this could well be seen in retrospect as no more than a public relations exercise devoted to a plain English presentation. This approach will inevitable result in a loss of much valuable precedent that provides taxpayers with a degree of certainty so far as our laws are concerned. Tonight, I submit that a more fundamental or in-depth review is necessary. I would therefore wish to take some time of the Senate to outline just a few of the areas that need further review and examination.

A recent feature of tax legislation has been the bringing forward of the receipt of moneys to account as assessable income or capital gains whilst at the same time denying or extending over time the allowability of deductions. An example of the former is the grouping of corporations into small, medium and large companies with lodgment and payment schedules causing work scheduling problems for accountants and tax agents, particularly in the first group, and cash flow financing problems for the medium sized corporations.

As taxpayers are relentlessly pushed into the accrual system for the recording of income, it seems extraordinary that legally incurred obligations that are reflected in accruals for holiday pay, long service leave, sickness, et cetera cannot be recognised or claimed as a deduction until these items are actually paid in cash. The result is that to the net operating profit has to be added the various provisions, minus the cash payments in respect of some of those provisions—provisions which were raised often many years ago—in order to arrive at a taxable income.

While the Australian tax authorities have borrowed extensively from the UK and the US legislation, some of the concessions available in those countries, unfortunately, are not replicated in Australian law. For example, the winding up provisions of corporations. While the carrying forward of losses is permitted under Australian law, the write-back of losses is not recognised for either a three, two, or even one year period—in fact, it is not allowed at all in Australia.

Some OECD countries allow start-up costs, including environmental impact type costs, in full or probated over a given period. Another problem is that franchise fees and licence fees were not part of the 1936 vocabulary but are essential features of our ways of doing business as such, but the recognition of such costs is very limited in the Income Tax Assessment Act.

We also have a problem that where we have, say, a sole practitioner or a business person who incurs a debt after ceasing a business and, for example, joins the PAYE system and discharges some of those former debts and obligations as an honourable person, there is no tax recognition in section 51 of those costs.

I therefore wish to refer to an article in the Charter journal 1995 by Mr Peter M. Roach, who practises as a barrister in Hobart. I remind the Senate that he was formerly a senior member of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. He said:

It offends my sense of justice if the "proximity" rule is correct. If it is, that means that a wealthy person who at the point of closure of his business has the resources to satisfy all liabilities arising from that business gets all potential tax deductions, with a consequent reduction in tax liability. Yet his neighbour, for want of immediate resources, may have his tax liability increased because he has to toil for years to generate the funds to discharge his obligations.

Further, whether the taxpayer be wealthy or not, it offends me to think that a deduction will be denied a taxpayer only because liability and quantum cannot be determined (or may not be known or suspected) while the business is being carried on.

SPEECH.PARA: I also remind the Senate that tax thresholds are available for resident taxpayers for income tax but not for fringe benefits or capital gains tax—all in the same act.

PARA.TAB: Also in the third tranche of legislative amendments affecting overseas income, known as the FIF regime, there are further examples of anomalies. Firstly, double taxation can arise where investors hold investments through managed investment funds. This is clearly unacceptable and it is up to the government to introduce appropriate amending legislation.

Secondly, while the FIF scheme extends to options, convertible notes and similar instruments, there is no entitlement under the regime. These are all entitlements to acquire an interest in shares of a foreign company, but the FIF exemption extends only to shares and not to options, convertible notes and other instruments. Hence this drafting oversight falls into the category of a technical deficiency of part XI of the Income Tax Assessment Act and also needs amendment.

The tax structure that a taxpayer chooses can also determine the bottom line of tax payable. A few examples include: salaries may be paid to principals of small companies and trusts, but partners and sole traders are subject to provisional tax. Secondly, retirement benefits paid to principals are deductible to companies and trusts, but there is no similar provision for sole traders and partners. Thirdly, superannuation for principals is largely deductible to companies and trusts whereas individuals and partners are only entitled to claim $3,000 plus 75 per cent of the excess over $3,000.

What is needed is a comprehensive review of the anomalies created in the Income Tax Assessment Act which distinguish between small businesses operated through companies, trusts, partnerships and sole traders. Often the difference between a sole trader and a company operated by one person is negligible, but if the person wants to avail himself or herself of the benefits of a company, he or she must go to considerable initial and continuing annual expense.

A further problem is that the following are exempt or concessionally treated for fringe benefits tax purposes, but no similar exemption-concession exists in the Income Tax Assessment Act. For example, the sole trader or partners themselves—although the exemption-concession is available to employees of the sole trader partnership; minor benefits of $50 deductible to companies and trusts and exempt from FBT; exemption of in-house dining facilities; exemption of $500 of in-house fringe benefits; exempt property benefits versus goods for own use; exemption of child-care facilities provided to employees on the employer's premises; exemption of recreational facilities provided for employees; safety awards; and relocation benefits.

Unfortunately, my time has run out, Mr President. But these are just a few of the problems that are adding to cost compliance and inhibiting some of the world's best practice in terms of Australian companies being able to generate adequate cash flow. The increase in the corporate tax rate in the last budget will exacerbate the problem. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the two minutes that are available to me, I want to assure the workers in the forest industry around Australia and, in particular, in New South Wales, especially Mr Norm Wilton and Mr Dennis White, that there are people within the federal parliament genuinely concerned about the activity of certain elements within the environment movement who engage in eco-terrorism.

PARA.TAB: I refer to the attack on machinery in the Glenbog forest of southern New South Wales. Whilst that activity has received some condemnation from certain quarters, it is appropriate that it be condemned in the strongest possible terms by all right thinking Australians.

Mr President, these people, as you would be well aware, came to this parliament some four months ago fighting for their very livelihood during the blockade of the federal parliament. The forest industry is a vulnerable industry. For people to try to win the public debate by attacking machinery is one of the most cowardly acts that can be engaged in and an inappropriate activity, because people going about their lawful duties are being victimised by certain elements within the environment movement.

It should be noted that that sort of behaviour was, in fact, written about in glowing terms by Simon Balderstone, who used to be the senior adviser to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on environmental matters. He wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: Direct action, whether it be by lying in front of a bulldozer or sabotaging environmentally-destructive items—
Et cetera—and then gives credence and support to that activity. Those activities ought to be condemned.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 8 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the fact that the Government has indicated that it intends to establish a transfer protocol to allow more cost effective procedures for transferring accounts between superannuation funds and a register of unclaimed members benefits:

(1) Given that the commencement date for the transfer protocol is understood to be 1 July 1995, can an assurance be given that the legislation will be introduced and passed through the Senate in the Autumn session.
(2) What investigation has the Government undertaken in respect of the data interchange standards that will be utilised in the transfer protocol.
(3) At what stage are consultations between the Government and the funds administration industry on the most appropriate data interchange standards for implementing the transfer protocol.
(4) Has the Government decided which agency will be administering the unclaimed members' benefits register.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The development of a so called accounts transfer protocol, under which standard procedures would be developed to facilitate a more cost effective and efficient means of transferring and/or amalgamating multiple accounts within the superannuation system, was presented to the Government last year as an initiative the superannuation industry itself was working towards. For its part, the Government has announced that it will encourage and facilitate this initiative by removing where possible all taxation reporting and other regulatory burdens that currently apply to accounts transferred between superannuation funds.
(1) Minor changes to the Income Tax Regulations (Reg 99) to allow the transfer protocol to be implemented were gazetted on 15 June 1995.

(2)&(3) The industry is working to develop data interchange standards. The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) is also involved to determine if these standards can be adopted for the Superannuation Holding Accounts Reserve and Lost Members register systems.

(4) The Treasurer has determined that the ATO will administer the Lost Members (unclaimed members' benefits) register. Legislation currently before Parliament defers the commencement date of the register from 1 July 1995 to 1 July 1996.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 4 April 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) In what year did the Commonwealth Government first assume responsibility for domestic meat inspection in South Australia.
(2) When did the arrangement between the Commonwealth and South Australia for the Commonwealth to provide domestic meat inspection services in South Australia come to an end.

(3) What was the total annual cost to the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) of providing domestic meat inspection service in South Australia: (a) for the 1993-94 financial year; and (b) from 1 July 1994 until the date the South Australian Government withdrew from the arrangement.
(4) What was the total annual cost to AQIS of providing a domestic meat inspection service in Victoria for the 1993-94 financial year.

(5) In discussion with the Victorian and South Australian Governments over plans to withdraw from the arrangements under which AQIS provided domestic meat inspection services in those States, to what extent was the cost of AQIS services under existing fee for service arrangements an issue.

(6) Did the Bland Committee in 1976, the Kelly Committee in 1980 and the Royal Commission into Australian Meat Industry in 1982 identify the fragmentation of meat inspection in Australia as a problem and identify the need for a single national meat inspection service to overcome the problem.

(7) Was it the objective of the Government's full cost recovery policy to provide an incentive to the meat industry to reduce its inspection costs by assuming greater responsibility for self-regulation.

(8) At the time the Government decided to investigate the imposition of full fee for service arrangements on the meat industry, what advice was sought from those Commonwealth departments and agencies responsible for health and primary industries on the food safety implications of the policy.
(9) What advice was provided by relevant Commonwealth departments and agencies on the food safety implication of the policy.

(1O) To what extent was the Government influenced by the public interest considerations of public health and food safety in deciding that meat inspection services and meat testing systems would be fully funded by the industry and that none of those costs would be borne by the taxpayer.
(11) To what extent did the Government intend or anticipate that its fee for service policy would increase the fragmentation of meat inspection services across Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Commonwealth undertook the provision of meat inspection services at domestic abattoirs in South Australia from 1 July 1965 in accordance with the Meat Inspection Arrangements Act 1964. The standards pertaining to these services were determined under the State's legislation for meat hygiene. The State exercised responsibility for the administration of standards relating to construction and equipment at domestic meat premises in the State, including abattoirs, and additionally provided inspection services at slaughter houses and meat manufacturing premises throughout South Australia.
(2) The South Australian Government withdrew from the arrangement with the Commonwealth on 1 December 1994, upon proclamation of the South Australian Meat Hygiene Act 1994.
(3) The total cost to the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) of providing domestic meat inspection service in South Australia was:
(a) for the 1993-94 financial year, approximately $824,000; and
(b) from 1 July 1994 until the date the South Australian Government withdrew from the arrangement, approximately $404,000.
(4) The total cost to AQIS of providing domestic meat inspection services in Victoria for the 1993-94 financial year was approximately $7,770,000.

(5) The Victorian and South Australian Governments chose to invite competitive tenders for the provision of domestic meat inspection services in those States. Neither State sought to negotiate with AQIS or the Commonwealth on existing fee-for-service arrangements in the context of discussions regarding the termination of AQIS's role as service provider.

(6) It has not been possible to access a copy of the report by Sir Henry Bland to the Prime Minister in 1976, but in his report of the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry, the Hon. Mr Justice AE Woodward quoted the Bland Committee as finding the problem of overlapping State and Federal inspection systems to be intractable and the then existing dual system to be unsatisfactory. The Kelly Committee in 1980 recommended the formation of an independent national inspection service. The recommendations of the Report of the Royal Commission in 1982 allude to joint Commonwealth and State authorities for the administration of meat inspection. Prior to the 1980's there were dual meat inspection systems under which both the Commonwealth and States supplied meat inspection services at export registered premises with the Commonwealth exercising control over export meat and the States control over domestic meat. Mr Justice Woodward concluded that there was a compelling case for a single inspection service, but no simple solution for its achievement. He suggested as an interim arrangement in most States a joint meat inspection authority between the Commonwealth Government and the government of each State.

(7) & (8), (9) & (10) The Government's primary objective in implementing full recovery of user attributable costs for meat inspection from 1991 was to give effect to its general policy that the beneficiaries of such services should pay for them. There were no associated implications for food safety, since no reduction in standards under the administration of AQIS was intended or anticipated. The introduction by AQIS of measures under which industry assumed greater direct responsibility for ensuring the safety of its products commenced in 1986 with the establishment of operational hygiene requirements under a code of practice. Subsequently AQIS has progressively introduced options for regulatory objectives to be achieved under quality assurance arrangements. Adoption by industry of officially sanctioned quality assurance under AQIS auditing has been subject to the criterion that the performance of systems under such an arrangement must be at least as good as under traditional inspection methods.
(11) The Government neither intended nor anticipated that its fee-for-service policy would cause fragmentation of meat inspection services.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 10 May 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission receive correspondence from A J Hosen (sic) and Co Barrister and Solicitor, dated 26 November 1993, referring to sections 11(f), 20 and 29 of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Act.
(2) Did the commission receive subsequent correspondence, dated 27 April 1994 and 11 October 1994, relating to the same matter.
(3) Has the commission taken any action in relation to this correspondence; if so, what action has been taken; if not, why not.
(4) Why is this matter not included in the commission's 1993-94 annual report as matters received in writing by the commission classified as relating to sexual preference (page 34).
(5) Has the commission received any other such requests for action or advice.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: I am informed by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission of the following:

(1) No. The Commission received a letter from a A J Hosken and Co, Barristers and Solicitors on September 21 1993, but it contained no reference to ss 11(f), 20 and 29 of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986. The matter was registered as an inquiry, not a complaint. A reply to the letter was sent on the date in question, November 26 1993, in which the Commission advised Hosken and Co that the matters raised in their letter of September 21 1993 did not fall within the Commission's jurisdiction and recommended that assistance be sought from the West Australian Ombudsman. The file was then closed.

(2) The Commission received a letter dated April 27 1994 referring to this matter. It contained the first reference of which the Commission is aware to ss 11(f), 20 and 29 of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act, and indicated that the Commission's letter of November 26 1993 had been received. The Commission has no correspondence relating to this matter dated October 11 1994.

(3) The response of the Commission that it had no power to investigate the complaint was conveyed to A J Hosken and Co in the Commission's letter of November 26 1993. Mr Hosken advised in his letter of April 27 1994 that he had obtained legal advice to the effect that the Commission could investigate his complaint but he did not provide that advice to the Commission. Telephone contact was made with Mr Hosken on May 9 1994, but no further information was subsequently received in support of his complaint. Consequently no further action was taken. A letter reconfirming the Commission's view of the issues was sent to Mr Hosken on 18 May 1995.

(4) Page 34 of the Commission's 1993/94 Annual Report shows that two inquiries about matters not covered by Commission legislation were received in the central Sydney office of the Commission. It also shows that 192 inquiries were recorded as related to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act, the Act under which Hosken and Co were purporting to complain.

(5) The Commission is currently considering a number of matters relating to sexual preference, but none relating to alleged police harassment of gay men or gender discrepancies in the State or Territory Criminal Codes as to permissible age limits for certain sexual practices. Any such requests for action or advice would be declined as being outside the Commission's jurisdiction or they would be referred to an appropriate State agency for investigation.
